complications: Trouble at work home or school
Problems with alcohol and other substance use
preventions: Develop new ways of thinking cognitive restructuring
Learn ways to improve your communication
diagnosis: Use the criteria in the DSM5

name: DiGeorge syndrome
description: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) is a disorder caused by a defect in chromosome 22, resulting in poor development of several body systems.
symptoms: Heart murmur and bluish skin due to poor circulation of oxygen-rich blood (cyanosis) as a result of a heart defect
Certain facial features, such as an underdeveloped chin, low-set ears, wide-set eyes or a narrow groove in the upper lip
A gap in the roof of the mouth (cleft palate) or other problems with the palate
Difficulty feeding, failure to gain weight or gastrointestinal problems
Delayed development, such as delays in rolling over, sitting up or other infant milestones
Delayed speech development or nasal-sounding speech
diagnosis: A combination of medical problems or conditions suggesting 22q11.2 deletion syndrome
A heart defect, because certain heart defects are commonly associated with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome

name: Prader-Willi syndrome
description: Prader-Willi syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that results in physical, mental and behavioral problems, including a constant sense of hunger.
causes: Paternal genes on chromosome 15 are missing.
The child inherited two copies of chromosome 15 from the mother and no chromosome 15 from the father.
There's some error or defect in paternal genes on chromosome 15.

name: Brain aneurysm
description: Learn about the signs and symptoms that may occur when a thinning wall of a blood vessel in your brain bulges — and know when to get emergency care.
risks: Narrow aorta coarctation of the aorta
complications: Narrowed blood vessels in the brain
A buildup of fluid within the brain hydrocephalus

name: Depression
description: Depression is a mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest and can interfere with your daily functioning.
symptoms: Feelings of sadness, tearfulness, emptiness or hopelessness
Angry outbursts, irritability or frustration, even over small matters
Loss of interest or pleasure in most or all normal activities, such as sex, hobbies or sports
Sleep disturbances, including insomnia or sleeping too much
Tiredness and lack of energy, so even small tasks take extra effort
Reduced appetite and weight loss or increased cravings for food and weight gain
Slowed thinking, speaking or body movements
Feelings of worthlessness or guilt, fixating on past failures or self-blame
Trouble thinking, concentrating, making decisions and remembering things
Frequent or recurrent thoughts of death, suicidal thoughts, suicide attempts or suicide
Unexplained physical problems, such as back pain or headaches
risks: Certain personality traits, such as low self-esteem and being too dependent, self-critical or pessimistic
Traumatic or stressful events, such as physical or sexual abuse, the death or loss of a loved one, a difficult relationship, or financial problems
Blood relatives with a history of depression, bipolar disorder, alcoholism or suicide
Being lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender, or having variations in the development of genital organs that aren't clearly male or female (intersex) in an unsupportive situation
History of other mental health disorders, such as anxiety disorder, eating disorders or post-traumatic stress disorder
Abuse of alcohol or recreational drugs
Serious or chronic illness, including cancer, stroke, chronic pain or heart disease
Certain medications, such as some high blood pressure medications or sleeping pills (talk to your doctor before stopping any medication)
complications: Excess weight or obesity, which can lead to heart disease and diabetes
Anxiety, panic disorder or social phobia
Family conflicts, relationship difficulties, and work or school problems
Suicidal feelings, suicide attempts or suicide
preventions: Reach out to family and friends
Get treatment at the earliest sign of a problem

name: Precocious puberty
description: Read about the signs and symptoms, causes, and risk factors that may cause a child's body to begin changing into an adult's body too soon.
symptoms: Breast growth and first period in girls
Enlarged testicles and penis, facial hair and deepening voice in boys
risks: Having received radiation therapy of the central nervous system
preventions: Keeping your child away from external sources of estrogen and testosterone — such as prescription medications for adults in the house or dietary supplements containing estrogen or testosterone
Encouraging your child to maintain a healthy weight
diagnosis: Review your child's and your family's medical history
Run blood tests to measure hormone levels

name: Interstitial cystitis
description: Bladder pain and urinary frequency flare with certain triggers if you have this condition. Learn about treatments and self-care.
symptoms: Pain in your pelvis or between the vagina and anus in women
Pain between the scrotum and anus (perineum) in men
A persistent, urgent need to urinate
Frequent urination, often of small amounts, throughout the day and night (up to 60 times a day)
Pain or discomfort while the bladder fills and relief after urinating

name: Genital warts
description: The human papillomavirus (HPV) causes the most common of sexually transmitted infections. Vaccines can help protect against the HPV strains that cause genital warts.
risks: Having unprotected sex with multiple partners
Having had another sexually transmitted infection
Having sex with a partner whose sexual history you don't know
Becoming sexually active at a young age
Having a compromised immune system, such as from HIV or drugs from an organ transplant

name: Popliteal aneurysm
description: Learn more about this lower extremity aneurysm that occurs in the wall of an artery located behind the knee.
causes: Wear and tear of the popliteal artery due to repetitive use of the knee joint
risks: Narrowing of a heart valve (stenotic disease)
Having three or more aneurysms anywhere in the body
complications: A change in skin color in the affected area
Skin in the affected area feels cold

name: Postpartum depression
description: Learn the risk factors and symptoms of depression in new mothers, as well as effective treatment that can help you manage symptoms and bond with your baby.
risks: You have a history of depression, either during pregnancy or at other times.
You had postpartum depression after a previous pregnancy.
You have family members who've had depression or other mood disorders.
You've experienced stressful events during the past year, such as pregnancy complications, illness or job loss.
Your baby has health problems or other special needs.
You have twins, triplets or other multiple births.
You're having problems in your relationship with your spouse or partner.
You have a weak support system.
The pregnancy was unplanned or unwanted.

name: Ventricular fibrillation
description: Without fast treatment, this heart rhythm problem can cause death within minutes. Learn the symptoms of VFib and what actions to take to save a life.
risks: A previous episode of ventricular fibrillation
A heart problem present at birth (congenital heart defect)
Injuries that cause damage to the heart muscle, such as being struck by lightning
Drug misuse, especially with cocaine or methamphetamine
A severe imbalance of potassium or magnesium

name: Interstitial lung disease
description: In interstitial lung disease, progressive lung can cause permanent breathing problems. Learn the causes, including many toxins in the environment.
symptoms: Shortness of breath at rest or aggravated by exertion
risks: Exposure to occupational and environmental toxins
complications: High blood pressure in your lungs pulmonary hypertension
treatment: Medications that slow the progression of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

name: Prediabetes
description: Blood sugar levels start to rise even before you get type 2 diabetes. Find out what steps you can take to prevent diabetes from developing.
symptoms: Numbness or tingling in the feet or hands
causes: Your pancreas may not make enough insulin
Your cells become resistant to insulin and don't allow as much sugar in
complications: Eye damage, including loss of vision
preventions: Controlling your blood pressure and cholesterol

name: Thoracic aortic aneurysm
description: Learn about this serious condition in which the upper part of the body's main artery becomes weak and may rupture.
symptoms: Tenderness or pain in the chest
risks: Buildup of plaques in the arteries
complications: Lifethreatening bleeding inside the body internal bleeding
preventions: Don't smoke or use tobacco products.
Keep blood pressure and cholesterol levels under control.
Reduce cholesterol and fat in the diet.

name: Teen depression
description: This serious mental health problem affects how your teenager thinks, feels and behaves, and can cause emotional, functional and physical problems.
symptoms: Contact a suicide hotline. In the U.S., call or text 988 to reach the 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline, available 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Or use the Lifeline Chat. The Spanish language phone line is 1-888-628-9454 (toll-free). Services are free and confidential. Or contact a crisis service for teenagers in the U.S. called TXT 4 HELP: Text the word "safe" and your current location to 4HELP (44357) for immediate help, with the option for interactive texting.

In the U.S., call or text 988 to reach the 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline, available 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Or use the Lifeline Chat. The Spanish language phone line is 1-888-628-9454 (toll-free). Services are free and confidential.
Or contact a crisis service for teenagers in the U.S. called TXT 4 HELP: Text the word "safe" and your current location to 4HELP (44357) for immediate help, with the option for interactive texting.
Seek help from your primary care doctor or other health care provider.
Reach out to a close friend or loved one.
Contact a minister, spiritual leader or someone else in your faith community.
risks: Having issues that negatively impact self-esteem, such as obesity, peer problems, long-term bullying or academic problems
Having been the victim or witness of violence, such as physical or sexual abuse
Having other mental health conditions, such as bipolar disorder, an anxiety disorder, a personality disorder, anorexia or bulimia
Having a learning disability or attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
Having ongoing pain or a chronic physical illness such as cancer, diabetes or asthma
Having certain personality traits, such as low self-esteem or being overly dependent, self-critical or pessimistic
Abusing alcohol, nicotine or other drugs
Being gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender in an unsupportive environment
preventions: Reach out for friendship and social support
Get treatment at the earliest sign of a problem

name: Aneurysm
description: A bulge or ballooning of a blood vessel wall may not cause symptoms. Learn how doctors assess your risk of rupture and when it's treated.

name: Intestinal ischemia
description: Learn about what happens when blood flow to part of the small or large intestine is blocked, and how this serious condition is treated.
symptoms: Abdominal cramps or fullness, usually within 30 minutes after eating, and lasting 1 to 3 hours
Abdominal pain that gets gradually worse over weeks or months
Fear of eating because of pain that happens after eating
causes: Blockage in an artery caused by a blood clot
Narrowing of an artery due to buildup of fatty deposits, such as cholesterol (atherosclerosis)
Low blood pressure leading to an overall reduced blood flow
Blockage in a vein, less commonly
risks: Buildup of fatty deposits in your arteries atherosclerosis
complications: A hole through the wall of the intestines
Scarring or narrowing of your intestine
diagnosis: A scope to see inside your digestive tract
Dye that tracks blood flow through the arteries

name: Premature ventricular contractions
description: Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) are extra heartbeats that disrupt the heart rhythm. PVCs are common.
risks: Stimulants such as cocaine or methamphetamines
Exercise — if you have certain types of PVCs
Heart disease, including congenital heart disease, coronary artery disease, heart failure and a weakened heart muscle (cardiomyopathy)

name: Dermatitis
description: Learn about the types, symptoms, causes and treatments — moisturizers and medications — for this itchy skin condition that affects people of all ages.
treatment: Applying to the affected skin corticosteroid creams, gels or ointments
Applying to the affected skin certain creams or ointments that affect your immune system (calcineurin inhibitors)
Exposing the affected area to controlled amounts of natural or artificial light (phototherapy)
Using oral corticosteroids (pills) or injectable dupilumab, for severe disease
Using wet dressings, a medical treatment for severe atopic dermatitis that involves applying a corticosteroid and wrapping it with wet bandages

name: Preeclampsia
description: Learn about the diagnosis, treatment of this pregnancy complication of high blood pressure with related damage to the kidneys or other organs.
symptoms: Excess protein in urine (proteinuria) or other signs of kidney problems
Decreased levels of platelets in blood (thrombocytopenia)
Increased liver enzymes that indicate liver problems
Changes in vision, including temporary loss of vision, blurred vision or light sensitivity
Shortness of breath, caused by fluid in the lungs
Pain in the upper belly, usually under the ribs on the right side
risks: Being pregnant with more than one baby
Type 1 or type 2 diabetes before pregnancy
diagnosis: Protein in your urine (proteinuria), indicating an impaired kidney
Elevated liver enzymes showing an impaired liver
New headaches that don't go away after taking pain medication
treatment: Antihypertensive drugs to lower blood pressure
Anticonvulsant medication, such as magnesium sulfate, to prevent seizures
Corticosteroids to promote development of your baby's lungs before delivery

name: Angelman syndrome
description: Learn about this genetic disorder that causes developmental delays, problems with speech and other symptoms.
symptoms: Developmental delays, including no crawling or babbling at 6 to 12 months
Difficulty walking, moving or balancing well
Trouble going to sleep and staying asleep

name: Whipple's disease
description: Learn more about the symptoms, causes and treatment of this rare primarily digestive infection.
risks: White people in North America and Europe
Farmers and other people who work outdoors and have frequent contact with sewage and wastewater

name: Ventricular septal defect
description: In this heart problem present at birth, there is a hole between the two lower heart chambers. Know the symptoms and when surgery is needed.
symptoms: Slow or no physical growth (failure to thrive)
Whooshing sound when listening to the heart with a stethoscope (heart murmur)
risks: Down syndrome and other genetic conditions
Family history of heart problems present at birth (congenital heart defects)
preventions: Get early prenatal care even before youre pregnant
Take a multivitamin with folic acid
Check with your provider before taking any medications
diagnosis: Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging MRI scan

name: Atopic dermatitis
description: Learn about the causes, symptoms and treatments of this itchy rash that most often begins before age 5, is persistent, and has periods of clearing and relapse.
complications: Patches of skin thats darker or lighter than the surrounding area
preventions: Moisturize your skin at least twice a day
Take a daily bath or shower
treatment: Medicated products applied to the skin

name: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
description: In WPW syndrome, an extra pathway between the heart's upper and lower chambers causes a fast heartbeat. Rarely, it can cause sudden cardiac death.
symptoms: Blue or gray coloring to the skin, lips and nails (cyanosis)

name: Vasculitis
description: An inflammation of the blood vessels, vasculitis may thicken and weaken blood vessel walls. If blood flow is restricted, organ damage can occur.
causes: Infections, such as hepatitis B and hepatitis C
Immune system diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis, lupus and scleroderma
diagnosis: Xrays of your blood vessels angiography

name: Intestinal obstruction
description: A blocked intestine needs prompt medical care. Learn about symptoms and the wide range of causes for this serious but treatable digestive disorder.
symptoms: Crampy abdominal pain that comes and goes
Inability to have a bowel movement or pass gas
risks: Abdominal or pelvic surgery, which often causes adhesions — a common intestinal obstruction
Crohn's disease, which can cause the intestine's walls to thicken, narrowing the passageway

name: Ventricular tachycardia
description: Ventricular tachycardia: When a rapid heartbeat is life-threatening
causes: Prior heart attack or other heart condition that caused scarring of heart tissue (structural heart disease)
Poor blood flow to the heart muscle due to coronary artery disease
Congenital heart diseases, including long QT syndrome
Imbalance of substances in the blood called electrolytes — such as potassium, sodium, calcium and magnesium
Use of stimulants such as cocaine or methamphetamine
risks: Use of stimulant drugs such as cocaine or methamphetamine
complications: How fast the heart is beating
How long the rapid heart rate lasts
Whether there are other heart conditions
preventions: Exercise and maintain a healthy weight
Control blood pressure and cholesterol levels

name: Swimmer's itch
description: Learn more about the symptoms, treatment and prevention of this itchy rash that usually affects people swimming in freshwater lakes.
risks: Spending time in water that's infested with certain parasites.
Forgetting to dry off with a towel after getting out of the water.
Being sensitive to the parasites that cause swimmer's itch.

name: Angina
description: Learn about a type of chest pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart. This symptom is a sign of underlying heart disease.
preventions: Managing other health conditions related to heart disease.
Getting recommended vaccines to avoid heart complications.

name: Intracranial hematoma
description: An intracranial hematoma is a serious, possibly life-threatening, complication of head trauma. Find out more signs and symptoms of intracranial hematoma.
symptoms: Drowsiness and progressive loss of consciousness
Loss of movement (paralysis) on the opposite side of the body from the head injury
preventions: Wear a helmet and make sure your kids wear helmets
Buckle your seat belt and make sure your kids are buckled in

name: Preeclampsia
description: Learn about the diagnosis, treatment of this pregnancy complication of high blood pressure with related damage to the kidneys or other organs.
symptoms: Excess protein in urine (proteinuria) or other signs of kidney problems
Decreased levels of platelets in blood (thrombocytopenia)
Increased liver enzymes that indicate liver problems
Changes in vision, including temporary loss of vision, blurred vision or light sensitivity
Shortness of breath, caused by fluid in the lungs
Pain in the upper belly, usually under the ribs on the right side
risks: Being pregnant with more than one baby
Type 1 or type 2 diabetes before pregnancy
diagnosis: Protein in your urine (proteinuria), indicating an impaired kidney
Elevated liver enzymes showing an impaired liver
New headaches that don't go away after taking pain medication
treatment: Antihypertensive drugs to lower blood pressure
Anticonvulsant medication, such as magnesium sulfate, to prevent seizures
Corticosteroids to promote development of your baby's lungs before delivery

name: Vertebral tumor
description: Vertebral tumors grow in the bones of the spine, causing pain and weakening the spinal column. Read more about how they’re managed, and what to expect.
symptoms: Pain at the site of the tumor due to tumor growth
Back pain, often radiating to other parts of your body
Back pain that's worse at night
Loss of sensation or muscle weakness, especially in your arms or legs
Difficulty walking, sometimes leading to falls
Feeling less sensitive to cold, heat and pain
Loss of bowel or bladder function
Paralysis, which may be mild or severe, and can strike in different areas throughout the body

name: Contact dermatitis
description: Contact with certain substances, such as poison ivy, skin lotions and detergents, can cause an itchy rash. Here's how to manage this common form of dermatitis.
risks: Cooks and others who work with food
Health care workers, including dental workers
Scuba divers or swimmers, due to the rubber in face masks or goggles
preventions: Apply an ironon patch to cover metal fasteners next to your skin
Apply a barrier cream or gel

name: Intracranial venous malformation
description: Intracranial venous malformations are abnormally enlarged veins in your brain. Find out more about diagnosis and treatment of this neurological condition.

name: Angina
description: Learn about a type of chest pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart. This symptom is a sign of underlying heart disease.
preventions: Managing other health conditions related to heart disease.
Getting recommended vaccines to avoid heart complications.

name: Premature birth
description: Having a preemie can be overwhelming. Here's what you need to know about your baby's care and the possible complications of a premature birth.
symptoms: Small size, with a disproportionately large head
Sharper looking, less rounded features than a full-term baby's features, due to a lack of fat stores
Fine hair (lanugo) covering much of the body
Low body temperature, especially immediately after birth in the delivery room, due to a lack of stored body fat
Lack of reflexes for sucking and swallowing, leading to feeding difficulties
risks: Pregnancy with twins, triplets or other multiples
An interval of less than six months between pregnancies
Problems with the uterus, cervix or placenta
Smoking cigarettes or using illicit drugs
Some infections, particularly of the amniotic fluid and lower genital tract
Some chronic conditions, such as high blood pressure and diabetes
Being underweight or overweight before pregnancy
Stressful life events, such as the death of a loved one or domestic violence
treatment: Surfactant, a medication used to treat respiratory distress syndrome
Fine-mist (aerosolized) or IV medication to strengthen breathing and heart rate
Antibiotics if infection is present or if there's a risk of possible infection
Medicines that increase urine output (diuretics) to manage excess fluid
An injection of medication into the eye to stop the growth of new blood vessels that could cause retinopathy of prematurity
Medicine that helps close the heart defect known as patent ductus arteriosus

name: Vesicoureteral reflux
description: Learn about what happens if urine flows backward from the bladder. Usually found in children, this condition boosts the risk of urinary tract infections.
symptoms: A strong, persistent urge to urinate
The need to pass small amounts of urine frequently
Pain in your side (flank) or abdomen
diagnosis: Specialized Xray of urinary tract system

name: Neurodermatitis
description: Learn about this itchy skin condition that can disrupt your sleep and daily activities. Treatment focuses on controlling itching and preventing scratching.
symptoms: An itchy, scaly skin patch or patches
Raised, rough patches that are inflamed or darker than the rest of the skin

name: Hives and angioedema
description: Learn more about these common but short-lived skin conditions, their symptoms, causes and home remedies, and how to prevent them.
risks: Have had hives or angioedema before
Have a family history of hives, angioedema or hereditary angioedema
treatment: Drugs that suppress the immune system

name: Ductal carcinoma in situ
description: Noninvasive breast cancer often has no signs or symptoms. Find out how doctors diagnose DCIS and learn about treatment, including mastectomy and lumpectomy.
risks: Personal history of benign breast disease, such as atypical hyperplasia
Having your first baby after age 30
Having your first period before age 12
Genetic mutations that increase the risk of breast cancer, such as those in the breast cancer genes BRCA1 and BRCA2

name: Premature ejaculation
description: Understand what may cause ejaculation to happen earlier than wanted during sex. Also learn how to treat and prevent it.

name: Acoustic neuroma
description: Acoustic neuroma is a tumor that grows on the balance and hearing nerve in the head that may cause hearing loss.
symptoms: Hearing loss, usually gradually worsening over months to years — although in rare cases sudden — and occurring on only one side or more severe on one side
Facial numbness and weakness or loss of muscle movement

name: Seborrheic dermatitis
description: Find out what you can do to treat this flaky skin condition that can cause scaly skin and stubborn, itchy dandruff.
symptoms: Flaking skin (dandruff) on your scalp, hair, eyebrows, beard or mustache
Patches of greasy skin covered with flaky white or yellow scales or crust on the scalp, face, sides of the nose, eyebrows, ears, eyelids, chest, armpits, groin area or under the breasts
Rash that may look darker or lighter in people with brown or Black skin and redder in those with white skin
Ring-shaped (annular) rash, for a type called petaloid seborrheic dermatitis
risks: Nervous system conditions, such as Parkinson's disease
Having a mental health condition, such as depression
Immune system disorders, such as HIV infection
Recovery from stressful medical conditions, such as a heart attack
treatment: Antifungal gels creams lotions foams or shampoos alternated with another medication
Creams lotions shampoos or ointments that control inflammation
Antifungal medication you take as a pill

name: Castleman disease
description: This rare disorder involves an overgrowth of cells in your body's lymph nodes. Treatment varies depending on how many lymph nodes are involved.

name: Cholestasis of pregnancy
description: This liver condition can occur late in pregnancy, triggering intense itching. The risk of complications for your baby may require early delivery.
symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes, called jaundice
risks: Personal or family history of cholestasis of pregnancy
History of liver damage or disease, including hepatitis C and gallbladder stones
Pregnancy at an older age, such as 35 years or older
complications: Being born too early, also called preterm birth.

Lung problems from breathing in meconium. Meconium is the sticky, green substance that typically collects in the developing baby's intestines. Meconium may pass into the amniotic fluid if a mom has cholestasis.
Death of the baby late in pregnancy before delivery, also called stillbirth.
diagnosis: Ask questions about your symptoms and medical history
Order blood tests to measure the level of bile acids in your blood and to check how well your liver is working

name: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans
description: Learn about symptoms and diagnosis for this rare type of skin cancer. DFSP treatments include Mohs surgery, radiation and targeted therapy.

name: Primary ovarian insufficiency
description: Primary ovarian insufficiency, also called premature ovarian failure, occurs in women under age 40. Hormone therapy can lessen uncomfortable symptoms.
symptoms: Irregular or skipped periods, which might be present for years or develop after a pregnancy or after stopping birth control pills
causes: An immune system response to ovarian tissue autoimmune disease

name: Ventricular fibrillation
description: Without fast treatment, this heart rhythm problem can cause death within minutes. Learn the symptoms of VFib and what actions to take to save a life.
risks: A previous episode of ventricular fibrillation
A heart problem present at birth (congenital heart defect)
Injuries that cause damage to the heart muscle, such as being struck by lightning
Drug misuse, especially with cocaine or methamphetamine
A severe imbalance of potassium or magnesium

name: Angiosarcoma
description: Learn about this rare cancer that begins in the blood vessels and lymph vessels. Treatments include surgery, radiation therapy and chemotherapy.
risks: Swelling caused by lymph vessel damage
diagnosis: Removing a sample of tissue for testing

name: Intussusception
description: This rare but serious disorder occurs when one part of the intestine slides into another part, like a collapsible telescope.
risks: Henoch-Schonlein purpura, also known as IgA vasculitis.
treatment: A water soluble contrast or air enema

name: Dermatographia
description: Dermatographia — Comprehensive overview covers symptoms, treatment of this skin condition.

name: Precocious puberty
description: Read about the signs and symptoms, causes, and risk factors that may cause a child's body to begin changing into an adult's body too soon.
symptoms: Breast growth and first period in girls
Enlarged testicles and penis, facial hair and deepening voice in boys
risks: Having received radiation therapy of the central nervous system
preventions: Keeping your child away from external sources of estrogen and testosterone — such as prescription medications for adults in the house or dietary supplements containing estrogen or testosterone
Encouraging your child to maintain a healthy weight
diagnosis: Review your child's and your family's medical history
Run blood tests to measure hormone levels

name: Viral gastroenteritis
description: This condition, often called stomach flu, is usually harmless, except for infants and people with immunosuppression. Symptoms can usually be managed.
risks: Anyone with a weakened immune system
preventions: Use separate personal items around your home
Avoid touching laundry that may have been exposed to a virus
Check out your child care center

name: Broken ankle
description: A simple misstep or twisting injury can cause bone fractures. Treatment depends on the exact site of injury and its severity.
symptoms: Difficulty or pain with walking or bearing weight
risks: Use improper technique or sports equipment
Keep your home cluttered or poorly lit

name: Invasive lobular carcinoma
description: Breast cancer that begins in the milk-producing glands of the breast is uncommon. Learn what sets lobular carcinoma apart from other breast cancer types.
symptoms: An area of thickening in part of the breast
A new area of fullness or swelling in the breast
A change in the texture or appearance of the skin over the breast, such as dimpling or thickening
preventions: Discuss the benefits and risks of menopausal hormone therapy with your doctor
Drink alcohol in moderation if at all
Exercise most days of the week

name: Dermatomyositis
description: Muscle weakness and a skin rash are hallmarks of dermatomyositis. There's no cure, but treatments can relieve symptoms.

name: Viral hemorrhagic fevers
description: Learn more about the symptoms, treatment and prevention of these sometimes deadly diseases.
symptoms: Bleeding under the skin, in internal organs, or from the mouth, eyes or ears
risks: Sharing needles to use intravenous drugs
Working outdoors or in rat-infested buildings
Being exposed to infected blood or other body fluids

name: Premature ventricular contractions
description: Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) are extra heartbeats that disrupt the heart rhythm. PVCs are common.
risks: Stimulants such as cocaine or methamphetamines
Exercise — if you have certain types of PVCs
Heart disease, including congenital heart disease, coronary artery disease, heart failure and a weakened heart muscle (cardiomyopathy)

name: Iritis
description: Learn about who's at risk of this eye condition and why you should get treatment right away if you have symptoms.
symptoms: Discomfort or achiness in the affected eye
risks: Have a weakened immune system or an autoimmune disorder

name: Sprained ankle
description: Sprained ankle — Injury to a ligament of the ankle can usually be treated with at-home care and appropriate exercises to get you back on your feet.
symptoms: Pain, especially when you bear weight on the affected foot
Tenderness when you touch the ankle
Popping sensation or sound at the time of injury
preventions: Warm up before you exercise or play sports.
Be careful when walking, running or working on an uneven surface.
Use an ankle support brace or tape on a weak or previously injured ankle.
Wear shoes that fit well and are made for your activity.
Don't play sports or participate in activities for which you are not conditioned.
Maintain good muscle strength and flexibility.
Practice stability training, including balance exercises.

name: Athlete's foot
description: Learn about the causes, symptoms, prevention and treatment of this common fungal skin infection.
risks: Share mats, rugs, bed linens, clothes or shoes with someone who has a fungal infection
Walk barefoot in public areas where the infection can spread, such as locker rooms, saunas, swimming pools, communal baths and showers
preventions: Protect your feet in public places
Be aware of the risk factors for spreading the condition

name: PMS
description: Mood swings, cramps and irritability are just a few telltale clues that you're getting your period. Learn what you can do for PMS symptom relief.

name: Vitamin deficiency anemia
description: A lack of folate and vitamin B-12 can cause a type of anemia in which red blood cells become too large and can't carry oxygen properly.
symptoms: Numbness or tingling in the hands and feet
preventions: Fortified foods, such as breakfast cereals
diagnosis: The number and appearance of red blood cells
The amount of vitamin B-12 and folate in the blood
The presence of antibodies to intrinsic factor, which indicates pernicious anemia
treatment: Injections into a muscle or under the skin
A liquid or tablet that dissolves under the tongue

name: Tongue-tie
description: With tongue-tie (ankyloglossia), a band of tissue (frenulum) tethers the tongue, restricting the range of motion. Learn about symptoms and treatment.
symptoms: Difficulty lifting the tongue to the upper teeth or moving the tongue from side to side
Trouble sticking out the tongue past the lower front teeth
A tongue that appears notched or heart shaped when stuck out

name: Iron deficiency anemia
description: Iron deficiency anemia — Comprehensive overview covers symptoms, causes, treatment of this blood disorder.
symptoms: Chest pain, fast heartbeat or shortness of breath
Inflammation or soreness of your tongue
Unusual cravings for non-nutritive substances, such as ice, dirt or starch
Poor appetite, especially in infants and children with iron deficiency anemia
causes: A lack of iron in your diet
diagnosis: Red blood cell size and color

name: Desmoid tumor
description: Learn how doctors use surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy and other medications to treat desmoid tumors, also known as aggressive fibromatosis.
symptoms: A mass or area of swelling
Loss of function in the affected area
Cramping and nausea, when desmoid tumors occur in the abdomen
risks: A genetic syndrome that causes many colon polyps
diagnosis: Removing a sample of tissue for testing biopsy
treatment: Monitoring the growth of the tumor

name: PMS
description: Mood swings, cramps and irritability are just a few telltale clues that you're getting your period. Learn what you can do for PMS symptom relief.

name: Vitiligo
description: Learn more about this condition in which your skin loses pigment cells, resulting in very light or white patches on parts of the body.
symptoms: Patchy loss of skin color, which usually first appears on the hands, face, and areas around body openings and the genitals
Premature whitening or graying of the hair on your scalp, eyelashes, eyebrows or beard
Loss of color in the tissues that line the inside of the mouth and nose (mucous membranes)
treatment: Medications that affect the immune system

name: Ankylosing spondylitis
description: Learn about this inflammatory disease that can cause some of the vertebrae in the spine to fuse over time.
symptoms: The joint between the base of the spine and the pelvis
The vertebrae in the lower back
The places where tendons and ligaments attach to bones, mainly in the spine, but sometimes along the back of the heel
The cartilage between the breastbone and the ribs

name: Hemochromatosis
description: This liver disorder causes your body to absorb too much iron from the foods you eat. Learn about symptoms, causes and treatment for this condition that usually runs in families.
risks: Having two copies of an altered HFE gene

name: Desmoplastic small round cell tumor
description: These rare, aggressive cancers most often form in the abdomen. Learn about DSRCT treatments, including surgery, chemotherapy and radiation therapy.
diagnosis: Removing a sample of tissue for testing

name: Vocal cord paralysis
description: Find out more about this condition caused by problems with the nerves that control your voice box.
causes: Injury to the vocal cord during surgery

name: Age-related hearing loss
description: Age- and noise-related hearing loss are common and can affect quality of life. But many treatments are available.
symptoms: Muffling of speech and other sounds
Difficulty understanding words, especially against background noise or in a crowd
Frequently asking others to speak more slowly, clearly and loudly
Needing to turn up the volume of the television or radio

name: Anorexia nervosa
description: Anorexia is an eating disorder characterized by an abnormally low body weight, intense fear of gaining weight and a distorted perception of body weight.
complications: Heart problems, such as mitral valve prolapse, abnormal heart rhythms or heart failure
Bone loss (osteoporosis), increasing the risk of fractures
In females, absence of a period
Gastrointestinal problems, such as constipation, bloating or nausea
Electrolyte abnormalities, such as low blood potassium, sodium and chloride
treatment: Not seeing anorexia as an illness but rather a lifestyle choice

name: Irritable bowel syndrome
description: Lifestyle changes can make a big difference when it comes to managing this common GI disorder. Learn more about symptoms, diagnosis, and how to avoid triggers for this long-term condition.
symptoms: Abdominal pain, cramping or bloating that is related to passing a bowel movement
Changes in appearance of bowel movement
Changes in how often you are having a bowel movement
risks: Have a family history of IBS
Have anxiety depression or other mental health issues

name: Retinal detachment
description: Eye floaters and reduced vision are signs of possible retinal detachment. Find out about causes and treatment for this eye emergency.
symptoms: The sudden appearance of many floaters — tiny specks that seem to drift through your field of vision
Flashes of light in one or both eyes (photopsia)
A curtain-like shadow over your field of vision
risks: Aging — retinal detachment is more common in people over age 50
Previous retinal detachment in one eye
Previous eye surgery, such as cataract removal
Previous other eye disease or disorder, including retinoschisis, uveitis or thinning of the peripheral retina (lattice degeneration)

name: Vocal cord paralysis
description: Find out more about this condition caused by problems with the nerves that control your voice box.
causes: Injury to the vocal cord during surgery

name: Intestinal ischemia
description: Learn about what happens when blood flow to part of the small or large intestine is blocked, and how this serious condition is treated.
symptoms: Abdominal cramps or fullness, usually within 30 minutes after eating, and lasting 1 to 3 hours
Abdominal pain that gets gradually worse over weeks or months
Fear of eating because of pain that happens after eating
causes: Blockage in an artery caused by a blood clot
Narrowing of an artery due to buildup of fatty deposits, such as cholesterol (atherosclerosis)
Low blood pressure leading to an overall reduced blood flow
Blockage in a vein, less commonly
risks: Buildup of fatty deposits in your arteries atherosclerosis
complications: A hole through the wall of the intestines
Scarring or narrowing of your intestine
diagnosis: A scope to see inside your digestive tract
Dye that tracks blood flow through the arteries

name: Presbyopia
description: Have you noticed — yet — having to hold books at arm's length to read them? Find out what options are available when it happens.
symptoms: A tendency to hold reading material farther away to make the letters clearer
Blurred vision at normal reading distance
Eyestrain or headaches after reading or doing close-up work
diagnosis: Two to four years between ages 40 and 54
One to three years between ages 55 and 64
One to two years beginning at age 65

name: Anorexia nervosa
description: Anorexia is an eating disorder characterized by an abnormally low body weight, intense fear of gaining weight and a distorted perception of body weight.
complications: Heart problems, such as mitral valve prolapse, abnormal heart rhythms or heart failure
Bone loss (osteoporosis), increasing the risk of fractures
In females, absence of a period
Gastrointestinal problems, such as constipation, bloating or nausea
Electrolyte abnormalities, such as low blood potassium, sodium and chloride
treatment: Not seeing anorexia as an illness but rather a lifestyle choice

name: Voice disorder
description: Learn more about the causes of common voice disorders, such as laryngitis and granuloma, and how Mayo Clinic diagnoses and treats them.
causes: Voice changes related to the brain and nervous system, known as spasmodic dysphonia (spaz-MOD-ki dis-FOE-nee-uh)
Polyps, nodules or cysts on the vocal cords — growths that aren't cancer
White patches, also known as leukoplakia (loo-koh-PLAY-key-uh)
risks: Conditions related to the brain and nervous system, such as Parkinson's disease or a stroke
Illnesses, such as colds or upper respiratory infections
Scarring from neck surgery or from trauma to the front of the neck

name: Hip dysplasia
description: In infancy, this condition often can be corrected with a soft brace. Older children and young adults might require surgery to correct the misalignment.

name: Avascular necrosis
description: A broken bone or dislocated joint can block blood flow to the bone, causing bone tissue to die.

name: Prescription drug abuse
description: Using a prescription medicine in a way not intended by the prescriber can lead to drug abuse. Learn about risk factors and treatment for drug misuse.
causes: To feel good or get high
To experiment with mental effects of the substance
To maintain an addiction and prevent withdrawal
To be accepted by peers or to be social
To try to improve concentration and school or work performance
risks: Past or present addictions to other substances, including alcohol and tobacco
Family history of substance abuse problems
Peer pressure or a social environment where there's drug use
Easier access to prescription drugs, such as having prescription medicines in the home medicine cabinet
Lack of knowledge about prescription drugs and their potential harm
preventions: Make sure youre getting the right medicine
Check in with your health care provider
Dont order prescriptions online unless theyre from a trustworthy pharmacy

name: Deviated septum
description: Learn how uneven nostrils can cause congestion, nosebleeds or other symptoms in severe cases.
symptoms: Obstruction of one or both nostrils
Preference for sleeping on a particular side
risks: Not wearing your seat belt while riding in a motorized vehicle

name: Anorgasmia
description: Anorgasmia is regular difficulty having an orgasm after plenty of sexual stimulation. It affects many women, causing distress.
diagnosis: Your recent and past sexual experiences
How you feel about your sexual experiences
The types of stimulation or sexual activity you engage in

name: von Willebrand disease
description: Learn more about the symptoms, causes, diagnosis, treatment of this inherited bleeding disorder in which blood doesn't clot well.
symptoms: Excessive bleeding from an injury or after surgery or dental work
Frequent nosebleeds that don't stop within 10 minutes
Heavy bleeding during labor and delivery
Blood in your urine or stool
treatment: The type and severity of your condition
How you've responded to previous therapy

name: Ischemic colitis
description: Ischemic colitis occurs when a part of the colon experiences a decrease in blood flow. It can cause serious complications but usually resolves on its own.
symptoms: Pain, tenderness or cramping in your belly, which can occur suddenly or happen over time
Bright red or maroon blood in your stool or, at times, passage of blood alone without stool
A feeling of urgency to move your bowels
causes: Buildup of fatty deposits on the walls of an artery, also called atherosclerosis
Low blood pressure, also called hypotension, associated with dehydration, heart failure, surgery, trauma or shock
Bowel obstruction caused by a hernia, scar tissue or a tumor
Surgery involving the heart or blood vessels, or the digestive or gynecological systems
Other medical disorders that affect your blood, such as inflammation of the blood vessels, called vasculitis, lupus or sickle cell anemia
treatment: Intravenous fluids, if you are dehydrated
Treatment for any underlying medical condition, such as congestive heart failure or an irregular heartbeat
Avoiding medications that constrict your blood vessels, such as migraine drugs, hormone medications and some heart drugs

name: Bedsore
description: Learn about the symptoms, treatment and prevention of this common skin condition that often affects older adults with limited mobility.
symptoms: Unusual changes in skin color or texture
An area of skin that feels cooler or warmer to the touch than other areas
treatment: A primary care physician who oversees the treatment plan
A physician or nurse specializing in wound care
Nurses or medical assistants who provide both care and education for managing wounds
A social worker who helps you or your family access resources and who addresses emotional concerns related to long-term recovery
A physical therapist who helps with improving mobility
An occupational therapist who helps to ensure appropriate seating surfaces
A dietitian who monitors your nutritional needs and recommends a good diet
A doctor who specializes in conditions of the skin (dermatologist)
A neurosurgeon, vascular surgeon, orthopedic surgeon or plastic surgeon

name: Neuromyelitis optica
description: Understand more about this condition that affects the spinal cord and eye nerves and is sometimes mistaken for multiple sclerosis.

name: ACL injury
description: Learn about this injury that affects one of the main ligaments in your knee and most commonly occurs during sports such as soccer and football.
symptoms: A loud pop or a "popping" sensation in the knee
Severe pain and inability to continue activity
A feeling of instability or "giving way" with weight bearing
causes: Suddenly slowing down and changing direction (cutting)
Pivoting with your foot firmly planted
Receiving a direct blow to the knee or having a collision, such as a football tackle
risks: Being female — possibly due to differences in anatomy, muscle strength and hormonal influences
Participating in certain sports, such as soccer, football, basketball, gymnastics and downhill skiing
Using faulty movement patterns, such as moving the knees inward during a squat
Wearing footwear that doesn't fit properly
Using poorly maintained sports equipment, such as ski bindings that aren't adjusted properly
preventions: Exercises to strengthen the core — including the hips, pelvis and lower abdomen — with a goal of training athletes to avoid moving the knee inward during a squat
Exercises that strengthen leg muscles, particularly hamstring exercises, to ensure an overall balance in leg muscle strength
Training and exercise emphasizing proper technique and knee position when jumping and landing from jumps
Training to improve technique when performing pivoting and cutting movements

name: Premature ventricular contractions
description: Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) are extra heartbeats that disrupt the heart rhythm. PVCs are common.
risks: Stimulants such as cocaine or methamphetamines
Exercise — if you have certain types of PVCs
Heart disease, including congenital heart disease, coronary artery disease, heart failure and a weakened heart muscle (cardiomyopathy)

name: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans
description: Learn about symptoms and diagnosis for this rare type of skin cancer. DFSP treatments include Mohs surgery, radiation and targeted therapy.

name: Priapism
description: Understand the symptoms, possible causes and treatment of prolonged erection of the penis, including when to seek emergency care.
preventions: Treatment for an underlying condition, such as sickle cell disease, that might have caused priapism
Use of oral or injectable phenylephrine
Hormone-blocking medications — only for adult men
Use of oral medications used to manage erectile dysfunction

name: Bedsore
description: Learn about the symptoms, treatment and prevention of this common skin condition that often affects older adults with limited mobility.
symptoms: Unusual changes in skin color or texture
An area of skin that feels cooler or warmer to the touch than other areas
treatment: A primary care physician who oversees the treatment plan
A physician or nurse specializing in wound care
Nurses or medical assistants who provide both care and education for managing wounds
A social worker who helps you or your family access resources and who addresses emotional concerns related to long-term recovery
A physical therapist who helps with improving mobility
An occupational therapist who helps to ensure appropriate seating surfaces
A dietitian who monitors your nutritional needs and recommends a good diet
A doctor who specializes in conditions of the skin (dermatologist)
A neurosurgeon, vascular surgeon, orthopedic surgeon or plastic surgeon

name: Anterior prolapse
description: Anterior prolapse happens when the pelvic floor muscles weaken and the bladder pushes into the top front part of your vagina. Learn how it's treated.
symptoms: A feeling of fullness or pressure in your pelvis and vagina
In some cases, a bulge of tissue in your vagina that you can see or feel
Increased pelvic pressure when you strain, cough, bear down or lift

Problems urinating, including difficulty starting a urine stream, the feeling that you haven't completely emptied your bladder after urinating, feeling a frequent need to urinate or leaking urine (urinary incontinence)

name: Vulvar cancer
description: Learn about this rare cancer that forms on the skin that surrounds the urethra and vagina. Treatments include surgery, radiation and chemotherapy.
symptoms: Skin changes, such as color changes or thickening
A lump, wartlike bumps or an open sore (ulcer)
risks: Being exposed to human papillomavirus HPV
Having a history of precancerous conditions of the vulva
Having a skin condition involving the vulva

name: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor
description: Learn about these cancers that start in the hormone-producing cells of the pancreas. Explore innovative treatments, including the Whipple procedure and PRRT.
symptoms: Pain in your abdomen or back
Yellowing of your skin or eyes
risks: A family history of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors

name: Diabetes
description: Learn more about the different types of this blood sugar disorder, who's at risk and how each type can be treated.
symptoms: Presence of ketones in the urine. Ketones are a byproduct of the breakdown of muscle and fat that happens when there's not enough available insulin.
Feeling irritable or having other mood changes.
Getting a lot of infections, such as gum, skin and vaginal infections.

name: Preterm labor
description: Going into labor before your due date is serious, but knowing the risk factors and how to manage them can help.
symptoms: Regular or frequent sensations of abdominal tightening (contractions)
A sensation of pelvic or lower abdominal pressure
Preterm rupture of membranes — in a gush or a continuous trickle of fluid after the membrane around the baby breaks or tears
A change in type of vaginal discharge — watery, mucus-like or bloody
risks: Previous preterm labor or premature birth, particularly in the most recent pregnancy or in more than one previous pregnancy
Pregnancy with twins, triplets or other multiples
Problems with the uterus or placenta
Smoking cigarettes or using illicit drugs
Certain infections, particularly of the amniotic fluid and lower genital tract
Some chronic conditions, such as high blood pressure, diabetes, autoimmune disease and depression
Stressful life events, such as the death of a loved one
Presence of a fetal birth defect
An interval of less than 12 months — or of more than 59 months — between pregnancies
Age of mother, both young and older
preventions: Be cautious when using assisted reproductive technology ART

name: Anterior prolapse
description: Anterior prolapse happens when the pelvic floor muscles weaken and the bladder pushes into the top front part of your vagina. Learn how it's treated.
symptoms: A feeling of fullness or pressure in your pelvis and vagina
In some cases, a bulge of tissue in your vagina that you can see or feel
Increased pelvic pressure when you strain, cough, bear down or lift

Problems urinating, including difficulty starting a urine stream, the feeling that you haven't completely emptied your bladder after urinating, feeling a frequent need to urinate or leaking urine (urinary incontinence)

name: Vulvodynia
description: If you have pain, burning or irritation in your vaginal area, talk to your doctor. You could have vulvodynia.
causes: Injury to or irritation of the nerves surrounding your vulvar region
Muscle spasm or weakness in the pelvic floor, which supports the uterus, bladder and bowel

name: Itchy skin
description: Learn about causes of this common irritating skin condition and which treatments and self-care measures may provide relief.
diagnosis: Tests of liver and kidney function

name: Diabetes insipidus
description: Learn more about this unusual disorder that disrupts the body's fluid balance, causing excessive urination and possibly leading to dehydration.
symptoms: Producing large amounts of pale urine
Frequently needing to get up to urinate during the night

name: Priapism
description: Understand the symptoms, possible causes and treatment of prolonged erection of the penis, including when to seek emergency care.
preventions: Treatment for an underlying condition, such as sickle cell disease, that might have caused priapism
Use of oral or injectable phenylephrine
Hormone-blocking medications — only for adult men
Use of oral medications used to manage erectile dysfunction

name: Anthrax
description: Learn about the symptoms and risks of anthrax, a rare but deadly bacterial disease that's been used in bioterrorism.
risks: Are in the military and deployed to an area with a high risk of exposure to anthrax
Work with anthrax in a laboratory setting
Handle animal skins, furs or wool from areas with a high incidence of anthrax
Work in veterinary medicine, especially if you deal with livestock
Handle or dress game animals — while anthrax is rare in the United States, there are occasional outbreaks in domestic cattle and wild animals such as deer
Inject illegal drugs, such as heroin
complications: Your body being unable to respond to infection normally, leading to damage of multiple organ systems (sepsis)
Inflammation of the membranes and fluid covering the brain and spinal cord, leading to massive bleeding (hemorrhagic meningitis) and death
preventions: A 60-day treatment with antibiotics — ciprofloxacin, doxycycline and levofloxacin are approved for adults and children
A three-dose series of anthrax vaccine
In some cases, treatment with monoclonal antibodies — raxibacumab and obiltoxaximab

name: Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia
description: Learn about this rare type of white blood cell cancer. Treatments include chemotherapy, targeted therapy, immunotherapy and bone marrow transplant.
symptoms: Bleeding from the nose or the gums
Numbness in your hands or feet
risks: Having a family history of lymphoma
diagnosis: Collecting a sample of bone marrow for testing

name: Immune thrombocytopenia
description: Caused by low levels of platelets, symptoms may include purple bruises called purpura, as well as tiny reddish-purple dots that look like a rash.

name: Heat rash
description: Learn more about the symptoms, causes and treatment of this heat-related problem of the skin that affects people of all ages.
risks: Being a newborn, as newborns have immature sweat ducts
Living in a hot, humid climate
Being on bedrest for a long time and having a fever
preventions: In hot weather, dress in loose, lightweight clothing that wicks moisture away from the skin. Don't wrap newborns in too many layers.
In hot weather, limit physical activity. Stay in the shade or in an air-conditioned building. Or use a fan to circulate the air.
Keep your sleeping area cool and well ventilated.
Avoid creams and ointments that can block pores.
Avoid drugs that cause sweating, such as clonidine, beta blockers and opioids.

name: Diabetes
description: Learn more about the different types of this blood sugar disorder, who's at risk and how each type can be treated.
symptoms: Presence of ketones in the urine. Ketones are a byproduct of the breakdown of muscle and fat that happens when there's not enough available insulin.
Feeling irritable or having other mood changes.
Getting a lot of infections, such as gum, skin and vaginal infections.

name: Pseudomembranous colitis
description: This inflammatory colon condition is usually caused by the bacterium Clostridioides difficile. The use of high-dose antibiotics may let these germs grow unchecked.
symptoms: Pus or mucus in the stool.
causes: Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin (Cipro) and levofloxacin.
Penicillins, such as amoxicillin and ampicillin.
risks: Staying in the hospital or a nursing home.
Having a colon disease, such as inflammatory bowel disease or colorectal cancer.
complications: A hole in your large intestine called bowel perforation
treatment: Stopping the antibiotic or other medication thats thought to be causing your symptoms if possible
Starting an antibiotic likely to be effective against C difficile

name: Common warts
description: Find out tips for preventing and dealing with this common skin condition that causes small, rough growths on your fingers and hands.
symptoms: Sprinkled with black pinpoints, which are small, clotted blood vessels
risks: Children and young adults, because their bodies may not have built up immunity to the virus
People with weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS or people who've had organ transplants
preventions: Avoid direct contact with warts. This includes your own warts.
Don't pick at warts. Picking may spread the virus.
Don't use the same emery board, pumice stone or nail clipper on your warts as you use on your healthy skin and nails. Use a disposable emery board.
Don't bite your fingernails. Warts occur more often in skin that has been broken. Nibbling the skin around your fingernails opens the door for the virus.
Groom with care. And avoid brushing, clipping or shaving areas that have warts. If you must shave, use an electric razor.
diagnosis: Scraping off the top layer of the wart to check for signs of dark, pinpoint dots — clotted blood vessels — which are common with warts
Removing a small section of the wart (shave biopsy) and sending it to a laboratory for analysis to rule out other types of skin growths

name: Jaw tumors and cysts
description: Also called odontogenic tumors and cysts, these typically benign lesions develop in the jawbone or the soft tissues in the mouth. They vary in severity.
symptoms: Other types of cysts and tumors
diagnosis: Imaging studies, such as X-ray, CT or MRI
A biopsy to remove a sample of tumor or cyst cells for laboratory analysis
treatment: Reconstruction of the jawbone or other structures
Medical therapy for certain types of jaw tumors and cysts
Supportive care to help maintain your quality of life, including assisting with nutrition, speech and swallowing, and replacements for missing teeth

name: Addison's disease
description: Learn about this rare but serious disorder of the adrenal glands that's treated by replacing needed hormones.
symptoms: Weight loss and loss of appetite
Low blood sugar, also called hypoglycemia
Body hair loss or sexual issues in some people
preventions: Talk to your health care provider if you always feel tired or weak or are losing weight without trying. Ask about an adrenal shortage.
If you have been diagnosed with Addison's disease, ask your provider what to do when you're sick. You may need to learn how to increase your dose of corticosteroids.
If you become very sick, especially if you are vomiting and you can't take your medicine, go to an emergency room.
treatment: Hydrocortisone Cortef prednisone Rayos or methylprednisolone Medrol

name: Antibiotic associated diarrhea
description: Learn more about why you might get diarrhea while taking antibiotics, as well as how to treat or prevent this uncomfortable and sometimes serious problem.
risks: Have had antibiotic-associated diarrhea in the past
Have taken antibiotic medications for an extended time
Are taking more than one antibiotic medication
preventions: Ask caregivers to wash their hands
Tell your doctor if youve had antibioticassociated diarrhea or C difficile before

name: Gestational diabetes
description: This high blood sugar disorder develops during pregnancy and can affect your pregnancy and your baby's health. Read about risks, prevention and treatment.
risks: Having had gestational diabetes during a previous pregnancy
Having an immediate family member with diabetes
Having previously delivered a baby weighing more than 9 pounds (4.1 kilograms)
Being of a certain race or ethnicity, such as Black, Hispanic, American Indian and Asian American
preventions: Start pregnancy at a healthy weight
Dont gain more weight than recommended

name: Genital warts
description: The human papillomavirus (HPV) causes the most common of sexually transmitted infections. Vaccines can help protect against the HPV strains that cause genital warts.
risks: Having unprotected sex with multiple partners
Having had another sexually transmitted infection
Having sex with a partner whose sexual history you don't know
Becoming sexually active at a young age
Having a compromised immune system, such as from HIV or drugs from an organ transplant

name: Jellyfish stings
description: Learn more about prevention and first aid for these painful injuries that are common among people swimming in seawater but are rarely life-threatening.
symptoms: Welts or tracks on the skin — a "print" of the tentacles' contact with the skin
Throbbing pain that radiates up a leg or an arm
risks: Swimming when jellyfish appear in large numbers (a jellyfish bloom)
Swimming or diving in jellyfish areas without protective clothing
Playing or sunbathing where jellyfish are washed up on the beach
Swimming in a place known to have many jellyfish
complications: Delayed skin reaction, causing blisters, rash or other irritation
Irukandji syndrome, which causes chest and stomach pain, high blood pressure, and heart problems

name: Antiphospholipid syndrome
description: Learn about causes and treatment of this blood disorder that mainly affects women and may cause blood clots and miscarriages.
risks: Are immobile for a time, such as being on bed rest or sitting during a long flight
Take oral contraceptives or estrogen therapy for menopause
Have high cholesterol and triglycerides levels

name: Primary biliary cholangitis
description: Primary biliary cholangitis is a type of liver disease that damages the bile ducts. Early treatment may help prevent liver failure.
complications: Increased pressure in the portal vein portal hypertension
diagnosis: Antibody tests for signs of autoimmune disease

name: Type 1 diabetes
description: Learn about the symptoms, causes, treatment of this chronic condition in which the pancreas produces little or no insulin.
symptoms: Bed-wetting in children who have never wet the bed during the night
Feeling irritable or having other mood changes
causes: Exposure to viruses and other environmental factors
treatment: Exercising regularly and keeping a healthy weight

name: Plantar warts
description: Learn about the causes, treatment and prevention of these hard, sometimes painful growths that appear on the heel or ball of the foot.
symptoms: A small, rough growth on the bottom of your foot, usually at the base of the toes or on the ball or heel
On brown and Black skin, the growth may be lighter than unaffected skin
Hard, thickened skin (callus) over a spot on the skin, where a wart has grown inward
Black pinpoints, which are small clotted blood vessels commonly called wart seeds
A cluster of growths on the sole of the foot (mosaic warts)
A growth that interrupts the normal lines and ridges in the skin of your foot
Pain or tenderness when walking or standing
risks: People who have had plantar warts before
People who walk barefoot in areas where a wart-causing virus is common, such as locker rooms and swimming pools
preventions: Avoid direct contact with warts. This includes your own warts. Wash your hands carefully after touching a wart.
Keep your feet clean and dry.
Wear sandals or other foot protection when walking around swimming pools, in locker rooms or in gym showers.
Don't pick at or scratch warts.
When using an emery board, pumice stone or nail clipper on your warts, choose one that you don't use on your healthy skin and nails.

name: Jet lag
description: Jetting across time zones can take a toll on your body's internal clock. Find out how to cope with fatigue and other symptoms while traveling.
preventions: Get plenty of rest before your trip
Gradually adjust your schedule before you leave
Try to sleep on the plane if its nighttime at your destination

name: Antisocial personality disorder
description: People with this mental condition consistently disregard right and wrong, antagonize and manipulate others, and ignore other's rights and feelings.
symptoms: Persistent lying or deceit to exploit others
Being callous, cynical and disrespectful of others
Using charm or wit to manipulate others for personal gain or personal pleasure
Arrogance, a sense of superiority and being extremely opinionated
Recurring problems with the law, including criminal behavior
Repeatedly violating the rights of others through intimidation and dishonesty
Impulsiveness or failure to plan ahead
Hostility, significant irritability, agitation, aggression or violence
Lack of empathy for others and lack of remorse about harming others
Unnecessary risk-taking or dangerous behavior with no regard for the safety of self or others
Failure to consider the negative consequences of behavior or learn from them
Being consistently irresponsible and repeatedly failing to fulfill work or financial obligations
causes: Genes may make you vulnerable to developing antisocial personality disorder — and life situations may trigger its development
Changes in the way the brain functions may have resulted during brain development
risks: Family history of antisocial personality disorder or other personality disorders or mental health disorders
Being subjected to abuse or neglect during childhood
Unstable, violent or chaotic family life during childhood
complications: Spouse abuse or child abuse or neglect
Problems with alcohol or substance use
Having other mental health disorders such as depression or anxiety
Low social and economic status and homelessness
Premature death, usually as a result of violence
diagnosis: A psychological evaluation that explores thoughts, feelings, relationships, behavior patterns and family history
Symptoms listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association

name: Primary biliary cholangitis
description: Primary biliary cholangitis is a type of liver disease that damages the bile ducts. Early treatment may help prevent liver failure.
complications: Increased pressure in the portal vein portal hypertension
diagnosis: Antibody tests for signs of autoimmune disease

name: Type 1 diabetes in children
description: Know what symptoms to look for, as well as more about diagnosis, treatment and daily living with this lifelong insulin-dependent condition.
symptoms: Frequent urination, possibly bed-wetting in a toilet-trained child
preventions: Preventing or delaying the start of type 1 diabetes in people who have a high risk of the disease.
Preventing further destruction of the islet cells in people who are newly diagnosed.

name: Genital warts
description: The human papillomavirus (HPV) causes the most common of sexually transmitted infections. Vaccines can help protect against the HPV strains that cause genital warts.
risks: Having unprotected sex with multiple partners
Having had another sexually transmitted infection
Having sex with a partner whose sexual history you don't know
Becoming sexually active at a young age
Having a compromised immune system, such as from HIV or drugs from an organ transplant

name: Jock itch
description: Learn more about this common treatable fungal infection that causes a red itchy rash in the groin and inner thighs.
risks: Are a teen or young adult

name: Generalized anxiety disorder
description: Excessive, ongoing anxiety and worry can interfere with your daily activities and may be a sign of generalized anxiety disorder, but treatment can help.
symptoms: Persistent worrying or anxiety about a number of areas that are out of proportion to the impact of the events
Overthinking plans and solutions to all possible worst-case outcomes
Perceiving situations and events as threatening, even when they aren't
Indecisiveness and fear of making the wrong decision
Inability to set aside or let go of a worry
Inability to relax, feeling restless, and feeling keyed up or on edge
Difficulty concentrating, or the feeling that your mind "goes blank"
causes: Differences in brain chemistry and function
Differences in the way threats are perceived
complications: Impair your ability to perform tasks quickly and efficiently because you have trouble concentrating
Take your time and focus from other activities
diagnosis: Do a physical exam to look for signs that your anxiety might be linked to medications or an underlying medical condition
Order blood or urine tests or other tests, if a medical condition is suspected
Ask detailed questions about your symptoms and medical history
Use psychological questionnaires to help determine a diagnosis
Use the criteria listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association

name: Primary immunodeficiency
description: Frequent infections could mean you have an immune system disorder. The conditions in this category are usually caused by genetic changes.
symptoms: Frequent and recurrent pneumonia, bronchitis, sinus infections, ear infections, meningitis or skin infections
Inflammation and infection of internal organs
Blood disorders, such as low platelet count or anemia
Digestive problems, such as cramping, loss of appetite, nausea and diarrhea
Autoimmune disorders, such as lupus, rheumatoid arthritis or type 1 diabetes
causes: Combination B and T cell deficiencies
complications: Damage to the heart, lungs, nervous system or digestive tract

name: Type 2 diabetes
description: High blood sugar levels are the key problem in diabetes. Learn about lifestyle changes to lower your risk and treatments to manage diabetes.
symptoms: Numbness or tingling in the hands or feet
Areas of darkened skin, usually in the armpits and neck
causes: Cells in muscle, fat and the liver become resistant to insulin. Because these cells don't interact in a normal way with insulin, they don't take in enough sugar.
The pancreas is unable to produce enough insulin to manage blood sugar levels.
risks: Areas of darkened skin usually in the armpits and neck
diagnosis: 6.5% or higher on two separate tests indicates diabetes.
treatment: Possibly, diabetes medication or insulin therapy

name: Swollen knee
description: This condition can be caused by trauma, overuse injuries, or an underlying disease or condition. A fluid sample from the knee may be needed for diagnosis.
preventions: Strengthen the muscles around your knee

name: Patellar tendinitis
description: Jumper's knee — a common knee injury — affects the tendon that stretches from the kneecap (patella) to the shinbone.

name: Social anxiety disorder
description: Learn more on this disorder where everyday interactions cause significant worry and self-consciousness because you fear being judged negatively by others.
risks: Having an appearance or condition that draws attention
complications: Substance abuse, such as drinking too much alcohol
diagnosis: Physical exam to help assess whether any medical condition or medication may trigger symptoms of anxiety
Discussion of your symptoms, how often they occur and in what situations
Review of a list of situations to see if they make you anxious
Self-report questionnaires about symptoms of social anxiety
Criteria listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association

name: Primary lateral sclerosis
description: This motor neuron disease causes nerves within the brain to slowly break down, resulting in muscle weakness primarily in the legs, arms and tongue.
symptoms: Stiffness, weakness and muscle spasms (spasticity) in your legs, rarely starting in one leg, and eventually progressing to your arms, hands, tongue and jaw
Tripping, clumsiness and difficulty with balance
Hoarseness, as well as slowed, slurred speech and drooling
Sometimes, frequent, rapid and intense shifts in emotions (mood lability)
Rarely, breathing problems and bladder problems late in the disease

name: Type 2 diabetes in children
description: More children are being diagnosed with this blood sugar condition. Learn how to help manage or prevent this chronic disease in your child.
symptoms: Darkened areas of skin, most often around the neck or in the armpits and groin
Unintended weight loss, although this is less common in children with type 2 diabetes than in children with type 1 diabetes
causes: The pancreas may not make enough insulin
The cells become resistant to insulin and don't allow as much sugar in
risks: Low birth weight or preterm birth

name: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
description: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis causes inflammation in the blood vessels in your nose, sinuses, throat, lungs and kidneys. Prompt treatment is vital.
symptoms: Pus-like drainage with crusts from your nose, stuffiness, sinus infections and nosebleeds
Numbness in your limbs, fingers or toes
Eye redness, burning or pain, and vision problems
complications: A loss of height in the bridge of the nose (saddling) caused by weakened cartilage
A blood clot forming in one or more deep veins, usually in your leg

name: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis
description: Learn about this type of arthritis that affects children and can cause growth problems, joint damage and eye inflammation.
symptoms: Fever swollen lymph nodes and rash

name: Primary ovarian insufficiency
description: Primary ovarian insufficiency, also called premature ovarian failure, occurs in women under age 40. Hormone therapy can lessen uncomfortable symptoms.
symptoms: Irregular or skipped periods, which might be present for years or develop after a pregnancy or after stopping birth control pills
causes: An immune system response to ovarian tissue autoimmune disease

name: Anxiety disorder
description: Learn the symptoms of this mental health condition, and ways to manage worry and fear that interfere with your daily activities.
symptoms: Having a sense of impending danger, panic or doom
Trouble concentrating or thinking about anything other than the present worry
Having the urge to avoid things that trigger anxiety
risks: Having blood relatives with an anxiety disorder
complications: Depression (which often occurs with an anxiety disorder) or other mental health disorders
Problems functioning at school or work
diagnosis: Compare your symptoms to the criteria in the DSM5
treatment: Certain antidepressants are also used to treat anxiety disorders.
An anti-anxiety medication called buspirone may be prescribed.

In limited circumstances, your doctor may prescribe other types of medications, such as sedatives, also called benzodiazepines, or beta blockers. These medications are for short-term relief of anxiety symptoms and are not intended to be used long term.

name: Diabetic coma
description: iabetic coma is a life-threatening disorder that can happen when blood sugar is very high or very low. Learn about its causes, treatment and prevention.

name: MEN 1
description: Learn about diagnosis and treatment for multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 1 (MEN 1) — a rare disorder that causes tumors and overproduction of hormones.
symptoms: Ulcers in the stomach or intestines
diagnosis: Endoscopic ultrasound of the pancreas and other scans

name: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis
description: Learn about this type of arthritis that affects children and can cause growth problems, joint damage and eye inflammation.
symptoms: Fever swollen lymph nodes and rash

name: Aortic aneurysm
description: Learn more about this condition that affects the body's main artery and can cause life-threatening bleeding.

name: Polycythemia vera
description: This slow-growing blood cancer mainly affects people over 60. Treatments and lifestyle changes may reduce complications and ease symptoms.
symptoms: Itchiness, especially after a warm bath or shower
Numbness, tingling, burning, or weakness in your hands, feet, arms or legs
A feeling of fullness soon after eating and bloating or pain in your left upper abdomen due to an enlarged spleen
Unusual bleeding, such as a nosebleed or bleeding gums
Painful swelling of one joint, often the big toe
Shortness of breath and difficulty breathing when lying down
complications: Problems due to high levels of red blood cells

name: Diabetic hypoglycemia
description: Low blood sugar can make you feel awful and is potentially dangerous. Learn about low blood sugar symptoms and treatments for someone with diabetes.
causes: Taking too much insulin or diabetes medication
Postponing or skipping a meal or snack
Increasing exercise or physical activity without eating more or adjusting your medications
risks: People taking diabetes drugs called sulfonylureas, such as glipizide (Glucotrol), glimepiride (Amaryl) or glyburide (Diabeta, Glynase)
Those with impaired liver or kidney function
People who've had diabetes for a long time
People who don't feel low blood sugar symptoms (hypoglycemia unawareness)
Anyone with a disability that prevents a quick response to falling blood sugar levels
preventions: Dont skip or delay meals or snacks
