description: Learn about this painful infection in a joint and why prompt treatment can help minimize joint damage.

name: DiGeorge syndrome
description: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) is a disorder caused by a defect in chromosome 22, resulting in poor development of several body systems.
symptoms: Heart murmur and bluish skin due to poor circulation of oxygen-rich blood (cyanosis) as a result of a heart defect
Certain facial features, such as an underdeveloped chin, low-set ears, wide-set eyes or a narrow groove in the upper lip
A gap in the roof of the mouth (cleft palate) or other problems with the palate
Difficulty feeding, failure to gain weight or gastrointestinal problems
Delayed development, such as delays in rolling over, sitting up or other infant milestones
Delayed speech development or nasal-sounding speech
diagnosis: A combination of medical problems or conditions suggesting 22q11.2 deletion syndrome
A heart defect, because certain heart defects are commonly associated with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome

name: Pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum
description: Also called PA/IVS, this rare congenital heart defect is diagnosed at or shortly after birth. Learn how it may be treated with one or more procedures.

name: Desmoplastic small round cell tumor
description: These rare, aggressive cancers most often form in the abdomen. Learn about DSRCT treatments, including surgery, chemotherapy and radiation therapy.
diagnosis: Removing a sample of tissue for testing

name: Tennis elbow
description: Tennis elbow — Painful condition is caused by repetitive motions of the wrist and arm. Non-athletes are also affected. Learn how to prevent and treat it.
symptoms: Shake hands or grip an object
causes: Cutting up cooking ingredients, particularly meat

name: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis
description: Learn about this type of arthritis that affects children and can cause growth problems, joint damage and eye inflammation.
symptoms: Fever swollen lymph nodes and rash

name: Ductal carcinoma in situ
description: Noninvasive breast cancer often has no signs or symptoms. Find out how doctors diagnose DCIS and learn about treatment, including mastectomy and lumpectomy.
risks: Personal history of benign breast disease, such as atypical hyperplasia
Having your first baby after age 30
Having your first period before age 12
Genetic mutations that increase the risk of breast cancer, such as those in the breast cancer genes BRCA1 and BRCA2

name: Pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum
description: This congenital heart defect affects the valve between the heart and lungs and includes a hole in the heart. Learn more about the surgeries and procedures needed to treat it.

name: Tennis elbow
description: Tennis elbow — Painful condition is caused by repetitive motions of the wrist and arm. Non-athletes are also affected. Learn how to prevent and treat it.
symptoms: Shake hands or grip an object
causes: Cutting up cooking ingredients, particularly meat

name: Osteoarthritis
description: This most common form of arthritis mainly affects joints in your hands, knees, hips and spine. There's no cure, but symptoms can be managed.

name: Dumping syndrome
description: People who have had stomach or weight-loss surgery can develop dumping syndrome, which causes cramping, diarrhea and, sometimes, low blood sugar.
symptoms: Feeling bloated or too full after eating

name: Pulmonary edema
description: Get more information about the causes of this potentially life-threatening lung condition and learn how to treat and prevent it.
causes: If a heart problem causes the pulmonary edema, it's called cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Most often, the fluid buildup in the lungs is due to a heart condition.
If pulmonary edema is not heart related, it's called noncardiogenic pulmonary edema.
Sometimes, pulmonary edema can be caused by both a heart problem and a nonheart problem.
complications: Swelling of the legs, feet and belly area
Buildup of fluid in the membranes that surround the lungs (pleural effusion)
Congestion and swelling of the liver
preventions: Eat a healthy diet rich in fresh fruits, vegetables, whole grains, fat-free or low-fat dairy, and a variety of proteins.
diagnosis: Btype natriuretic peptide BNP blood test

name: Tennis elbow
description: Tennis elbow — Painful condition is caused by repetitive motions of the wrist and arm. Non-athletes are also affected. Learn how to prevent and treat it.
symptoms: Shake hands or grip an object
causes: Cutting up cooking ingredients, particularly meat

name: Psoriatic arthritis
description: This form of arthritis affects some people who have psoriasis — a disease that features red patches of skin topped with silvery scales.
diagnosis: Examine your joints for signs of swelling or tenderness
Check your fingernails for pitting, flaking and other abnormalities
Press on the soles of your feet and around your heels for to check for tender areas

name: Median arcuate ligament syndrome
description: Stomach pain after eating isn't always due to indigestion. It could be MALS, also called celiac artery compression.
symptoms: Pain in the upper middle stomach area, which may go away when leaning forward
Stomach pain after eating, exercising or changing body position
Fear of eating food due to pain, leading to significant weight loss — usually greater than 20 pounds (9.1 kilograms)
diagnosis: Computerized tomography CT of the abdomen

name: Latex allergy
description: If rubber gloves, balloons or similar products make you itchy, you could have latex allergy. Know how to spot the symptoms.
risks: People who undergo multiple surgeries or medical procedures
People with a personal or family history of allergies

name: Pulmonary embolism
description: A blood clot blocks and stops blood flow to an artery in the lung. Often the clot starts in a leg and travels to the lung.
causes: Fat from the inside of a broken long bone

name: Reactive arthritis
description: This joint pain is triggered by an infection in another part of the body — often the intestines, genitals or urinary tract.

name: Dupuytren's contracture
description: This painless condition causes one or more fingers to bend toward the palm of the hand. The affected fingers can't straighten completely.

name: Lazy eye
description: Abnormal visual development early in life can cause reduced vision in one eye, which often wanders inward or outward.
symptoms: An eye that wanders inward or outward
Eyes that appear to not work together
Abnormal results of vision screening tests
causes: Difference in sharpness of vision between the eyes refractive amblyopia

name: Rheumatoid arthritis
description: This chronic inflammatory disorder can affect more than just your joints. It can also damage your skin, eyes, lungs, heart and blood vessels.
symptoms: Joint stiffness that is usually worse in the mornings and after inactivity
Fatigue, fever and loss of appetite

name: Pulmonary fibrosis
description: Pulmonary fibrosis — Learn about the symptoms, causes and treatment of this serious lung disease that occurs when lung tissue becomes damaged and scarred.
symptoms: Widening and rounding of the tips of the fingers or toes (clubbing)
complications: High blood pressure in your lungs pulmonary hypertension

name: Lobular carcinoma in situ
description: If a breast biopsy reveals you have LCIS, your risk of breast cancer is increased. Learn how you can reduce your risk through medications and other strategies.
treatment: Taking a medication to reduce cancer risk (preventive therapy)

name: Dural arteriovenous fistula
description: Treatments for these abnormal connections between an artery and the brain's dura include endovascular embolization and stereotactic radiosurgery.
symptoms: Symptoms related to increased pressure such as headaches, nausea and vomiting.

name: Septic arthritis
description: Learn about this painful infection in a joint and why prompt treatment can help minimize joint damage.

name: Pulmonary hypertension
description: Learn more about the warning signs and symptoms and treatment of high blood pressure in the lungs.
symptoms: Shortness of breath (dyspnea), initially while exercising and eventually while at rest
Swelling (edema) in the ankles, legs and eventually the belly area (abdomen)
risks: A family history of the condition
Blood-clotting disorders or a family history of blood clots in the lungs
Use of certain drugs, including some weight-loss medicines and illegal drugs such as cocaine or methamphetamine
Use of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), used to treat depression and anxiety
complications: Rightsided heart enlargement and heart failure cor pulmonale

name: Pulmonary valve disease
description: Learn about the types of lung valve disease and treatment options at Mayo Clinic.

name: Lead poisoning
description: Learn about lead poisoning symptoms and treatment of lead exposure in children and adults. Explore ways to keep your kids safe from lead exposure.
preventions: Remove shoes before entering the house
Prevent children from playing on soil

name: Dust mite allergy
description: Dust mite allergy can lead to year-round sniffles and sneezes. Here's how to find relief.
symptoms: Itchy nose, roof of mouth or throat
Swollen, blue-colored skin under your eyes
In a child, frequent upward rubbing of the nose
risks: Having a family history of allergies
Being a child or a young adult

name: Thumb arthritis
description: This common condition can cause pain and mobility issues, making simple tasks difficult. Treatment may include medications, splints and sometimes surgery.
symptoms: Swelling, stiffness and tenderness at the base of your thumb
Decreased strength when pinching or grasping objects
Enlarged or bony appearance of the joint at the base of your thumb
risks: Certain hereditary conditions, such as joint ligament laxity and malformed joints.
Injuries to your thumb joint, such as fractures and sprains.

Diseases that change the normal structure and function of cartilage, such as rheumatoid arthritis. Although osteoarthritis is the most common cause of thumb arthritis, rheumatoid arthritis can also affect the CMC joint, usually to a lesser extent than other joints of the hand.
Activities and jobs that put high stress on the thumb joint.

name: Pulmonary valve stenosis
description: When the valve between the heart and lungs is narrowed, blood flow slows. Know the symptoms of this type of valve disease and how it's treated.
symptoms: A whooshing sound called a heart murmur that can be heard with a stethoscope.
Shortness of breath, especially during activity.
complications: Infection of the lining of the heart called infective endocarditis

name: Left ventricular hypertrophy
description: Learn more about this heart condition that causes the walls of the heart's main pumping chamber to become enlarged and thickened.
symptoms: Shortness of breath, especially while lying down
Sensation of rapid, fluttering or pounding heartbeats, called palpitations
Fainting or a feeling of lightheadedness
complications: Too little oxygen to the heart, called ischemic heart disease
Sudden, unexpected loss of heart function, breathing and consciousness, called sudden cardiac arrest
preventions: Get 7 to 9 hours of sleep daily

name: Deep vein thrombosis
description: This potentially serious condition can occur with few or no symptoms. Know the risk factors.
symptoms: Leg pain, cramping or soreness that often starts in the calf
Change in skin color on the leg — such as red or purple, depending on the color of your skin
A feeling of warmth on the affected leg
risks: Birth control pills oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy
A personal or family history of DVT or PE

name: Asbestosis
description: Exposure to asbestos fibers causes this chronic lung disease. It may be decades before signs and symptoms such as shortness of breath and coughing appear.
risks: Workers removing asbestos insulation around steam pipes in older buildings

name: Broken leg
description: Treatment of a broken leg depends on the location and severity of the injury. Surgical repair uses metal pins and plates to hold the fragments together.
symptoms: Severe pain, which may worsen with movement
Obvious deformity or shortening of the affected leg

name: Premature ventricular contractions
description: Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) are extra heartbeats that disrupt the heart rhythm. PVCs are common.
risks: Stimulants such as cocaine or methamphetamines
Exercise — if you have certain types of PVCs
Heart disease, including congenital heart disease, coronary artery disease, heart failure and a weakened heart muscle (cardiomyopathy)

name: Ascariasis
description: Learn more about the causes, treatment and prevention of this roundworm infection.

name: Dwarfism
description: Very short stature of 4 feet 10 inches or less that results from a genetic or medical condition is considered dwarfism. Learn about causes and treatment.

name: Legg Calve Perthes disease
description: This childhood condition occurs when blood supply is temporarily interrupted to the ball part of the hip joint, making it fracture easily and heal poorly.
symptoms: Pain or stiffness in the hip, groin, thigh or knee
Limited range of motion of the hip joint
Pain that worsens with activity and improves with rest

name: Peripheral artery disease
description: Learn more about this common blood flow condition that can cause leg pain when walking. Lifestyle changes and medications can help.
symptoms: Coldness in the lower leg or foot, especially when compared with the other side
No pulse or a weak pulse in the legs or feet
Painful cramping in one or both of the hips, thighs or calf muscles after certain activities, such as walking or climbing stairs
Skin color changes on the legs
Sores on the toes, feet or legs that won't heal
Pain when using the arms, such as aching and cramping when knitting, writing or doing other manual tasks
Hair loss or slower hair growth on the legs
risks: A family history of peripheral artery disease, heart disease or stroke
High levels of an amino acid called homocysteine, which increase the risk for coronary artery disease
Increasing age, especially after 65 (or after 50 if you have risk factors for atherosclerosis)
preventions: Eat foods that are low in saturated fat.
Get regular exercise — but check with your care provider about what type and how much is best for you.

name: Dysarthria
description: This condition affects muscles used for speaking. Speech therapy and treating the underlying cause may improve speech.
symptoms: Inability to speak louder than a whisper or speaking too loudly
Rapid speech that is difficult to understand
Difficulty moving your tongue or facial muscles

name: Atrial septal defect
description: This opening between the heart's upper chambers is this common congenital heart defect, but can be treated.
symptoms: Shortness of breath, especially when exercising
Swelling of legs, feet or belly (abdomen)
Sensation of a rapid, pounding heartbeat (palpitations) or skipped beats
Whooshing sound that can be heard through a stethoscope (heart murmur)
risks: German measles (rubella) infection during the first few months of pregnancy
Illegal drug use, such as cocaine
Use of certain medications, including some anti-seizure medications and drugs to treat mood disorders
complications: High blood pressure in the lung arteries (pulmonary hypertension)
preventions: Discussing current health conditions and medications
Getting tested for immunity to German measles rubella
diagnosis: Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging MRI scan

name: Legionnaires' disease
description: Bacteria that can live in water from air conditioning systems, showers and spas cause this severe form of pneumonia.
symptoms: Fever that may be 104 F (40 C) or higher
risks: Have a chronic lung disease or other serious condition
diagnosis: Chest X-ray, which doesn't confirm Legionnaires' disease but can show the extent of infection in your lungs
Tests on a sample of your sputum or lung tissue

name: Post-vasectomy pain syndrome
description: Learn about post-vasectomy pain syndrome (PVPS) — How it happens after a vasectomy, tests to diagnose it and treatment options.
symptoms: Pain and tenderness in the scrotum
Dull ache in one or both testicles
Pain and tenderness at the site of the vasectomy
Swelling of the small, C-shaped tube behind the testicle where sperm are stored (epididymis)

name: Dyshidrosis
description: Learn about the symptoms, causes and treatment of this skin condition that causes little blisters on the hands.
preventions: Using mild cleansers and lukewarm water to wash your hands and drying your hands well

name: Avascular necrosis
description: A broken bone or dislocated joint can block blood flow to the bone, causing bone tissue to die.

name: Legionnaires' disease
description: Bacteria that can live in water from air conditioning systems, showers and spas cause this severe form of pneumonia.
symptoms: Fever that may be 104 F (40 C) or higher
risks: Have a chronic lung disease or other serious condition
diagnosis: Chest X-ray, which doesn't confirm Legionnaires' disease but can show the extent of infection in your lungs
Tests on a sample of your sputum or lung tissue

name: Kidney infection
description: A urinary tract infection that travels to the kidneys can be dangerous. Know the symptoms and when to get prompt medical treatment.
symptoms: A burning feeling or pain when urinating
A strong, lasting urge to urinate
Pus or blood in the urine
Urine that smells bad or is cloudy
risks: Having damage to nerves around the bladder
Having a condition that causes urine to flow the wrong way
preventions: Urinate as soon as you need to
Empty the bladder after sexual intercourse
Avoid using products in the genital area

name: Dyslexia
description: This learning disorder involves difficulty reading due to problems identifying speech sounds and learning how they relate to letters and words.
diagnosis: Your childs development educational issues and medical history
Vision hearing and brain neurological tests
Tests for reading and other academic skills

name: Aspergillosis
description: This fungal lung infection is caused by inhaling certain mold spores. It may be serious in those with asthma or other chronic lung diseases.

name: Leiomyosarcoma
description: Learn about this rare cancer that begins in smooth muscle tissue. Leiomyosarcoma treatments include surgery, radiation therapy and chemotherapy.

name: Pyloric stenosis
description: In this condition, a valve between an infant's stomach and small intestine fails to open enough for food to pass through. Surgery is the treatment.
diagnosis: Blood tests to check for dehydration or electrolyte imbalance or both.
Ultrasound to view the pylorus and confirm a diagnosis of pyloric stenosis.
X-rays of your baby's digestive system, if results of the ultrasound aren't clear.

name: Menstrual cramps
description: Menstrual cramps — pain in the lower abdomen just before or during menstrual periods — can range from mild to severe. Learn about treatment options.
symptoms: Throbbing or cramping pain in your lower abdomen that can be intense
Pain that starts 1 to 3 days before your period, peaks 24 hours after the onset of your period and subsides in 2 to 3 days
Pain that radiates to your lower back and thighs
risks: You started puberty early, at age 11 or younger
You have a family history of menstrual cramps (dysmenorrhea)

name: Asthma
description: Find out what can trigger asthma and how to relieve your symptoms and breathe easier.
symptoms: Wheezing when exhaling, which is a common sign of asthma in children
Trouble sleeping caused by shortness of breath, coughing or wheezing
Coughing or wheezing attacks that are worsened by a respiratory virus, such as a cold or the flu
risks: Having a blood relative with asthma, such as a parent or sibling
Having another allergic condition, such as atopic dermatitis — which causes red, itchy skin — or hay fever — which causes a runny nose, congestion and itchy eyes
Exposure to exhaust fumes or other types of pollution
Exposure to occupational triggers, such as chemicals used in farming, hairdressing and manufacturing
complications: Signs and symptoms that interfere with sleep, work and other activities
Sick days from work or school during asthma flare-ups
A permanent narrowing of the tubes that carry air to and from your lungs (bronchial tubes), which affects how well you can breathe
Emergency room visits and hospitalizations for severe asthma attacks
Side effects from long-term use of some medications used to stabilize severe asthma
preventions: Get vaccinated for influenza and pneumonia
Pay attention to increasing quickrelief inhaler use

name: Age spots
description: Learn more about the harmless dark spots on your skin that tend to appear as you age, especially in areas exposed to the sun. Treatment is available.
risks: Have a history of frequent or intense sun exposure or sunburn
preventions: Avoid the sun between 10 am and 2 pm

name: Pyoderma gangrenosum
description: Learn about the symptoms, treatment and risk factors of this skin condition with open sores, along with advice on how to cope with it.

name: Painful intercourse
description: Painful intercourse can occur in women for various reasons, ranging from physical problems to emotional concerns. Medications or other therapies may help.
symptoms: Pain with every penetration, including putting in a tampon
Throbbing pain, lasting hours after intercourse

name: Asthma attack
description: Learn how to recognize when you need to step up treatment.
symptoms: Severe shortness of breath, chest tightness or pain, and coughing or wheezing
Low peak expiratory flow (PEF) readings, if you use a peak flow meter
Symptoms that fail to respond to use of a quick-acting (rescue) inhaler
causes: Pollen, pets, mold and dust mites
risks: You've had a severe asthma attack in the past
You've previously been admitted to the hospital or had to go to the emergency room for asthma
You've previously required intubation for an asthma attack
You use more than two quick-acting (rescue) inhalers a month
Your asthma attacks tend to sneak up on you before you notice symptoms have worsened
You have other chronic health conditions, such as sinusitis or nasal polyps, or cardiovascular or chronic lung disease
complications: Interrupt everyday activities such as sleep, school, work and exercise, causing a significant impact on your quality of life — and can disrupt the lives of those around you.
Send you to the emergency room, which can be stressful and costly.
Lead to respiratory arrest and death.

name: Leukemia
description: Learn about this cancer that forms in the blood and bone marrow.
symptoms: Swollen lymph nodes, enlarged liver or spleen
Tiny red spots in your skin (petechiae)
treatment: Engineering immune cells to fight leukemia

name: Rheumatoid arthritis
description: This chronic inflammatory disorder can affect more than just your joints. It can also damage your skin, eyes, lungs, heart and blood vessels.
symptoms: Joint stiffness that is usually worse in the mornings and after inactivity
Fatigue, fever and loss of appetite

name: Indigestion
description: Is it indigestion or something else? Find out about causes, symptoms and treatment for this common digestive disorder.
causes: Too much caffeine, alcohol, chocolate or carbonated beverages
Certain antibiotics, pain relievers and iron supplements
diagnosis: Imaging tests Xray or CT scan
treatment: Eating five or six small meals a day instead of three large meals
Reducing or eliminating the use of alcohol and caffeine
Avoiding certain pain relievers, such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve)
Finding alternatives for medications that trigger indigestion

name: Childhood asthma
description: The lungs and airways of children with asthma become inflamed, interfering with daily activities. Some children can have dangerous attacks.
symptoms: Frequent coughing that worsens when your child has a viral infection, occurs while your child is asleep or is triggered by exercise or cold air
A whistling or wheezing sound when breathing out
causes: Some types of airway infections at a very young age
Exposure to environmental factors, such as cigarette smoke or other air pollution
risks: Exposure to tobacco smoke, including before birth
Previous allergic reactions, including skin reactions, food allergies or hay fever (allergic rhinitis)
A family history of asthma or allergies
Living in an area with high pollution
Respiratory conditions, such as a chronic runny or stuffy nose (rhinitis), inflamed sinuses (sinusitis) or pneumonia
complications: Severe asthma attacks that require emergency treatment or hospital care
Missed school days or getting behind in school
Symptoms that interfere with play, sports or other activities
preventions: Dont allow smoking around your child
Encourage your child to be active
Help your child maintain a healthy weight
diagnosis: Acid reflux or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
Respiratory tract infections such as bronchiolitis and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)

name: Acute lymphocytic leukemia
description: Learn about this cancer that forms in the blood and bone marrow. Treatments include medications and bone marrow transplant.
symptoms: Lumps caused by swollen lymph nodes in and around the neck, armpits, abdomen or groin
Weakness, fatigue or a general decrease in energy

name: Rabies
description: Learn about this deadly virus that most often spreads to people through the bite of an infected animal.
symptoms: Fear brought on by attempts to drink fluids because of difficulty swallowing water
Fear brought on by air blown on the face
risks: Traveling or living in developing countries where rabies is more common

Activities that are likely to put you in contact with wild animals that may have rabies, such as exploring caves where bats live or camping without taking precautions to keep wild animals away from your campsite
Working in a laboratory with the rabies virus
Wounds to the head or neck, which may help the rabies virus travel to your brain more quickly
preventions: Report stray animals to local authorities
Keep bats out of your home
Consider the rabies vaccine if youre traveling or often around animals that may have rabies
treatment: A fast-acting shot (rabies immune globulin) to prevent the virus from infecting you. This is given if you haven't had the rabies vaccine. This injection is given near the area where the animal bit you if possible, as soon as possible after the bite.

A series of rabies vaccinations to help your body learn to identify and fight the rabies virus. Rabies vaccinations are given as injections in your arm. If you haven't previously had the rabies vaccines, you'll receive four injections over 14 days. If you have had the rabies vaccine, you'll have two injections over the first three days.

name: Dysphagia
description: Learn more about what causes persistent trouble swallowing, along with therapies for treating this condition.
symptoms: A sensation of food getting stuck in the throat or chest or behind the breastbone (sternum)
Food or stomach acid backing up into the throat
diagnosis: Xray with a contrast material barium Xray
A visual examination of your esophagus endoscopy
Fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing FEES

name: Exercise-induced asthma
description: Regular exercise is beneficial in many ways, but for some people, exercise can trigger breathing problems. Medicine can help.
symptoms: Avoiding activity, which happens mostly in young children.
complications: Serious or life-threatening breathing difficulties, particularly among people with poorly managed asthma.
Lower quality of life because of inability to exercise.

name: Radiation enteritis
description: This complication of radiation therapy for cancer can cause stomach pain, vomiting or diarrhea. For most people, symptoms go away within weeks.

name: Acute myelogenous leukemia
description: Learn about this cancer that forms in the bone and bone marrow. Treatments include medications and bone marrow transplant.
symptoms: Unusual bleeding, such as frequent nosebleeds and bleeding from the gums

name: Voice disorder
description: Learn more about the causes of common voice disorders, such as laryngitis and granuloma, and how Mayo Clinic diagnoses and treats them.
causes: Voice changes related to the brain and nervous system, known as spasmodic dysphonia (spaz-MOD-ki dis-FOE-nee-uh)
Polyps, nodules or cysts on the vocal cords — growths that aren't cancer
White patches, also known as leukoplakia (loo-koh-PLAY-key-uh)
risks: Conditions related to the brain and nervous system, such as Parkinson's disease or a stroke
Illnesses, such as colds or upper respiratory infections
Scarring from neck surgery or from trauma to the front of the neck

name: Occupational asthma
description: Dust, fumes and other substances you come into contact with at work can cause asthma. Find out how to recognize this common type of asthma.
risks: You have existing allergies or asthma
Allergies or asthma runs in your family
You work around known asthma triggers

name: Radiation sickness
description: Read about what happens when someone is exposed to high doses of radiation, and what you can do to prevent such exposure in an emergency.
complications: Experiencing a radioactive accident or attack
Mourning friends or family who haven't survived
Dealing with the uncertainty of a mysterious and potentially fatal illness
Worrying about the eventual risk of cancer due to radiation exposure

name: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
description: Learn about this cancer that forms in white blood cells called lymphocytes. Treatments include chemotherapy, targeted therapy and immunotherapy.
symptoms: Pain in the upper left portion of the abdomen, which may be caused by an enlarged spleen
risks: Family history of blood and bone marrow cancers
A condition that causes excess lymphocytes
complications: A switch to a more aggressive form of cancer

name: Heart arrhythmia
description: Learn about common heart rhythm disorders that can cause your heart to beat too fast, too slow or irregularly.
risks: Coronary artery disease other heart problems and previous heart surgery
Caffeine nicotine or illegal drug use
preventions: Limiting or avoiding caffeine and alcohol
Reducing stress, as intense stress and anger can cause heart rhythm problems
Using medications as directed and telling your doctor about all the medicines you take, including those bought without a prescription

name: Astigmatism
description: Imperfect curvature of your eye can cause blurred distance and near vision. Learn about this common and treatable eye condition.

name: Ramsay Hunt syndrome
description: A shingles outbreak can affect the facial nerve near one of your ears, potentially causing facial paralysis and hearing loss.
risks: Anyone who's never had chickenpox or who's never had the chickenpox vaccine
Anyone who has a weak immune system
complications: Permanent hearing loss and facial weakness

name: Chronic myelogenous leukemia
description: Learn about chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) symptoms and causes. Find out how doctors treat CML, including targeted therapy and bone marrow transplant.
symptoms: Feeling full after eating a small amount of food
Pain or fullness below the ribs on the left side
risks: Radiation exposure, such as radiation therapy for certain types of cancer

name: Persistent depressive disorder
description: This type of depression may cause you to feel sad and empty and to lose interest in life. You may feel like a failure. These feelings may last years.
symptoms: Loss of interest in daily activities.
Low self-esteem, self-criticism or feeling you're not capable.
Trouble focusing clearly and trouble making decisions.
Problems getting things done well and on time.
Quickly becoming annoyed, impatient or angry.
Feelings of guilt and worries over the past.
risks: Having a first-degree blood relative, such as a parent or sibling, with major depressive disorder or other depressive disorders.
Traumatic or stressful life events, such as the loss of a loved one or major financial problems.
Personality traits that include negativity, such as low self-esteem, being too dependent or self-critical, or always thinking the worst will happen.
History of other mental health disorders, such as a personality disorder.
complications: Major depression, anxiety disorders and other mood disorders.
School or work problems and trouble getting things done.
Continuing pain and general medical illnesses.
Personality disorders or other mental health disorders.
preventions: Reach out to family and friends
Get treatment at the earliest sign of a problem
treatment: Your desire to explore emotional or other issues affecting your life.
Other emotional problems you may have.
What type of treatment you prefer.

name: Astrocytoma
description: Astrocytoma — Overview covers diagnosis and treatment for this type of glioma brain tumor, including surgery, chemotherapy and radiation therapy.
treatment: Steroid medicines to reduce brain swelling.
Medicine to improves alertness if you have severe fatigue.
Medicine to help with thinking and memory problems.

name: Dumping syndrome
description: People who have had stomach or weight-loss surgery can develop dumping syndrome, which causes cramping, diarrhea and, sometimes, low blood sugar.
symptoms: Feeling bloated or too full after eating

name: Dystonia
description: Find out more about this painful muscle contraction disorder and ways to improve muscle function.
symptoms: Begin in a single area, such as your leg, neck or arm. Focal dystonia that begins after age 21 usually starts in the neck, arm or face. It tends to remain focal or become segmental.
Occur during a specific action, such as writing by hand.
Worsen with stress, fatigue or anxiety.
causes: Brain tumor or certain disorders that develop in some people with cancer (paraneoplastic syndromes)
Oxygen deprivation or carbon monoxide poisoning
Infections, such as tuberculosis or encephalitis
Reactions to certain medications or heavy metal poisoning
complications: Physical disabilities that affect your performance of daily activities or specific tasks
Difficulty with vision that affects your eyelids
Difficulty with jaw movement, swallowing or speech
Pain and fatigue, due to constant contraction of your muscles
treatment: Diazepam Valium Diastat others clonazepam Klonopin and baclofen Lioresal Gablofen others

name: Atrial tachycardia
description: This type of fast heartbeat may occur after heart surgery or during pregnancy. But infections may trigger it, too. Learn how it's diagnosed and treated.

name: Leukemia
description: Learn about this cancer that forms in the blood and bone marrow.
symptoms: Swollen lymph nodes, enlarged liver or spleen
Tiny red spots in your skin (petechiae)
treatment: Engineering immune cells to fight leukemia

name: Tachycardia
description: Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of this heart rhythm disorder (arrhythmia), which causes a rapid heart rate.
symptoms: Sensation of a racing, pounding heartbeat or flopping in the chest (palpitations)
causes: Heavy alcohol use or alcohol withdrawal
Imbalance of substances in the blood called electrolytes — such as potassium, sodium, calcium and magnesium
Reduced volume of red blood cells (anemia), often caused by bleeding
Use of illegal drugs, including stimulants such as cocaine or methamphetamine
complications: How fast the heart is beating
How long the rapid heart rate lasts
If there are other heart conditions
preventions: Keep blood pressure and cholesterol levels under control
Dont use illegal drugs or stimulants such as cocaine

name: Cervical dystonia
description: This rare movement disorder causes neck muscles to contract involuntarily. This can make your head twist or turn into often painful positions.

name: Ataxia
description: Often caused by an underlying condition, ataxia affects muscle control and coordination and impacts movement, speech and swallowing.
symptoms: Walking unsteadily or with the feet set wide apart
Difficulty with fine motor tasks, such as eating, writing or buttoning a shirt

name: Hairy cell leukemia
description: This slow-growing cancer doesn't always need immediate treatment. When hairy cell leukemia treatment is needed, it usually starts with chemotherapy.
symptoms: A feeling of fullness in your belly that may make it uncomfortable to eat more than a little at a time

name: Poison ivy rash
description: Learn about the symptoms, causes and home remedies for this itchy skin rash and how to prevent it.
symptoms: Difficulty breathing, if you've inhaled the smoke from burning poison ivy
preventions: Wash your skin or your pets fur

name: Atelectasis
description: Atelectasis is a partly or completely collapsed lung. Know the symptoms and causes.
risks: Any condition that makes it difficult to swallow
Confinement to bed with infrequent changes of position
Lung disease, such as asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis or cystic fibrosis
Weak breathing (respiratory) muscles due to muscular dystrophy, spinal cord injury or another neuromuscular condition
Medications that may cause shallow breathing
Pain or injury that may make it painful to cough or cause shallow breathing, including stomach pain or rib fracture

name: E coli infection
description: Most strains of E. coli bacteria are harmless, but some can cause severe symptoms. Learn about symptoms and treatment of this common foodborne illness.
symptoms: Diarrhea, which may range from mild and watery to severe and bloody
Nausea and vomiting, in some people
treatment: Fluids to help prevent dehydration and fatigue

name: Leukoplakia
description: Leukoplakia appears as thickened, white patches on your gums, cheeks and bottom of your mouth that can't be scraped off.
symptoms: White or grayish in patches that can't be wiped away
Along with raised, red lesions (speckled leukoplakia or erythroplakia), which are more likely to show precancerous changes
causes: Jagged, broken or sharp teeth rubbing on tongue surfaces
diagnosis: Examining the patches in your mouth
Attempting to wipe off the white patches
Discussing your medical history and risk factors
treatment: Followup visits to check the area

name: Raynaud's disease
description: Learn how this disease causes parts of the body, mainly fingers and toes, to feel cold and numb and possibly change colors from cold temperatures or stress.

name: Arteriosclerosis/atherosclerosis
description: Learn about the symptoms, causes and treatments for hardening of the arteries.
symptoms: If you have atherosclerosis in your heart arteries
If you have atherosclerosis in the arteries leading to your brain
If you have atherosclerosis in the arteries in your arms and legs
If you have atherosclerosis in the arteries leading to your kidneys
risks: A family history of early heart disease
High levels of C-reactive protein (CRP), a marker of inflammation
preventions: Checking and maintaining a healthy blood pressure
Checking and maintaining healthy cholesterol and blood sugar levels

name: Middle ear infection
description: These usually get better on their own, but sometimes medicine is needed. Find out more about how doctors diagnose and treat this common ear condition.
preventions: Prevent common colds and other illnesses
If you bottlefeed hold your baby in an upright position
Talk to your doctor about vaccinations

name: Lewy body dementia
description: This common dementia is caused by a buildup of proteins in the brain, and it affects thinking, memory and motor control.
symptoms: Poor regulation of body functions autonomic nervous system
complications: Increased risk of falling and injury
Worsening of parkinsonian signs and symptoms, such as tremors
Death, on average about seven to eight years after symptoms start
diagnosis: REM sleep behavior disorder, in which people act out their dreams during sleep

name: Reactive arthritis
description: This joint pain is triggered by an infection in another part of the body — often the intestines, genitals or urinary tract.

name: Athlete's foot
description: Learn about the causes, symptoms, prevention and treatment of this common fungal skin infection.
risks: Share mats, rugs, bed linens, clothes or shoes with someone who has a fungal infection
Walk barefoot in public areas where the infection can spread, such as locker rooms, saunas, swimming pools, communal baths and showers
preventions: Protect your feet in public places
Be aware of the risk factors for spreading the condition

name: Swimmer's ear
description: The moist environment from water remaining in your ear after swimming or bathing can lead to this infection in the outer ear canal.
risks: Excess moisture in your ear canal
complications: Bone and cartilage damage early skull base osteomyelitis
preventions: Use caution after an ear infection or surgery
Avoid putting foreign objects in your ear

name: Lice infestation
description: Learn how to get rid of these tiny, wingless insects and keep them from coming back.
causes: Items shared among friends or family members
Contact with furniture that has lice on it
preventions: Ask your child to avoid headtohead contact
Teach your child not to share personal belongings
Tell your child to avoid shared spaces

name: Reactive attachment disorder
description: Reactive attachment disorder is when an infant or young child doesn't establish healthy attachments with parents or caregivers due to neglect.
symptoms: Unexplained withdrawal, fear, sadness or irritability
Not seeking comfort or showing no response when comfort is given
Watching others closely but not engaging in social interaction
Failure to reach out when picked up
No interest in playing peekaboo or other interactive games
Failing to seek support or assistance
risks: Live in a children's home or other institution
Frequently change foster homes or caregivers
Have parents who have severe mental health problems, criminal behavior or substance abuse that impairs their parenting
Have prolonged separation from parents or other caregivers due to repeated out-of-home placement, hospitalization or death of a primary caregiver
preventions: Be actively engaged with your child
Learn to interpret your babys cues
Provide warm nurturing interaction with your child
Offer both verbal and nonverbal responses
Take classes or volunteer with children
diagnosis: Direct observation of interaction with parents or caregivers
Details about the pattern of behavior over time
Examples of the behavior in a variety of situations
Information about interactions with parents or caregivers and others
Questions about the home and living situation since birth
An evaluation of parenting and caregiving styles and abilities
treatment: Has a safe and stable living situation
Develops positive interactions and strengthens the attachment with parents and caregivers

name: Body lice infestation
description: Body lice are tiny insects that live in your clothing and feed on your blood. Find out how to treat and prevent this itchy nuisance of a bug.

name: Ruptured eardrum
description: A ruptured eardrum is a hole or tear in your eardrum, the thin tissue that separates your ear canal from your middle ear.
symptoms: Ear pain that may subside quickly
Mucuslike, pus-filled or bloody drainage from the ear
Nausea or vomiting that can result from vertigo
preventions: Get treatment for middle ear infections
Keep your ears free of foreign objects

name: Atopic dermatitis
description: Learn about the causes, symptoms and treatments of this itchy rash that most often begins before age 5, is persistent, and has periods of clearing and relapse.
complications: Patches of skin thats darker or lighter than the surrounding area
preventions: Moisturize your skin at least twice a day
Take a daily bath or shower
treatment: Medicated products applied to the skin

name: Dyslexia
description: This learning disorder involves difficulty reading due to problems identifying speech sounds and learning how they relate to letters and words.
diagnosis: Your childs development educational issues and medical history
Vision hearing and brain neurological tests
Tests for reading and other academic skills

name: Lichen planus
description: Learn about the causes, symptoms and treatment of this skin condition that causes swelling and irritation in the skin, hair, nails, mouth and vagina.
symptoms: Purplish, flat bumps, most often on the inner forearm, wrist or ankle, and sometimes the genitals
Blisters that break to form scabs or crusts
Lacy white patches in the mouth or on the lips or tongue
Painful sores in the mouth or vagina
causes: Pain relievers, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen (Aleve, others)
Certain medications for heart disease, high blood pressure or arthritis

name: Precocious puberty
description: Read about the signs and symptoms, causes, and risk factors that may cause a child's body to begin changing into an adult's body too soon.
symptoms: Breast growth and first period in girls
Enlarged testicles and penis, facial hair and deepening voice in boys
risks: Having received radiation therapy of the central nervous system
preventions: Keeping your child away from external sources of estrogen and testosterone — such as prescription medications for adults in the house or dietary supplements containing estrogen or testosterone
Encouraging your child to maintain a healthy weight
diagnosis: Review your child's and your family's medical history
Run blood tests to measure hormone levels

name: Atrial fibrillation
description: A fast, pounding heartbeat could be due to A-fib, a type of heart rhythm problem (arrhythmia). Know the warning signs and when treatment is needed.
symptoms: Sensations of a fast, fluttering or pounding heartbeat (palpitations)
causes: Heart defect that you're born with (congenital heart defect)
Physical stress due to surgery, pneumonia or other illnesses
Problem with the heart's natural pacemaker (sick sinus syndrome)
Thyroid disease such as an overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism) and other metabolic imbalances
Use of stimulants, including certain medications, caffeine, tobacco and alcohol
preventions: Get regular exercise and maintain a healthy weight
Avoid or limit alcohol and caffeine
Manage stress, as intense stress and anger can cause heart rhythm problems

name: Atrial flutter
description: Learn more about this condition in which the heart's upper chambers (atria) beat too quickly, causing a rapid, but usually regular, heart rhythm.

name: Medication overuse headache
description: When medications that ease headache pain are used too often, these drugs can actually start causing headaches. Learn about prevention and treatment.
symptoms: Occur every day or nearly every day, often waking you in the early morning
Improve with pain relief medication but then return as your medication wears off
preventions: Take your headache medication as prescribed.
If you need headache medication more than twice a week, contact your doctor.
Avoid medications that contain butalbital or opioids.
Use OTC painkillers less than 15 days a month.
Limit use of triptans or combination analgesics to no more than nine days a month.

name: Earwax blockage
description: Learn simple steps for treatment and self-care of this common problem, including earwax removal.
symptoms: Feeling of fullness in the ear
Ringing or noises in the ear (tinnitus)
Odor or discharge in the ear
Pain or infection in the ear

name: Oral lichen planus
description: This chronic inflammatory condition results in white, lacy patches; red, swollen tissues; or open sores inside your mouth that may cause burning or pain.
complications: Secondary oral yeast or fungal infections
diagnosis: Discussion of your medical and dental history and the medications you're taking
Review of symptoms, including lesions in your mouth and any other places on your body
Examination of your mouth, and other areas as appropriate

name: Atrial septal defect
description: This opening between the heart's upper chambers is this common congenital heart defect, but can be treated.
symptoms: Shortness of breath, especially when exercising
Swelling of legs, feet or belly (abdomen)
Sensation of a rapid, pounding heartbeat (palpitations) or skipped beats
Whooshing sound that can be heard through a stethoscope (heart murmur)
risks: German measles (rubella) infection during the first few months of pregnancy
Illegal drug use, such as cocaine
Use of certain medications, including some anti-seizure medications and drugs to treat mood disorders
complications: High blood pressure in the lung arteries (pulmonary hypertension)
preventions: Discussing current health conditions and medications
Getting tested for immunity to German measles rubella
diagnosis: Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging MRI scan

name: Rectal cancer
description: Find out about rectal cancer symptoms, causes and prevention. Learn about treatments, including chemotherapy, radiation and surgery.
symptoms: A change in bowel habits, such as diarrhea, constipation or more-frequent bowel movements
Dark maroon or bright red blood in stool
A feeling that your bowel doesn't empty completely
risks: A personal history of colorectal cancer or polyps
Inherited syndromes that increase rectal cancer risk
Eating a diet low in vegetables
preventions: Talk to your doctor about cancer screening
Exercise most days of the week
Eat a variety of fruits vegetables and whole grains
Drink alcohol in moderation if at all

name: Eating disorder
description: Eating disorders, such as anorexia, bulimia and binge-eating disorder, seriously impact health. Learn about symptoms and treatments.
preventions: Cultivate and reinforce a healthy body image
Enlist the help of your childs doctor

name: Lichen sclerosus
description: Learn more about the causes, symptoms, complications, treatment and self-care tips for this blotchy skin condition that affects the genital and anal areas.
risks: Women who have another autoimmune disease, such as forms of low thyroid function (hypothyroidism)
Men with urinary incontinence or an uncircumcised penis
People with a family history of the disease

name: Atrial tachycardia
description: This type of fast heartbeat may occur after heart surgery or during pregnancy. But infections may trigger it, too. Learn how it's diagnosed and treated.

name: Proctitis
description: Proctitis means inflammation of the rectal lining. This condition is often a treatment side effect or part of a more generalized disease.
symptoms: A frequent or continuous feeling that you need to have a bowel movement
Pain on the left side of your abdomen
A feeling of fullness in your rectum
preventions: Limiting your number of sex partners
Using a latex condom during each sexual contact
Not having sex with anyone who has any unusual sores or discharge in the genital area

name: Neurodermatitis
description: Learn about this itchy skin condition that can disrupt your sleep and daily activities. Treatment focuses on controlling itching and preventing scratching.
symptoms: An itchy, scaly skin patch or patches
Raised, rough patches that are inflamed or darker than the rest of the skin

name: Anorexia nervosa
description: Anorexia is an eating disorder characterized by an abnormally low body weight, intense fear of gaining weight and a distorted perception of body weight.
complications: Heart problems, such as mitral valve prolapse, abnormal heart rhythms or heart failure
Bone loss (osteoporosis), increasing the risk of fractures
In females, absence of a period
Gastrointestinal problems, such as constipation, bloating or nausea
Electrolyte abnormalities, such as low blood potassium, sodium and chloride
treatment: Not seeing anorexia as an illness but rather a lifestyle choice

name: Atrioventricular canal defect
description: This congenital heart defect involves a hole in the heart. It affects blood flow through the heart valves. Learn the symptoms and how it's treated.
complications: High blood pressure in the lungs

name: Anal itching
description: Learn about the causes, treatment and self-care tips for this common, sometimes embarrassing condition.

name: Lip cancer
description: Lip cancer often appears as a sore on your lip that doesn't heal. Learn about lip cancer treatments, including surgery, radiation and chemotherapy.
symptoms: A flat or slightly raised whitish discoloration of the lip
A sore on your lip that won't heal
Tingling, pain or numbness of the lips or the skin around the mouth
risks: Tobacco use of any kind, including cigarettes, cigars, pipes, chewing tobacco and snuff, among others
Excessive sun exposure to your lips
preventions: Stop using tobacco or dont start
Avoid the sun during the middle of the day
Use a broadspectrum sunscreen with an SPF of at least 30 even on cloudy days
diagnosis: Removing a sample of tissue for testing

name: Binge-eating disorder
description: People with binge-eating disorder frequently consume unusually large amounts of food and feel unable to stop eating. Learn about symptoms and treatment.
symptoms: Eating unusually large amounts of food in a specific amount of time, such as over a two-hour period
Feeling that your eating behavior is out of control
Eating even when you're full or not hungry
Frequently eating alone or in secret
Feeling depressed, disgusted, ashamed, guilty or upset about your eating
Frequently dieting, possibly without weight loss
complications: Problems functioning at work, with your personal life or in social situations
Medical conditions related to obesity, such as joint problems, heart disease, type 2 diabetes, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and some sleep-related breathing disorders
preventions: Foster and reinforce a healthy body image
Discuss any concerns with your childs primary care provider

name: AV nodal reentry tachycardia
description: This most common type of supraventricular tachycardia, a type of irregular heartbeat, tends to occur in young women. Know the symptoms and treatment.

name: Rectal prolapse
description: It's unclear what exactly causes this rare condition in which the rectum slips outside of the anus. Find out about symptoms and treatment.
symptoms: The inability to control bowel movements (fecal incontinence)
Leaking blood or mucus from the rectum
Feeling that your rectum isn't empty after a bowel movement

name: Bulimia
description: With bulimia, a serious eating disorder, you eat large amounts of food and then purge to get rid of extra calories. Learn about symptoms and treatment.
symptoms: Being preoccupied with your body shape and weight
Living in fear of gaining weight
Repeated episodes of eating abnormally large amounts of food in one sitting
Feeling a loss of control during bingeing — like you can't stop eating or can't control what you eat
Forcing yourself to vomit or exercising too much to keep from gaining weight after bingeing
Using laxatives, diuretics or enemas after eating when they're not needed
Fasting, restricting calories or avoiding certain foods between binges
Using dietary supplements or herbal products excessively for weight loss
complications: Negative self-esteem and problems with relationships and social functioning
Dehydration, which can lead to major medical problems, such as kidney failure
Heart problems, such as an irregular heartbeat or heart failure
Severe tooth decay and gum disease
Absent or irregular periods in females
Anxiety, depression, personality disorders or bipolar disorder
preventions: Foster and reinforce a healthy body image in your children, no matter what their size or shape. Help them build confidence in ways other than their appearance.
Avoid talking about weight at home. Focus instead on having a healthy lifestyle.
Discourage dieting, especially when it involves unhealthy weight-control behaviors, such as fasting, using weight-loss supplements or laxatives, or self-induced vomiting.
Talk with your primary care provider. He or she may be in a good position to identify early indicators of an eating disorder and help prevent its development.

If you notice a relative or friend who seems to have food issues that could lead to or indicate an eating disorder, consider supportively talking to the person about these issues and ask how you can help.
diagnosis: Talk to you about your eating habits, weight-loss methods and physical symptoms
Request a test that can identify problems with your heart (electrocardiogram)
Perform a psychological evaluation, including a discussion of your attitude toward your body and weight
Use the criteria for bulimia listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association

name: Mouth cancer
description: Learn what doctors and dentists look for when diagnosing mouth cancer. Find out about oral cancer treatments, including surgery, chemotherapy and radiation.
symptoms: A lip or mouth sore that doesn't heal
A white or reddish patch on the inside of your mouth
A growth or lump inside your mouth
risks: Tobacco use of any kind, including cigarettes, cigars, pipes, chewing tobacco and snuff, among others
Excessive sun exposure to your lips
A sexually transmitted virus called human papillomavirus (HPV)
preventions: Stop using tobacco or dont start
Drink alcohol only in moderation if at all
Avoid excessive sun exposure to your lips

name: Atrioventricular canal defect
description: This congenital heart defect involves a hole in the heart. It affects blood flow through the heart valves. Learn the symptoms and how it's treated.
complications: High blood pressure in the lungs

name: Solitary rectal ulcer syndrome
description: Solitary rectal ulcer syndrome is a rare condition that's often linked to chronic constipation. Learn more about symptoms and treatment.
symptoms: Pain or a feeling of fullness in your pelvis
A feeling of incomplete passing of stool

name: Whipple's disease
description: Learn more about the symptoms, causes and treatment of this rare primarily digestive infection.
risks: White people in North America and Europe
Farmers and other people who work outdoors and have frequent contact with sewage and wastewater

name: Ebstein anomaly
description: In this rare heart defect, the tricuspid heart valve didn't form properly. This can affect the heart's ability to pump blood. Know the risks and symptoms.
symptoms: Shortness of breath, especially with exertion
Heart palpitations or abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias)
A bluish discoloration of the lips and skin caused by low oxygen (cyanosis)

name: Vaginal atrophy
description: Read about this condition that causes vaginal and urinary symptoms, often after menopause. It's also called genitourinary syndrome of menopause.
symptoms: Decreased vaginal lubrication during sexual activity
Shortening and tightening of the vaginal canal

name: Rectovaginal fistula
description: This open tunnel connects the rectum and vagina, allowing gas or stool to pass into the vagina. Learn about rectovaginal fistula treatment and self-care.
causes: Cancer or radiation treatment in the pelvic area
Surgery involving the vagina perineum rectum or anus
complications: Uncontrolled loss of stool, called fecal incontinence.
Recurrent vaginal or urinary tract infections.
Irritation or inflammation of your vagina, perineum or the skin around your anus.

name: Lipoma
description: Lipoma — Comprehensive overview covers symptoms, causes, treatment of this usually harmless fatty tumor that tends to show up in middle age.
symptoms: Soft and doughy to the touch
diagnosis: A tissue sample removal (biopsy) for lab examination
An X-ray or other imaging test, such as an MRI or CT scan, if the lipoma is large, has unusual features or appears to be deeper than the fatty

name: Premature ventricular contractions
description: Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) are extra heartbeats that disrupt the heart rhythm. PVCs are common.
risks: Stimulants such as cocaine or methamphetamines
Exercise — if you have certain types of PVCs
Heart disease, including congenital heart disease, coronary artery disease, heart failure and a weakened heart muscle (cardiomyopathy)

name: Reactive attachment disorder
description: Reactive attachment disorder is when an infant or young child doesn't establish healthy attachments with parents or caregivers due to neglect.
symptoms: Unexplained withdrawal, fear, sadness or irritability
Not seeking comfort or showing no response when comfort is given
Watching others closely but not engaging in social interaction
Failure to reach out when picked up
No interest in playing peekaboo or other interactive games
Failing to seek support or assistance
risks: Live in a children's home or other institution
Frequently change foster homes or caregivers
Have parents who have severe mental health problems, criminal behavior or substance abuse that impairs their parenting
Have prolonged separation from parents or other caregivers due to repeated out-of-home placement, hospitalization or death of a primary caregiver
preventions: Be actively engaged with your child
Learn to interpret your babys cues
Provide warm nurturing interaction with your child
Offer both verbal and nonverbal responses
Take classes or volunteer with children
diagnosis: Direct observation of interaction with parents or caregivers
Details about the pattern of behavior over time
Examples of the behavior in a variety of situations
Information about interactions with parents or caregivers and others
Questions about the home and living situation since birth
An evaluation of parenting and caregiving styles and abilities
treatment: Has a safe and stable living situation
Develops positive interactions and strengthens the attachment with parents and caregivers

name: Recurrent breast cancer
description: Learn about symptoms that alert doctors to a breast cancer recurrence and strategies for treating cancer that comes back after initial treatment.
risks: Lack of radiation treatment following a lumpectomy
Lack of endocrine therapy for hormone receptorpositive breast cancer
diagnosis: Removing a sample of tissue for lab testing biopsy

name: Liposarcoma
description: Learn about diagnosis and treatment options for this type of soft tissue sarcoma that forms from fat cells.
symptoms: A growing lump of tissue under your skin
diagnosis: Removing a sample of tissue for testing
Using advanced lab tests to determine the kinds of cells involved in the cancer

name: Ectopic pregnancy
description: Ectopic pregnancy occurs outside the uterus, threatening the mother's life. It can't continue normally. But swift treatment can prevent deadly blood loss.
preventions: Limiting the number of sexual partners and using a condom during sex helps to prevent sexually transmitted infections and may reduce the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease.
Don't smoke. If you do, quit before you try to get pregnant.

name: Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder in children
description: This condition affects children, and may continue into adulthood. It can include difficulty sustaining attention, hyperactivity and impulsive behavior.
risks: Blood relatives, such as a parent or sibling, with ADHD or another mental health disorder
Exposure to environmental toxins — such as lead, found mainly in paint and pipes in older buildings
Maternal drug use, alcohol use or smoking during pregnancy
complications: Often struggle in the classroom, which can lead to academic failure and judgment by other children and adults
Tend to have more accidents and injuries of all kinds than do children who don't have ADHD
Are more likely to have trouble interacting with and being accepted by peers and adults
Are at increased risk of alcohol and drug abuse and other delinquent behavior
preventions: Protect your child from exposure to pollutants and toxins
diagnosis: ADHD criteria from the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders DSM5

name: Canker sores
description: Canker sore — Learn about the causes, treatment and prevention of this painful mouth sore.
causes: A minor injury to your mouth from dental work, overzealous brushing, sports mishaps or an accidental cheek bite
Toothpastes and mouth rinses containing sodium lauryl sulfate
Food sensitivities, particularly to chocolate, coffee, strawberries, eggs, nuts, cheese, and spicy or acidic foods
A diet lacking in vitamin B-12, zinc, folate (folic acid) or iron
An allergic response to certain bacteria in your mouth
Helicobacter pylori, the same bacteria that cause peptic ulcers

name: Listeria infection
description: This foodborne bacterial illness can be very serious for some people. Learn about symptoms, treatment and tips for prevention.
causes: Raw vegetables that have been contaminated from the soil or from contaminated manure used as fertilizer
Unpasteurized milk or foods made with unpasteurized milk
Certain processed foods — such as soft cheeses, hot dogs and deli meats that have been contaminated after processing
complications: Inflammation of the membranes and fluid surrounding the brain (meningitis)

name: Ectropion
description: Ectropion is an eye condition in which your eyelid sags or turns outward. Find out about causes and treatment for this common eye problem.

name: Subconjunctival hemorrhage
description: Subconjunctival hemorrhage is a broken blood vessel in the eye — learn more about this common, harmless condition that clears up without treatment.
risks: Certain blood-thinning medications, such as warfarin (Coumadin, Jantoven) and aspirin
diagnosis: Ask you questions about your general health and symptoms
Obtain a routine blood test to make sure you don't have a potentially serious bleeding disorder

name: Listeria infection
description: This foodborne bacterial illness can be very serious for some people. Learn about symptoms, treatment and tips for prevention.
causes: Raw vegetables that have been contaminated from the soil or from contaminated manure used as fertilizer
Unpasteurized milk or foods made with unpasteurized milk
Certain processed foods — such as soft cheeses, hot dogs and deli meats that have been contaminated after processing
complications: Inflammation of the membranes and fluid surrounding the brain (meningitis)

name: Adult ADHD
description: This mental health disorder includes a combination of persistent problems, such as difficulty paying attention, hyperactivity and impulsive behavior.
symptoms: Problems following through and completing tasks
risks: You have blood relatives, such as a parent or sibling, with ADHD or another mental health disorder
Your mother smoked, drank alcohol or used drugs during pregnancy
As a child, you were exposed to environmental toxins — such as lead, found mainly in paint and pipes in older buildings
complications: Frequent car accidents or other accidents
diagnosis: ADHD rating scales or psychological tests

name: Atopic dermatitis
description: Learn about the causes, symptoms and treatments of this itchy rash that most often begins before age 5, is persistent, and has periods of clearing and relapse.
complications: Patches of skin thats darker or lighter than the surrounding area
preventions: Moisturize your skin at least twice a day
Take a daily bath or shower
treatment: Medicated products applied to the skin

name: Bile reflux
description: This digestive problem tends to develop in people who've had stomach surgery and sometimes contributes to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
symptoms: Upper abdominal pain that may be severe
Frequent heartburn — a burning sensation in your chest that sometimes spreads to your throat, along with a sour taste in your mouth

name: Dyshidrosis
description: Learn about the symptoms, causes and treatment of this skin condition that causes little blisters on the hands.
preventions: Using mild cleansers and lukewarm water to wash your hands and drying your hands well

name: Liver cancer
description: Learn how doctors use surgery, liver transplant, radiation, chemotherapy and other methods to treat hepatocellular carcinoma and other types of liver cancer.
risks: Chronic infection with HBV or HCV

name: Atypical hyperplasia of the breast
description: Learn how a diagnosis of atypical lobular hyperplasia or atypical ductal hyperplasia affects your risk of breast cancer and what you can do.

name: Vesicoureteral reflux
description: Learn about what happens if urine flows backward from the bladder. Usually found in children, this condition boosts the risk of urinary tract infections.
symptoms: A strong, persistent urge to urinate
The need to pass small amounts of urine frequently
Pain in your side (flank) or abdomen
diagnosis: Specialized Xray of urinary tract system

name: Erectile dysfunction
description: Understand what can cause the inability to get and keep an erection firm enough for sex and the possible treatment options.
complications: The inability to get your partner pregnant
preventions: Work with your doctor to manage diabetes, heart disease or other chronic health conditions.
See your doctor for regular checkups and medical screening tests.
Stop smoking, limit or avoid alcohol, and don't use illegal drugs.
Get help for anxiety, depression or other mental health concerns.

name: Liver problems
description: The liver has a lot of important functions including ridding the body of toxins. Learn about problems that can affect the liver and how to avoid them.
risks: Exposure to other people's blood and body fluids
Exposure to certain chemicals or toxins
preventions: Avoid contact with other peoples blood and body fluids

name: Autism spectrum disorder
description: Autism spectrum disorder is a serious condition related to brain development that impairs the ability to communicate and interact with others.
complications: Problems in school and with successful learning
diagnosis: Observe your child and ask how your child's social interactions, communication skills and behavior have developed and changed over time
Give your child tests covering hearing, speech, language, developmental level, and social and behavioral issues
Present structured social and communication interactions to your child and score the performance
Use the criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association
Include other specialists in determining a diagnosis
Recommend genetic testing to identify whether your child has a genetic disorder such as Rett syndrome or fragile X syndrome

name: Aortic valve regurgitation
description: Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of this condition in which the heart's aortic valve doesn't close tightly.
symptoms: Shortness of breath with exercise or when you lie down
Fatigue and weakness, especially when you increase your activity level
Chest pain (angina), discomfort or tightness, often increasing during exercise
Sensations of a rapid, fluttering heartbeat (palpitations)
risks: Certain heart conditions present at birth (congenital heart disease)
History of infections that can affect the heart
Certain conditions that can affect the heart, such as Marfan syndrome
Other heart valve conditions, such as aortic valve stenosis
complications: Infections that affect the heart, such as endocarditis

name: Edema
description: Learn about symptoms, causes and treatment of swelling caused by too much fluid in body tissues.
causes: Sitting or staying in one position for too long.
risks: Having a long-lasting illness, such as congestive heart failure or liver or kidney disease.
Having surgery that involves a lymph node.
complications: Swelling that gets more and more painful.
Increased risk of infection in the swollen area.
Less ability of the of arteries, veins, joints and muscles to stretch.

name: Acute liver failure
description: A rapid loss of liver function can occur in people who don't even have liver disease. Find out about symptoms, treatment and prevention of this serious medical emergency.
symptoms: Yellowing of your skin and eyeballs (jaundice)
Pain in your upper right abdomen
A general sense of feeling unwell (malaise)
Breath may have a musty or sweet odor
causes: Diseases of the veins in the liver
complications: Too much fluid in the brain cerebral edema
preventions: Tell your provider about all your medicines
Drink alcohol in moderation if at all
Avoid contact with other peoples blood and body fluids
Watch what gets on your skin

name: Autoimmune hepatitis
description: This type of hepatitis occurs when your immune system attacks your liver with destructive antibodies. Immune-suppressing medication is the main treatment.
symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice)
Abnormal blood vessels on the skin (spider angiomas)

name: Mitral valve regurgitation
description: Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of the most common heart valve condition, which causes blood to leak backward in the heart.
symptoms: Sound of blood flow across the valve (heart murmur)
Shortness of breath (dyspnea), especially when lying down
Sensation of a rapid, pounding or fluttering heartbeat (palpitations)
risks: Certain infections that affect the heart
Heart problems present at birth (congenital heart defect)
History of other heart valve diseases, including mitral valve prolapse and mitral valve stenosis
complications: Irregular and often rapid heart rate atrial fibrillation
High blood pressure in the lungs pulmonary hypertension

name: Liver hemangioma
description: A liver hemangioma is a noncancerous mass that typically doesn't need treatment. Find out more about this common liver condition and when to get treatment.
treatment: Surgery to remove the liver hemangioma
Surgery to remove part of the liver including the hemangioma
Procedures to stop blood flow to the hemangioma

name: Pulmonary edema
description: Get more information about the causes of this potentially life-threatening lung condition and learn how to treat and prevent it.
causes: If a heart problem causes the pulmonary edema, it's called cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Most often, the fluid buildup in the lungs is due to a heart condition.
If pulmonary edema is not heart related, it's called noncardiogenic pulmonary edema.
Sometimes, pulmonary edema can be caused by both a heart problem and a nonheart problem.
complications: Swelling of the legs, feet and belly area
Buildup of fluid in the membranes that surround the lungs (pleural effusion)
Congestion and swelling of the liver
preventions: Eat a healthy diet rich in fresh fruits, vegetables, whole grains, fat-free or low-fat dairy, and a variety of proteins.
diagnosis: Btype natriuretic peptide BNP blood test

name: Autoimmune pancreatitis
description: Autoimmune pancreatitis is a relatively uncommon disease of the pancreas that may be mistaken for pancreatic cancer.
symptoms: Pale stools or stools that float in the toilet
Pain in your upper abdomen or middle part of your back
Loss of appetite or feelings of fullness
Weight loss for no known reason

name: Reactive arthritis
description: This joint pain is triggered by an infection in another part of the body — often the intestines, genitals or urinary tract.

name: Age spots
description: Learn more about the harmless dark spots on your skin that tend to appear as you age, especially in areas exposed to the sun. Treatment is available.
risks: Have a history of frequent or intense sun exposure or sunburn
preventions: Avoid the sun between 10 am and 2 pm

name: Egg allergy
description: Egg allergy can cause a serious reaction in children and adults. Here's how to recognize egg allergy symptoms, and what to do if a severe reaction occurs.
symptoms: Skin inflammation or hives — the most common egg allergy reaction
Nasal congestion, runny nose and sneezing (allergic rhinitis)
Digestive symptoms, such as cramps, nausea and vomiting
Asthma signs and symptoms such as coughing, wheezing, chest tightness or shortness of breath
complications: Allergies to other foods, such as milk, soy or peanuts
Allergies to pet dander, dust mites or grass pollen
Allergic skin reactions such as atopic dermatitis
Asthma, which in turn increases the risk of having a severe allergic reaction to eggs or other foods
preventions: Wear an allergy bracelet or necklace
Let your childs caregivers know about his or her egg allergy

name: REM sleep behavior disorder
description: REM sleep behavior disorder is a sleep disorder in which you physically and vocally act out vivid, often unpleasant dreams during REM sleep.
symptoms: Movement, such as kicking, punching, arm flailing or jumping from bed, in response to action-filled or violent dreams, such as being chased or defending yourself from an attack
Noises, such as talking, laughing, shouting, emotional outcries or even cursing
Being able to recall the dream if you awaken during the episode
risks: Being male and over 50 years old
Having a certain type of neurodegenerative disorder
complications: Distress to your sleeping partner or other people living in your home
Social isolation for fear that others may become aware of your sleep disruption
Injury to yourself or your sleeping partner

name: Autonomic neuropathy
description: Damage to the nerves that control involuntary body functions, such as blood pressure and digestion, results in autonomic neuropathy.
preventions: Control your blood sugar if you have diabetes.
Get appropriate treatment if you have an autoimmune disease.
Take steps to prevent or control high blood pressure.
Achieve and maintain a healthy weight.

name: Enlarged liver
description: Having a larger than normal liver is a sign of a serious problem, such as liver disease, congestive heart failure or cancer.
symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and the whites of the eyes (jaundice)
risks: Large doses of medicines vitamins or supplements
preventions: Drink alcohol in moderation if at all
Follow directions when taking medications vitamins or supplements

name: Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
description: Learn about these complex genetic disorders that cause problems with connective tissue in the skin, joints and blood vessel walls.

name: Renal artery stenosis
description: Read more about what happens when the arteries leading to your kidneys become narrowed, as well as potential treatments for this condition.
symptoms: High blood pressure that begins suddenly or worsens without explanation
High blood pressure that begins before age 30 or after age 50
risks: A family history of early heart disease
complications: Kidney failure, requiring treatment with dialysis or a kidney transplant
Fluid retention in your legs, causing swollen ankles or feet
Shortness of breath due to a sudden buildup of fluid in the lungs
diagnosis: A physical exam that includes your provider listening through a stethoscope over the kidney areas for sounds that may mean the artery to your kidney is narrowed
A review of your medical history
Blood and urine tests to check your kidney function
Blood and urine tests to measure the levels of hormones that regulate blood pressure

name: Avascular necrosis
description: A broken bone or dislocated joint can block blood flow to the bone, causing bone tissue to die.

name: Ehrlichiosis and anaplasmosis
description: Learn how to prevent and treat the tick-borne diseases ehrlichiosis and anaplasmosis.
risks: Being outdoors in warm spring and summer months
Participating in activities in wooded areas, such as camping, hiking or hunting
Wearing clothes that leave your skin exposed in tick-friendly habitat
complications: Damage to the central nervous system
diagnosis: Low count of white blood cells, which are disease-fighting cells of the immune system
