description: Learn what doctors and dentists look for when diagnosing mouth cancer. Find out about oral cancer treatments, including surgery, chemotherapy and radiation.
symptoms: A lip or mouth sore that doesn't heal
A white or reddish patch on the inside of your mouth
A growth or lump inside your mouth
risks: Tobacco use of any kind, including cigarettes, cigars, pipes, chewing tobacco and snuff, among others
Excessive sun exposure to your lips
A sexually transmitted virus called human papillomavirus (HPV)
preventions: Stop using tobacco or dont start
Drink alcohol only in moderation if at all
Avoid excessive sun exposure to your lips

name: Giardia infection
description: Stomach cramps, nausea and watery diarrhea could indicate a giardia infection. Find out how to treat and prevent this waterborne parasite.
symptoms: Watery, sometimes foul-smelling diarrhea that may alternate with soft, greasy stools
risks: People without access to safe drinking water

name: Ovarian cancer
description: Learn more about cancer of the ovaries, including symptoms and treatments, such as surgery, chemotherapy and targeted therapy.
risks: Age when menstruation started and ended
preventions: Discuss your risk factors with your doctor

name: Gilbert's syndrome
description: This inherited liver condition affects the liver's ability to break down red blood cells. It usually has no serious medical consequences.
symptoms: Illness, such as a cold or the flu
Fasting or eating a very low-calorie diet
risks: Both your parents carry the modified gene that causes the disorder
complications: Some protease inhibitors used to treat HIV

name: Pancreatic cancer
description: Pancreatic cancer — Overview covers symptoms, risk factors, prevention, diagnosis, surgery, chemotherapy and other treatment for cancer of the pancreas.
symptoms: Abdominal pain that radiates to your back
Loss of appetite or unintended weight loss
Yellowing of your skin and the whites of your eyes (jaundice)
New diagnosis of diabetes or existing diabetes that's becoming more difficult to control
risks: Family history of genetic syndromes that can increase cancer risk, including a BRCA2 gene mutation, Lynch syndrome and familial atypical mole-malignant melanoma (FAMMM) syndrome
Older age, as most people are diagnosed after age 65

name: Gingivitis
description: Gingivitis is a common and mild form of gum disease that causes irritation, redness and swelling of your gums.
risks: Poor nutrition, including vitamin C deficiency
Dental restorations that don't fit properly or crooked teeth that are difficult to clean
Conditions that decrease immunity such as leukemia, HIV/AIDS or cancer treatment
Certain drugs, such as phenytoin (Dilantin, Phenytek) for epileptic seizures, and some calcium channel blockers, used for angina, high blood pressure and other conditions
Hormonal changes, such as those related to pregnancy, menstrual cycle or use of birth control pills
Medical conditions such as certain viral and fungal infections
diagnosis: Review of your dental and medical history
Examination of your teeth gums mouth and tongue

name: Phobias
description: Specific phobias are an overwhelming and unreasonable fear of objects or situations that pose little real danger but provoke anxiety and avoidance.
symptoms: Situations, such as airplanes, enclosed spaces or going to school
Nature, such as thunderstorms or heights
Animals or insects, such as dogs or spiders
Blood, injection or injury, such as needles, accidents or medical procedures
Others, such as choking, vomiting, loud noises or clowns

name: Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis
description: Learn about symptoms, risk factors and possible treatments for this rare disorder in people with advanced kidney disease.
symptoms: Swelling and tightening of the skin
Reddened or darkened patches on the skin
Thickening and hardening of the skin, typically on the arms and legs and sometimes on the body, but almost never on the face or head
Skin that may feel "woody" and develop an orange-peel appearance
Burning, itching or severe sharp pains in areas of involvement
Skin thickening that inhibits movement, resulting in loss of joint flexibility
causes: Use of high-dose erythropoietin (EPO), a hormone that promotes the production of red blood cells, often used to treat anemia
risks: Have moderate to severe kidney disease
Have had a kidney transplant but have compromised renal function
Are receiving hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis

name: Paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system
description: This group of uncommon disorders affects people who have cancer, and occurs when parts of the immune system attack parts of the nervous system.
symptoms: Loss of muscle tone or weakness
Loss of fine motor skills, such as picking up objects
Memory loss and other thinking (cognitive) impairment

name: Dyslexia
description: This learning disorder involves difficulty reading due to problems identifying speech sounds and learning how they relate to letters and words.
diagnosis: Your childs development educational issues and medical history
Vision hearing and brain neurological tests
Tests for reading and other academic skills

name: Prostate cancer
description: Learn about detection, diagnostic approaches, treatment options and advances for prostate cancer, including robotic prostatectomy and current research.
symptoms: Decreased force in the stream of urine
preventions: Choose a healthy diet full of fruits and vegetables
Exercise most days of the week
Talk to your doctor about increased risk of prostate cancer

name: Spermatocele
description: Learn more about this noncancerous testicular disorder that may require surgery if it's causing discomfort. But, the condition often needs no treatment.
symptoms: Pain or discomfort in the affected testicle
Heaviness in the testicle with the spermatocele
Fullness behind and above the testicle

name: Glaucoma
description: Regular eye exams may catch glaucoma early and save your eyesight. Find out about symptoms and treatment for this vision-stealing eye disease.
risks: High internal eye pressure, also known as intraocular pressure
Certain medical conditions, such as diabetes, migraines, high blood pressure and sickle cell anemia
Corneas that are thin in the center
Eye injury or certain types of eye surgery
Taking corticosteroid medicines, especially eye drops, for a long time
preventions: Know your familys eye health history
diagnosis: Measuring intraocular pressure, also called tonometry
Testing for optic nerve damage with a dilated eye examination and imaging tests
Checking for areas of vision loss, also known as a visual field test
Measuring corneal thickness with an exam called pachymetry
Inspecting the drainage angle, also known as gonioscopy

name: Nephrotic syndrome
description: Swelling around your feet and ankles is a common sign of this condition that occurs when your kidneys pass too much protein in your urine.
symptoms: Severe swelling (edema), particularly around your eyes and in your ankles and feet
Foamy urine, a result of excess protein in your urine
Weight gain due to fluid retention
risks: Medical conditions that can damage your kidneys
complications: High blood cholesterol and elevated blood triglycerides

name: Rectal cancer
description: Find out about rectal cancer symptoms, causes and prevention. Learn about treatments, including chemotherapy, radiation and surgery.
symptoms: A change in bowel habits, such as diarrhea, constipation or more-frequent bowel movements
Dark maroon or bright red blood in stool
A feeling that your bowel doesn't empty completely
risks: A personal history of colorectal cancer or polyps
Inherited syndromes that increase rectal cancer risk
Eating a diet low in vegetables
preventions: Talk to your doctor about cancer screening
Exercise most days of the week
Eat a variety of fruits vegetables and whole grains
Drink alcohol in moderation if at all

name: Glioblastoma
description: Glioblastoma — Overview covers diagnosis and treatment for this aggressive form of brain cancer that can be slowed, but often can't be cured.
treatment: Steroid medicines to reduce brain swelling.
Medicine to improves alertness if you have severe fatigue.
Medicine to help with thinking and memory problems.

name: Postherpetic neuralgia
description: This complication of shingles can cause pain, itching and numbness long after the shingles rash clears. Treatments can ease symptoms.
symptoms: Pain that lasts three months or longer
Not being able to stand light touch
risks: How bad the case of shingles was
complications: Not feeling as hungry as usual.

name: Retinoblastoma
description: Learn about the symptoms, causes and treatments for this eye cancer that occurs in young children.
symptoms: A white color in the center circle of the eye (pupil) when light is shone in the eye, such as when someone takes a flash photograph of the child
Eyes that appear to be looking in different directions
preventions: Your child with retinoblastoma is at risk of other related cancers.
Your child with retinoblastoma may carry a gene mutation that can be passed to his or her future children.
Your other children are at risk of retinoblastoma and other related cancers.
You and your partner have the possibility of passing the genetic mutation on to future children.

name: Glioma
description: Gliomas are the most common brain tumors in adults. Learn more about diagnosis and treatment, including innovative research to find new therapies.
symptoms: Headache, particularly one that hurts the most in the morning.
Confusion or a decline in brain function, such as problems with thinking and understanding information.
Vision problems, such as blurred vision, double vision or loss of peripheral vision.
Seizures, especially in someone who hasn't had seizures before.
risks: Having a family history of glioma
treatment: Steroid medicines to reduce brain swelling.
Medicine to improves alertness if you have severe fatigue.
Medicine to help with thinking and memory problems.

name: Skin cancer
description: Learn about skin cancer, including basal cell carcinoma, melanoma and squamous cell carcinoma. Find out about symptoms, treatments and ways to lower your risk.
risks: A family history of skin cancer
A personal history of skin cancer
preventions: Avoid the sun during the middle of the day
Check your skin regularly and report changes to your doctor
diagnosis: Remove a sample of suspicious skin for testing skin biopsy

name: Trigeminal neuralgia
description: Learn about this painful nerve condition that can jolt areas on the face with electric-shock-like pain.

name: Neuroblastoma
description: Learn more about the symptoms, diagnosis and treatment of neuroblastoma, one of the most common cancers of childhood.
symptoms: A mass under the skin that isn't tender when touched
Changes in bowel habits, such as diarrhea or constipation
complications: Signs and symptoms caused by tumor secretions
diagnosis: Removing a sample of tissue for testing
Removing a sample of bone marrow for testing

name: Soft tissue sarcoma
description: This rare type of cancer can begin in the muscles, fat, blood vessels, nerves, tendons and the lining of joints. Treatment usually includes surgery.
symptoms: Pain, if a tumor presses on nerves or muscles

name: Glomerulonephritis
description: Learn about symptoms, causes and treatments for acute and chronic glomerulonephritis, a type of kidney inflammation.
symptoms: Pink or cola-colored urine from red blood cells in your urine (hematuria)
Foamy or bubbly urine due to excess protein in the urine (proteinuria)
Fluid retention (edema) with swelling evident in your face, hands, feet and abdomen
complications: Accumulation of wastes or toxins in the bloodstream
Poor regulation of essential minerals and nutrients
preventions: Seek prompt treatment of a strep infection with a sore throat or impetigo.
To prevent infections that can lead to some forms of glomerulonephritis, such as HIV and hepatitis, follow safe-sex guidelines and avoid intravenous drug use.
Control high blood pressure, which lessens the likelihood of damage to your kidneys from hypertension.
Control your blood sugar to help prevent diabetic nephropathy.
treatment: Whether you have an acute or chronic form of the disease
The type and severity of your signs and symptoms

name: Spider bites
description: Learn more about prevention, symptoms, complications and treatment of spider bites, which are usually harmless.
preventions: Learn what dangerous spiders look like and their preferred habitats.
Wear a long-sleeved shirt, hat, long pants tucked into socks, gloves and boots when handling stored boxes or firewood and when cleaning out sheds, garages, basements, attics and crawl spaces.
Inspect and shake out gardening gloves, boots and clothing before use.
Use insect repellents, such as DEET. Carefully follow directions on the package.
Keep insects and spiders out of the house by installing tightfitting screens on windows and doors, sealing cracks where spiders can come in, and using safe indoor insecticides.
Reduce debris or remove piles of rocks or lumber from the area around your home and avoid storing firewood against the walls of your home.
Make sure beds aren't pushed against the wall and that only the legs of the bed touch the floor. Don't store items under the bed and don't let bedding drag on the floor.
Remove spiders and spiderwebs from your home.
If a spider is on your skin, flick it off with your finger rather than crushing it against your skin.
When cleaning tarantula enclosures, wear gloves, a surgical mask and eye protection.
treatment: Clean the wound with mild soap and water. Apply an antibiotic ointment three times a day to help prevent infection.
Apply a cool compress over the bite for 15 minutes each hour. Use a clean cloth dampened with water or filled with ice. This helps reduce pain and swelling.
If possible, elevate the affected area.
Take an over-the-counter pain reliever as needed.
If the affected area is itchy, an antihistamine, such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl) or certirizine (Zyrtec), might help.
Observe the bite for signs of worsening or infection. You might need antibiotics if the bite develops into an open wound or becomes infected.

name: Vasovagal syncope
description: Learn about what causes a brief loss of consciousness and when to see a doctor if this happens to you.
symptoms: Tunnel vision — your field of vision narrows so that you see only what's in front of you
causes: Standing for long periods of time
Straining, such as to have a bowel movement

name: Burning mouth syndrome
description: This chronic burning, without an obvious cause, may affect the tongue, gums, lips, cheeks, roof of your mouth or widespread areas of your mouth.
symptoms: A burning or scalding sensation that most commonly affects your tongue, but may also affect your lips, gums, palate, throat or whole mouth
A sensation of dry mouth with increased thirst
Taste changes in your mouth, such as a bitter or metallic taste
Tingling, stinging or numbness in your mouth
diagnosis: Review your medical history and medications
Ask you to describe your symptoms, oral habits and oral care routine

name: Spina bifida
description: Fetal surgery during pregnancy may improve outcomes for babies with myelomeningocele, a severe form of spina bifida. Learn the latest treatment options.
symptoms: The spinal canal remains open along several vertebrae in the lower or middle back
Both the membranes and the spinal cord or nerves protrude at birth, forming a sac
Tissues and nerves usually are exposed, though sometimes skin covers the sac
risks: Family history of neural tube defects
complications: The size and location of the neural tube defect
Whether skin covers the affected area
Which spinal nerves come out of the affected area of the spinal cord
treatment: Bowel management may include oral medications, suppositories, enemas, surgery or a combination of these approaches.
Bladder management may include medications, using catheters to empty the bladder, surgery or a combination of treatments.
Treatment and management of other complications

name: Neurodermatitis
description: Learn about this itchy skin condition that can disrupt your sleep and daily activities. Treatment focuses on controlling itching and preventing scratching.
symptoms: An itchy, scaly skin patch or patches
Raised, rough patches that are inflamed or darker than the rest of the skin

name: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
description: Squamous cell carcinoma is a common skin cancer that usually looks like a red bump or a scaly sore. Learn about symptoms and explore treatment options.
symptoms: A flat sore with a scaly crust
A new sore or raised area on an old scar or ulcer
A rough, scaly patch on your lip that may evolve to an open sore
A red sore or rough patch inside your mouth
A red, raised patch or wartlike sore on or in the anus or on your genitals
risks: A personal history of precancerous skin lesions
A personal history of skin cancer
complications: Involves the mucous membranes, such as the lips
Occurs in a person with a weakened immune system, such as someone who takes anti-rejection medications after an organ transplant or someone who has chronic leukemia
preventions: Avoid the sun during the middle of the day
Check your skin regularly and report changes to your doctor
diagnosis: Removing a sample of tissue for testing

name: Merkel cell carcinoma
description: Learn about this aggressive skin cancer. Find out about symptoms, diagnosis and treatments, including Mohs surgery, radiation and immunotherapy.
risks: Excessive exposure to natural or artificial sunlight
preventions: Avoid the sun during peak hours
diagnosis: Removing a sample of suspicious skin

name: Gaucher disease
description: An enzyme that breaks down certain fatty substances doesn't work properly in people with Gaucher disease. Enzyme replacement therapy often helps.
complications: Delays in growth and puberty in children
Cancers such as myeloma, leukemia and lymphoma

name: Stomach cancer
description: Stomach cancer, which is also called gastric cancer, is cancer that begins in the stomach. Learn about symptoms, causes, detection and treatments.
symptoms: Feeling full after eating small amounts of food
Not feeling hungry when you would expect to be hungry
risks: Ongoing problems with stomach acid backing up into the esophagus, which is called gastroesophageal reflux disease
A diet high in salty and smoked foods
A diet low in fruits and vegetables
Infection in the stomach caused by a germ called Helicobacter pylori
Swelling and irritation of the inside of the stomach, which is called gastritis
Growths of noncancerous cells in the stomach, called polyps

Family history of genetic syndromes that increase the risk of stomach cancer and other cancers, such as hereditary diffuse gastric cancer, Lynch syndrome, juvenile polyposis syndrome, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and familial adenomatous polyposis
preventions: Eat plenty of fruits and vegetables
Reduce the amount of salty and smoked foods you eat
Tell your health care provider if stomach cancer runs in your family

name: Neuroendocrine tumor
description: Learn about the types of tumors that make up this group of rare cancers. Find out about symptoms, causes, diagnosis and treatments.
symptoms: A growing lump you can feel under the skin
diagnosis: Tests to look for excess hormones
Procedures to remove a sample of cells for testing biopsy

name: Celiac disease
description: In celiac disease, wheat protein (gluten) in food damages the small intestine, making it hard to absorb nutrients and causing a variety of symptoms.
risks: A family member with celiac disease or dermatitis herpetiformis

name: Spinal arteriovenous malformation
description: Find out how this rare blood vessel disorder can damage the spinal cord.
symptoms: Problems with walking or climbing stairs
Numbness, tingling or sudden pain in the legs
Weakness on one or both sides of the body
complications: High blood pressure in the veins (venous hypertension), which can cause fluid accumulation (edema) and tissue death due to lack of oxygen (spinal cord infarction)
Hemorrhage, which can speed up spinal cord damage

name: Neurofibroma
description: Learn about this type of peripheral nerve tumor that can appear anywhere in the body, forming soft bumps on or under the skin.

name: Goiter
description: Enlargement of the thyroid gland may be caused by autoimmune disorders, an iodine-poor diet, pregnancy-related hormones and other factors.
diagnosis: Measure the size of the thyroid
Assess whether the thyroid may be overactive or underactive
Determine the cause of the goiter

name: Spinal cord injury
description: Learn more about what happens after your spinal cord has been damaged.
risks: Being between the ages of 16 and 30

name: Testicular cancer
description: Learn about cancer that starts in the testicles. Treatments include surgery, chemotherapy and radiation therapy.
risks: Having an undescended testicle which is called cryptorchidism
Having a family history of testicular cancer

name: Golfer's elbow
description: Golfers, tennis players and others who repeatedly use their wrists or clench their fingers can develop this painful condition.
risks: Performing repetitive activity at least two hours a day

name: Spinal cord tumor
description: Spinal cord tumors can cause serious problems such as pain and paralysis. Find out how more about management and treatment.
symptoms: Pain at the site of the tumor due to tumor growth
Back pain, often radiating to other parts of your body
Feeling less sensitive to pain, heat and cold
Loss of bowel or bladder function
Difficulty walking, sometimes leading to falls
Back pain that's worse at night
Loss of sensation or muscle weakness, especially in your arms or legs
Muscle weakness , which may be mild or severe, in different parts of your body

name: Gonorrhea
description: This common sexually transmitted infection often causes no signs or symptoms. Learn more about treatment, prevention and possible complications.
risks: Having a sex partner who has other partners
Having more than one sex partner
Having had gonorrhea or another sexually transmitted infection
complications: Infection that spreads to the joints and other areas of your body
preventions: Use a condom if you have sex
Limit your number of sex partners
Be sure you and your partner are tested for sexually transmitted infections
Dont have sex with someone who appears to have a sexually transmitted infection

name: Neurofibromatosis
description: This genetic disorder causes tumors on nerve tissue, but surgery and other therapies can manage pain and other symptoms.

name: Scoliosis
description: This sideways curvature of the spine occurs most often during the growth spurt just before puberty. Treatment may include braces or surgery.
symptoms: One shoulder blade that appears more prominent than the other
One hip higher than the other
One side of the rib cage jutting forward
A prominence on one side of the back when bending forward
causes: Certain neuromuscular conditions, such as cerebral palsy or muscular dystrophy
Birth defects affecting the development of the bones of the spine
Previous surgery on the chest wall as a baby
Injuries to or infections of the spine

name: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors
description: MPNSTs are cancers that form in the linings of nerves. Treatment includes surgery, radiation therapy and, sometimes, chemotherapy.
symptoms: Weakness when trying to move the affected body part
A growing lump of tissue under the skin
risks: An inherited condition that increases risk of nerve tumors
diagnosis: Removing a sample of tissue for testing biopsy

name: Gout
description: This type of arthritis can cause sudden, severe attacks of pain, swelling, redness and tenderness — often in the big toe.
treatment: Medications that block uric acid production
Medications that improve uric acid removal

name: Acoustic neuroma
description: Acoustic neuroma is a tumor that grows on the balance and hearing nerve in the head that may cause hearing loss.
symptoms: Hearing loss, usually gradually worsening over months to years — although in rare cases sudden — and occurring on only one side or more severe on one side
Facial numbness and weakness or loss of muscle movement

name: Spinal headache
description: These headaches can happen after a spinal tap procedure or spinal anesthesia, and usually don’t require treatment.
symptoms: Dull, throbbing pain that varies in intensity from mild to very severe
Pain that typically gets worse when you sit up or stand and decreases or goes away when you lie down
risks: Being between the ages of 18 and 30
Having a history of frequent headaches
Undergoing procedures involving the use of larger needles or multiple punctures in the membrane that surrounds the spinal cord

name: Grand mal seizure
description: Learn all about grand mal seizures — the type of seizure that can cause convulsions — and how to help if you see someone having one.
risks: A family history of seizure disorders
Any injury to the brain from trauma, a stroke, previous infection and other causes
Medical problems that affect electrolyte balance

name: Morton's neuroma
description: Learn how this painful foot disorder is diagnosed, as well as its causes and treatment.
symptoms: A feeling as if you're standing on a pebble in your shoe
A burning pain in the ball of your foot that may radiate into your toes
Tingling or numbness in your toes

name: Throat cancer
description: Learn more about this type of cancer that affects your throat (pharynx), voice box (larynx) or tonsils.
symptoms: Changes in your voice, such as hoarseness or not speaking clearly
A lump or sore that doesn't heal
preventions: Stop smoking or dont start smoking
Drink alcohol only in moderation if at all
Choose a healthy diet full of fruits and vegetables
diagnosis: Using a scope to get a closer look at your throat
Removing a tissue sample for testing

name: Morton's neuroma
description: Learn how this painful foot disorder is diagnosed, as well as its causes and treatment.
symptoms: A feeling as if you're standing on a pebble in your shoe
A burning pain in the ball of your foot that may radiate into your toes
Tingling or numbness in your toes

name: Granuloma annulare
description: Learn about this painless skin condition mainly affecting young adults in which bumps form a ring. The rash can be long lasting or recur after treatment.

name: Neuromyelitis optica
description: Understand more about this condition that affects the spinal cord and eye nerves and is sometimes mistaken for multiple sclerosis.

name: Thyroid cancer
description: Learn about thyroid cancer diagnosis and treatment, including thyroid surgery, radioactive iodine and thyroid hormone therapy.
treatment: Destroying cancer cells with heat and cold

name: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
description: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis causes inflammation in the blood vessels in your nose, sinuses, throat, lungs and kidneys. Prompt treatment is vital.
symptoms: Pus-like drainage with crusts from your nose, stuffiness, sinus infections and nosebleeds
Numbness in your limbs, fingers or toes
Eye redness, burning or pain, and vision problems
complications: A loss of height in the bridge of the nose (saddling) caused by weakened cartilage
A blood clot forming in one or more deep veins, usually in your leg

name: Neuromyelitis optica
description: Understand more about this condition that affects the spinal cord and eye nerves and is sometimes mistaken for multiple sclerosis.

name: Endometrial cancer
description: Learn about the symptoms and causes of this cancer of the uterus. Treatments include hysterectomy, radiation therapy, chemotherapy and other drug treatments.
preventions: Talk to your doctor about the risks of hormone therapy after menopause

name: Spinal stenosis
description: This condition narrows the amount of space within the spine. This can squeeze the nerves that travel through the spine. Surgery is sometimes needed.

name: Autonomic neuropathy
description: Damage to the nerves that control involuntary body functions, such as blood pressure and digestion, results in autonomic neuropathy.
preventions: Control your blood sugar if you have diabetes.
Get appropriate treatment if you have an autoimmune disease.
Take steps to prevent or control high blood pressure.
Achieve and maintain a healthy weight.

name: Vaginal cancer
description: Learn about vaginal cancer symptoms and diagnosis. Treatments for cancer of the vagina include surgery, radiation therapy and chemotherapy.
risks: Atypical cells in the vagina called vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia
preventions: Undergo regular pelvic exams and Pap tests
Ask your doctor about the HPV vaccine

name: Enlarged spleen
description: Learn about what your spleen does and what can happen if it becomes enlarged.
symptoms: Pain or fullness in the left upper belly that can spread to the left shoulder
A feeling of fullness without eating or after eating a small amount because the spleen is pressing on your stomach
causes: Bacterial infections, such as syphilis or an infection of your heart's inner lining (endocarditis)
Cirrhosis and other diseases affecting the liver
Various types of hemolytic anemia — a condition characterized by early destruction of red blood cells
Blood cancers, such as leukemia and myeloproliferative neoplasms, and lymphomas, such as Hodgkin's disease
Metabolic disorders, such as Gaucher disease and Niemann-Pick disease
Pressure on the veins in the spleen or liver or a blood clot in these veins
Autoimmune conditions, such as lupus or sarcoidosis
risks: Children and young adults with infections, such as mononucleosis
People who have Gaucher disease, Niemann-Pick disease, and several other inherited metabolic disorders affecting the liver and spleen
People who live in or travel to areas where malaria is common

name: Diabetic neuropathy
description: High blood sugar can lead to nerve damage in feet and other areas of the body. Know the signs and how to take steps to prevent this diabetes complication.
complications: Loss of a toe foot or leg
Urinary tract infections and urinary incontinence
diagnosis: Sensitivity to touch, pain, temperature and vibration

name: Vulvar cancer
description: Learn about this rare cancer that forms on the skin that surrounds the urethra and vagina. Treatments include surgery, radiation and chemotherapy.
symptoms: Skin changes, such as color changes or thickening
A lump, wartlike bumps or an open sore (ulcer)
risks: Being exposed to human papillomavirus HPV
Having a history of precancerous conditions of the vulva
Having a skin condition involving the vulva

name: Cervical spondylosis
description: As people age, the spinal disks in the neck shrink and bone spurs often develop. If symptoms occur, nonsurgical treatments are usually effective.
symptoms: Tingling, numbness and weakness in the arms, hands, legs or feet
Lack of coordination and difficulty walking
Loss of bladder or bowel control
diagnosis: Checking the range of motion in your neck
Testing your reflexes and muscle strength to find out if there's pressure on your spinal nerves or spinal cord
Watching you walk to see if spinal compression is affecting your gait

name: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease
description: Learn how to spot the symptoms and how doctors treat this group of peripheral nerve disorders.
symptoms: Weakness in your legs, ankles and feet
Loss of muscle bulk in your legs and feet
Difficulty lifting your foot at the ankle (footdrop)
Awkward or higher than normal step (gait)
Decreased sensation or a loss of feeling in your legs and feet
diagnosis: Signs of muscle weakness in your arms, legs, hands and feet
Decreased muscle bulk in your lower legs, resulting in an inverted champagne bottle appearance
Sensory loss in your feet and hands
Foot deformities, such as high arches or hammertoes
Other orthopedic problems, such as mild scoliosis or hip dysplasia

name: Wilms' tumor
description: Advancements in the diagnosis and treatment of Wilms' tumor have greatly improved the outlook (prognosis) for children with this type of kidney cancer.
symptoms: An abdominal mass you can feel

name: Spontaneous coronary artery dissection
description: A torn blood vessel in the heart can cause a heart attack. Learn about the diagnosis and treatment of this medical emergency.
symptoms: A rapid heartbeat or fluttery feeling in the chest
Pain in the arms, shoulders, back or jaw

name: Graves' disease
description: Learn about the symptoms, causes and treatment of this immune system disorder that results in the overproduction of thyroid hormones (hyperthyroidism).

name: Peripheral neuropathy
description: Learn what may cause the prickling, tingling or numb sensations of nerve damage and how to prevent and treat this painful disorder.
symptoms: Sensory nerves that receive sensation, such as temperature, pain, vibration or touch, from the skin
Motor nerves that control muscle movement
Autonomic nerves that control functions such as blood pressure, perspiration, heart rate, digestion and bladder function
risks: Diabetes, especially if your sugar levels are poorly controlled
Infections, such as Lyme disease, shingles, Epstein-Barr virus, hepatitis B and C, and HIV
Autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus, in which your immune system attacks your own tissues
Repetitive motion, such as those performed for certain jobs

name: Sprained ankle
description: Sprained ankle — Injury to a ligament of the ankle can usually be treated with at-home care and appropriate exercises to get you back on your feet.
symptoms: Pain, especially when you bear weight on the affected foot
Tenderness when you touch the ankle
Popping sensation or sound at the time of injury
preventions: Warm up before you exercise or play sports.
Be careful when walking, running or working on an uneven surface.
Use an ankle support brace or tape on a weak or previously injured ankle.
Wear shoes that fit well and are made for your activity.
Don't play sports or participate in activities for which you are not conditioned.
Maintain good muscle strength and flexibility.
Practice stability training, including balance exercises.

name: Greenstick fractures
description: Greenstick fractures — Comprehensive overview covers symptoms, diagnosis and treatment of this childhood bone injury.

name: Mole
description: Learn about moles (nevi), what causes them, whether they put you at increased risk of skin cancer and how to check a mole for signs of skin cancer.
complications: Having a personal or family history of melanoma

name: Complicated grief
description: In complicated grief, painful emotions of loss don't improve with time and are so severe that you have trouble recovering and resuming your own life.
symptoms: Intense sorrow, pain and rumination over the loss of your loved one
Focus on little else but your loved one's death
Extreme focus on reminders of the loved one or excessive avoidance of reminders
Intense and persistent longing or pining for the deceased
Feeling that life holds no meaning or purpose
Inability to enjoy life or think back on positive experiences with your loved one
risks: An unexpected or violent death, such as death from a car accident, or the murder or suicide of a loved one
Close or dependent relationship to the deceased person
Social isolation or loss of a support system or friendships
Past history of depression, separation anxiety or post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)
Traumatic childhood experiences, such as abuse or neglect
Other major life stressors, such as major financial hardships
complications: Increased risk of physical illness, such as heart disease, cancer or high blood pressure
Long-term difficulty with daily living, relationships or work activities
Alcohol, nicotine use or substance misuse

name: Nickel allergy
description: Nickel allergy, often caused by nickel in jewelry, is a form of contact dermatitis. Things such as coins and zippers also may provoke nickel allergy.
symptoms: Rash or bumps on the skin
Redness or changes in skin color
Dry patches of skin that may resemble a burn
Blisters and draining fluid in severe cases
risks: Having a family history of nickel allergy

name: Blood in urine
description: Lots of things can cause bloody urine. Some are serious problems, and others are harmless. Find out why it's always important to get a checkup.
treatment: Taking antibiotic medicines to clear a urinary tract infection.
Trying a prescription medicine to shrink an enlarged prostate.
Having a treatment that uses sound waves to break up bladder or kidney stones.

name: Nicotine dependence
description: Nicotine dependence can be tough to kick, but treatments and resources are available to boost your chances of success.
symptoms: You have withdrawal symptoms when you try to stop
You keep smoking despite health problems

name: Nicotine dependence
description: Nicotine dependence can be tough to kick, but treatments and resources are available to boost your chances of success.
symptoms: You have withdrawal symptoms when you try to stop
You keep smoking despite health problems

name: Oral thrush
description: Oral thrush is a fungal infection caused by the overgrowth of Candida albicans, which causes creamy white lesions on the tongue and lining of your mouth.
preventions: Brush your teeth at least twice a day and floss daily
Maintain good blood sugar control if you have diabetes

name: Sprain
description: A sprain is a stretching or tearing of ligaments — the tough bands of tissue that connect two bones together in your joints. Ice and elevation can help.
causes: Ankle — Walking or exercising on an uneven surface, landing awkwardly from a jump
Knee — Pivoting during an athletic activity
Wrist — Landing on an outstretched hand during a fall
Thumb — Skiing injury or overextension when playing racquet sports, such as tennis

name: Group B strep infection
description: This common bacterium, usually harmless in healthy adults, can cause serious illness in newborns and adults with certain chronic conditions, such as diabetes.
complications: Inflammation of the membranes and fluid surrounding the brain and spinal cord (meningitis)
preventions: Delivered a previous baby with group B strep disease
Haven't delivered your baby within 18 hours of your water breaking
Go into labor before 37 weeks and haven't been tested for group B strep

name: Vaginal yeast infection
description: Vaginal itching or burning could mean you have a yeast infection. Learn about other symptoms and effective treatments for this uncomfortable condition.
symptoms: Itching and irritation in the vagina and vulva
A burning sensation, especially during intercourse or while urinating
Redness and swelling of the vulva
Thick, white, odor-free vaginal discharge with a cottage cheese appearance
causes: Antibiotic use, which causes an imbalance in natural vaginal flora
Taking oral contraceptives or hormone therapy that increase estrogen levels
preventions: Douching, which removes some of the normal bacteria in the vagina that protect you from infection
Scented feminine products, including bubble bath, pads and tampons
Hot tubs and very hot baths
Unnecessary antibiotic use, such as for colds or other viral infections
Staying in wet clothes, such as swimsuits and workout attire, for long periods of time
diagnosis: Ask questions about your medical history

name: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
description: Squamous cell carcinoma is a common skin cancer that usually looks like a red bump or a scaly sore. Learn about symptoms and explore treatment options.
symptoms: A flat sore with a scaly crust
A new sore or raised area on an old scar or ulcer
A rough, scaly patch on your lip that may evolve to an open sore
A red sore or rough patch inside your mouth
A red, raised patch or wartlike sore on or in the anus or on your genitals
risks: A personal history of precancerous skin lesions
A personal history of skin cancer
complications: Involves the mucous membranes, such as the lips
Occurs in a person with a weakened immune system, such as someone who takes anti-rejection medications after an organ transplant or someone who has chronic leukemia
preventions: Avoid the sun during the middle of the day
Check your skin regularly and report changes to your doctor
diagnosis: Removing a sample of tissue for testing

name: Canker sores
description: Canker sore — Learn about the causes, treatment and prevention of this painful mouth sore.
causes: A minor injury to your mouth from dental work, overzealous brushing, sports mishaps or an accidental cheek bite
Toothpastes and mouth rinses containing sodium lauryl sulfate
Food sensitivities, particularly to chocolate, coffee, strawberries, eggs, nuts, cheese, and spicy or acidic foods
A diet lacking in vitamin B-12, zinc, folate (folic acid) or iron
An allergic response to certain bacteria in your mouth
Helicobacter pylori, the same bacteria that cause peptic ulcers

name: Growing pains
description: Learn about this common condition involving leg pain in children, including growing pain symptoms and how to ease discomfort.

name: Niemann-Pick disease
description: Niemann-Pick — Learn more about this inherited disease that mainly affects children, causing malfunction of the nerves, brain and other organs.
symptoms: Excessive muscle contractions (dystonia) or eye movements

name: Acromegaly
description: An excess of growth hormone causes the bones to keep growing, which can lead to a number of serious complications if left untreated.
symptoms: Enlarged facial features, including the facial bones, lips, nose and tongue
Small outgrowths of skin tissue (skin tags)
Fatigue and joint or muscle weakness
A deepened, husky voice due to enlarged vocal cords and sinuses
Severe snoring due to obstruction of the upper airway
Headaches, which may be persistent or severe
complications: Heart problems, particularly enlargement of the heart (cardiomyopathy)
Precancerous growths (polyps) on the lining of your colon
Sleep apnea, a condition in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep
treatment: Drugs that reduce growth hormone production somatostatin analogues
Drugs to lower hormone levels dopamine agonists
Drug to block the action of GH growth hormone antagonist

name: Carbon monoxide poisoning
description: Carbon monoxide is colorless, odorless, tasteless — and extremely dangerous. Don't count on detecting it. Instead, prevent it.
risks: People who have chronic heart disease
Those in whom carbon monoxide poisoning leads to unconsciousness
complications: Damage to your heart, possibly leading to life-threatening cardiac complications
preventions: Open the garage door before starting your car
Keep your fuelburning appliances and engines properly vented
If you have a fireplace keep it in good repair
Keep vents and chimneys unblocked during remodeling
Make repairs before returning to the site of an incident
Use caution when working with solvents in a closed area

name: Growth plate fracture
description: Growth plate fractures — This common childhood bone injury often needs immediate treatment as it can result in a shorter, longer or crooked limb.
symptoms: Pain and tenderness, particularly in response to pressure on the growth plate
Inability to move the affected area or to put weight or pressure on the limb
Warmth and swelling at the end of a bone, near a joint
causes: Competitive sports, such as football, basketball, running, dancing or gymnastics
Recreational activities, such as biking, sledding, skiing or skateboarding

name: Boils and carbuncles
description: Learn about symptoms, causes, treatment and prevention of these painful pus-filled infections that cause bumps under your skin or leaking sores.
risks: Close contact with a person who has a staph infection
preventions: Wash your hands regularly with mild soap

name: Guillain Barre syndrome
description: This rare autoimmune disorder affects the nerves, causing weakness and tingling in the arms and legs that rapidly spreads throughout the body.
symptoms: A pins and needles sensation in your fingers, toes, ankles or wrists
Weakness in your legs that spreads to your upper body
Unsteady walking or inability to walk or climb stairs
Difficulty with facial movements, including speaking, chewing or swallowing
Double vision or inability to move the eyes
Severe pain that may feel achy, shooting or cramplike and may be worse at night
Difficulty with bladder control or bowel function
risks: Most commonly, infection with campylobacter, a type of bacteria often found in undercooked poultry
Hepatitis A, B, C and E
HIV, the virus that causes AIDS
Rarely, influenza vaccinations or childhood vaccinations
COVID-19 Johnson & Johnson and AstraZeneca vaccine

name: Nightmare disorder
description: Nightmare disorder involves disturbing or scary dreams that awaken you, causing distress or preventing adequate sleep.
symptoms: Your dream seems vivid and real and is very upsetting, often becoming more disturbing as the dream unfolds.
Your dream storyline is usually related to threats to safety or survival, but it can have other disturbing themes.
You feel scared, anxious, angry, sad or disgusted as a result of your dream.
You feel sweaty or have a pounding heartbeat while in bed.
You can think clearly upon awakening and can recall details of your dream.
Your dream causes distress that keeps you from falling back to sleep easily.
complications: Excessive daytime sleepiness, which can lead to difficulties at school or work, or problems with everyday tasks, such as driving and concentrating
Problems with mood, such as depression or anxiety from dreams that continue to bother you
Resistance to going to bed or to sleep for fear you'll have another bad dream

name: Stage 4 prostate cancer
description: Find out how doctors diagnose and treat advanced prostate cancer that has spread to the lymph nodes or other parts of the body.
symptoms: Decreased force in the stream of urine
risks: A family history of prostate cancer
treatment: Training your immune system to recognize cancer cells

name: Gingivitis
description: Gingivitis is a common and mild form of gum disease that causes irritation, redness and swelling of your gums.
risks: Poor nutrition, including vitamin C deficiency
Dental restorations that don't fit properly or crooked teeth that are difficult to clean
Conditions that decrease immunity such as leukemia, HIV/AIDS or cancer treatment
Certain drugs, such as phenytoin (Dilantin, Phenytek) for epileptic seizures, and some calcium channel blockers, used for angina, high blood pressure and other conditions
Hormonal changes, such as those related to pregnancy, menstrual cycle or use of birth control pills
Medical conditions such as certain viral and fungal infections
diagnosis: Review of your dental and medical history
Examination of your teeth gums mouth and tongue

name: Bed wetting
description: Bed-wetting — Learn about causes and treatments, including moisture alarms, bladder training and medications.
causes: Inability to recognize a full bladder
A structural problem in the urinary tract or nervous system
complications: Guilt and embarrassment, which can lead to low self-esteem
Loss of opportunities for social activities, such as sleepovers and camp
Rashes on the child's bottom and genital area — especially if your child sleeps in wet underwear
diagnosis: Discussion of symptoms, fluid intake, family history, bowel and bladder habits, and problems associated with bed-wetting
Urine tests to check for signs of an infection or diabetes
X-rays or other imaging tests of the kidneys or bladder to look at the structure of the urinary tract
Other types of urinary tract tests or assessments, as needed

name: Periodontitis
description: This serious gum infection damages the soft tissue and can destroy the bone that supports your teeth. It can cause teeth to loosen or lead to tooth loss.
symptoms: Bright red, dusky red or purplish gums
Gums that feel tender when touched
Spitting out blood when brushing or flossing your teeth
Pus between your teeth and gums
Loose teeth or loss of teeth
New spaces developing between your teeth
Gums that pull away from your teeth (recede), making your teeth look longer than normal
A change in the way your teeth fit together when you bite
causes: Plaque can harden under your gumline into tartar calculus
Ongoing gum inflammation can cause periodontitis
risks: Hormonal changes, such as those related to pregnancy or menopause
Recreational drug use, such as smoking marijuana or vaping
Inadequate nutrition, including vitamin C deficiency
Certain medications that cause dry mouth or gum changes
Conditions that cause decreased immunity, such as leukemia, HIV/AIDS and cancer treatment
Certain diseases, such as diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis and Crohn's disease

name: Neuromyelitis optica
description: Understand more about this condition that affects the spinal cord and eye nerves and is sometimes mistaken for multiple sclerosis.

name: Neuromyelitis optica
description: Understand more about this condition that affects the spinal cord and eye nerves and is sometimes mistaken for multiple sclerosis.

name: Helicobacter pylori infection
description: Learn more about the symptoms, tests and treatments of this infection with Helicobacter pylori bacteria.
symptoms: An ache or burning pain in your stomach (abdomen)
Stomach pain that may be worse when your stomach is empty
risks: Living without a reliable supply of clean water
Living with someone who has an H pylori infection

name: Stuttering
description: Stuttering, sometimes called stammering, is a speech disorder that involves frequent and significant problems with normal fluency and flow of speech.
symptoms: Difficulty starting a word, phrase or sentence
Prolonging a word or sounds within a word
Repetition of a sound, syllable or word
Brief silence for certain syllables or words, or pauses within a word (broken word)
Addition of extra words such as "um" if difficulty moving to the next word is anticipated
Excess tension, tightness, or movement of the face or upper body to produce a word
complications: Not speaking or avoiding situations that require speaking
Loss of social, school, or work participation and success
treatment: Participate fully in school, work and social activities

name: Bed wetting
description: Bed-wetting — Learn about causes and treatments, including moisture alarms, bladder training and medications.
causes: Inability to recognize a full bladder
A structural problem in the urinary tract or nervous system
complications: Guilt and embarrassment, which can lead to low self-esteem
Loss of opportunities for social activities, such as sleepovers and camp
Rashes on the child's bottom and genital area — especially if your child sleeps in wet underwear
diagnosis: Discussion of symptoms, fluid intake, family history, bowel and bladder habits, and problems associated with bed-wetting
Urine tests to check for signs of an infection or diabetes
X-rays or other imaging tests of the kidneys or bladder to look at the structure of the urinary tract
Other types of urinary tract tests or assessments, as needed

name: Staph infections
description: Learn about the symptoms, causes and treatment of these potentially lethal infections.

name: Swine flu
description: Find out more about the flu caused by the H1N1 virus. Learn how to prevent and treat the flu.
complications: Worsening of chronic conditions, such as heart disease and asthma
Neurological signs and symptoms, ranging from confusion to seizures
preventions: Wash your hands thoroughly and frequently
diagnosis: You're at high risk of complications from the flu
You live with someone who is at greater risk of flu complications

name: Carcinoid syndrome
description: Find out about skin flushing and other symptoms of this syndrome caused by a rare cancer called a carcinoid tumor.
diagnosis: A scope or camera to see inside your body
treatment: Medications to block cancer cells from secreting chemicals
Drugs that deliver radiation directly to the cancer cells
Stopping blood supply to liver tumors
Killing cancer cells in the liver with heat or cold

name: Sexually transmitted disease
description: Find out the signs and symptoms of STDs and what you can do to prevent them, along with the treatments available if you're diagnosed with one.
symptoms: Sores or bumps on the genitals or in the oral or rectal area
Sore, swollen lymph nodes, particularly in the groin but sometimes more widespread
Rash over the trunk, hands or feet
risks: Having sexual contact with multiple partners
Being forced to engage in sexual activity
Misuse of alcohol or use of recreational drugs
complications: Certain cancers, such as HPV-associated cervical and rectal cancers
preventions: Use condoms and dental dams consistently and correctly
Dont drink alcohol excessively or use drugs

name: Age-related hearing loss
description: Age- and noise-related hearing loss are common and can affect quality of life. But many treatments are available.
symptoms: Muffling of speech and other sounds
Difficulty understanding words, especially against background noise or in a crowd
Frequently asking others to speak more slowly, clearly and loudly
Needing to turn up the volume of the television or radio

name: Swine flu
description: Find out more about the flu caused by the H1N1 virus. Learn how to prevent and treat the flu.
complications: Worsening of chronic conditions, such as heart disease and asthma
Neurological signs and symptoms, ranging from confusion to seizures
preventions: Wash your hands thoroughly and frequently
diagnosis: You're at high risk of complications from the flu
You live with someone who is at greater risk of flu complications

name: Carcinoid tumor
description: Learn about these slow-growing cancers that usually begin in the digestive system or in the lungs. Treatments include peptide receptor radionuclide therapy.
diagnosis: A scope or camera that sees inside your body
treatment: Drugs that deliver radiation directly to the cancer cells
Treatment for cancer that spreads to the liver

name: Progressive supranuclear palsy
description: Learn about this brain disorder that interferes with the ability to walk, move your eyes, talk and eat.
symptoms: A loss of balance while walking
An inability to aim your eyes properly
complications: Falling, which could lead to head injuries, fractures and other injuries
Difficulty focusing your eyes, which also can lead to injuries
Difficulty sleeping, which can lead to a feeling of tiredness and excessive daytime sleeping
Problems swallowing, which can lead to choking or inhaling food or liquid into your airway (aspiration)
Pneumonia, which can be caused by aspiration and is the most common cause of death in people with progressive supranuclear palsy
Impulsive behaviors — for example, standing up without waiting for assistance — which can lead to falls
diagnosis: Are having a lot of unexplained falls
Have little or no response to Parkinson's medications
Have difficulty moving your eyes, particularly downward
treatment: Eyeglasses with bifocal or prism lenses

name: Swine flu
description: Find out more about the flu caused by the H1N1 virus. Learn how to prevent and treat the flu.
complications: Worsening of chronic conditions, such as heart disease and asthma
Neurological signs and symptoms, ranging from confusion to seizures
preventions: Wash your hands thoroughly and frequently
diagnosis: You're at high risk of complications from the flu
You live with someone who is at greater risk of flu complications

name: Polycystic ovary syndrome
description: Polycystic ovaries, hormone imbalance and irregular periods are telltale signs and symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome. Find out about treatments.
complications: Gestational diabetes or pregnancy-induced high blood pressure
Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis — a severe liver inflammation caused by fat buildup in the liver

Metabolic syndrome — a cluster of conditions including high blood pressure, high blood sugar, and unhealthy cholesterol or triglyceride levels that significantly increase your risk of heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) disease
Cancer of the uterine lining (endometrial cancer)

name: Swine flu
description: Find out more about the flu caused by the H1N1 virus. Learn how to prevent and treat the flu.
complications: Worsening of chronic conditions, such as heart disease and asthma
Neurological signs and symptoms, ranging from confusion to seizures
preventions: Wash your hands thoroughly and frequently
diagnosis: You're at high risk of complications from the flu
You live with someone who is at greater risk of flu complications

name: Trigger finger
description: In this condition, a finger gets stuck in a bent position and may straighten suddenly with a snap. It happens most often in women over the age of 50.
symptoms: Finger stiffness, particularly in the morning.
A popping or clicking sensation as the finger moves.
Tenderness or a bump in the palm at the base of the affected finger.
Finger catching or locking in a bent position, which suddenly pops straight.
Finger locked in a bent position.

name: Hair loss
description: This common and sometimes stressful condition may result from heredity, medications or medical conditions. Treatment may reverse or slow hair loss.
risks: A family history of balding on your mother's or father's side
Certain medical conditions, such as diabetes and lupus
preventions: Be gentle with your hair. Use a detangler and avoid tugging when brushing and combing, especially when your hair is wet. A wide-toothed comb might help prevent pulling out hair. Avoid harsh treatments such as hot rollers, curling irons, hot-oil treatments and permanents. Limit the tension on hair from styles that use rubber bands, barrettes and braids.
Ask your doctor about medications and supplements you take that might cause hair loss.
Protect your hair from sunlight and other sources of ultraviolet light.
Stop smoking. Some studies show an association between smoking and baldness in men.
If you're being treated with chemotherapy, ask your doctor about a cooling cap. This cap can reduce your risk of losing hair during chemotherapy.

name: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease
description: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is becoming more common in the Western world. Find out how to treat and prevent this potentially dangerous liver disease.
causes: Insulin resistance, in which your cells don't take up sugar in response to the hormone insulin
High blood sugar (hyperglycemia), indicating prediabetes or type 2 diabetes
High levels of fats, particularly triglycerides, in the blood
risks: High levels of triglycerides in the blood
Obesity, particularly when fat is concentrated in the abdomen

name: Aortic valve stenosis
description: Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of this condition that reduces or blocks blood flow from the heart to the body.
symptoms: An irregular heart sound (heart murmur) heard through a stethoscope
Chest pain (angina) or tightness with activity
Feeling faint or dizzy or fainting with activity
Shortness of breath, especially with activity
Fatigue, especially during times of increased activity
Not eating enough (mainly in children with aortic valve stenosis)
Not gaining enough weight (mainly in children with aortic valve stenosis)
risks: Certain heart conditions present at birth (congenital heart defects), such as a bicuspid aortic valve
Having heart disease risk factors, such as diabetes, high cholesterol and high blood pressure
History of infections that can affect the heart, such as rheumatic fever and infective endocarditis
History of radiation therapy to the chest
complications: Infections that affect the heart, such as endocarditis
preventions: Taking steps to prevent rheumatic fever
Taking care of the teeth and gums

name: Cancer of unknown origin
description: In this uncommon and aggressive type of cancer, doctors aren't sure where the cancer began. Learn how they determine which treatments are most likely to help.
symptoms: A lump that can be felt through the skin
Changes in bowel habits, such as new and persistent constipation or diarrhea
causes: The original cancer is too small to be detected by imaging tests
The original cancer was killed by the body's immune system
The original cancer was removed in an operation for another condition
diagnosis: Removing a sample of tissue for testing

name: Trichotillomania
description: Trichotillomania (hair-pulling disorder) involves recurrent, irresistible urges to pull out hair from your body. Therapy may help reduce or stop urges.
symptoms: Repeatedly pulling your hair out, typically from your scalp, eyebrows or eyelashes, but sometimes from other body areas, and sites may vary over time
An increasing sense of tension before pulling, or when you try to resist pulling
A sense of pleasure or relief after the hair is pulled
Noticeable hair loss, such as shortened hair or thinned or bald areas on the scalp or other areas of your body, including sparse or missing eyelashes or eyebrows
Preference for specific types of hair, rituals that accompany hair pulling or patterns of hair pulling
Biting, chewing or eating pulled-out hair
Playing with pulled-out hair or rubbing it across your lips or face
Repeatedly trying to stop pulling out your hair or trying to do it less often without success
Significant distress or problems at work, school or in social situations related to pulling out your hair
complications: Problems with social and work functioning
diagnosis: Examining how much hair loss you have
Asking questions and discussing your hair loss with you
Eliminating other possible causes of hair pulling or hair loss through testing determined by your doctor
Identifying any physical or mental health problems that may be associated with hair pulling
Using the diagnostic criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association

name: Nonallergic rhinitis
description: A number of factors can trigger this bothersome nonallergic condition. Learn how to get relief from your runny, stuffy nose.
causes: Sleeping on your back sleep apnea and acid reflux
risks: Prolonged use of decongestant nasal drops or sprays

name: Mitral valve stenosis
description: When the valve between the left heart chambers is narrowed, the heart doesn't get enough blood. Know the symptoms, causes and treatment of this type of heart valve disease.
symptoms: Shortness of breath, especially with activity or when you lie down
Sensations of a fast, fluttering or pounding heartbeat
Irregular heart sound, also called a heart murmur
complications: High blood pressure in the lung arteries
treatment: Beta blockers calcium channel blockers or other heart drugs

name: Hairy cell leukemia
description: This slow-growing cancer doesn't always need immediate treatment. When hairy cell leukemia treatment is needed, it usually starts with chemotherapy.
symptoms: A feeling of fullness in your belly that may make it uncomfortable to eat more than a little at a time

name: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
description: Learn more about the symptoms, risk factors and treatment of this cancer of the lymphatic system that causes swollen lymph nodes.
risks: Medications that suppress your immune system
Infection with certain viruses and bacteria

name: Pulmonary valve stenosis
description: When the valve between the heart and lungs is narrowed, blood flow slows. Know the symptoms of this type of valve disease and how it's treated.
symptoms: A whooshing sound called a heart murmur that can be heard with a stethoscope.
Shortness of breath, especially during activity.
complications: Infection of the lining of the heart called infective endocarditis

name: Black hairy tongue
description: Black hairy tongue is a temporary, harmless oral condition that gives your tongue a dark, furry appearance.
symptoms: Black discoloration of the tongue, although the color may be brown, tan, green, yellow or white
A hairy or furry appearance of the tongue
Altered taste or metallic taste in your mouth
Gagging or tickling sensation, if the overgrowth of the papillae is excessive
causes: Changes in the normal bacteria or yeast content of the mouth after antibiotic use
Regular use of mouthwashes containing irritating oxidizing agents, such as peroxide
Drinking excessive amounts of coffee or black tea
Eating a soft diet that doesn't help to rub dead skin cells from your tongue
diagnosis: Foods or medications that have stained the tongue
Oral lesions that occur on the tongue, such as oral hairy leukoplakia
Blackened tongue (pseudo-black hairy tongue) from using products containing bismuth, such as Pepto-Bismol

name: Priapism
description: Understand the symptoms, possible causes and treatment of prolonged erection of the penis, including when to seek emergency care.
preventions: Treatment for an underlying condition, such as sickle cell disease, that might have caused priapism
Use of oral or injectable phenylephrine
Hormone-blocking medications — only for adult men
Use of oral medications used to manage erectile dysfunction

name: Pyloric stenosis
description: In this condition, a valve between an infant's stomach and small intestine fails to open enough for food to pass through. Surgery is the treatment.
diagnosis: Blood tests to check for dehydration or electrolyte imbalance or both.
Ultrasound to view the pylorus and confirm a diagnosis of pyloric stenosis.
X-rays of your baby's digestive system, if results of the ultrasound aren't clear.

name: Bad breath
description: Bad breath — Comprehensive overview covers causes, treatment and prevention.
causes: Other mouth nose and throat conditions

name: Spinal stenosis
description: This condition narrows the amount of space within the spine. This can squeeze the nerves that travel through the spine. Surgery is sometimes needed.

name: Hammertoe and mallet toe
description: Hammertoe and mallet toe — Comprehensive overview covers causes, symptoms and treatment of these foot deformities.
causes: Abnormal balance of the toe muscles

name: Stevens-Johnson syndrome
description: Learn more about the causes of this rare disorder of the skin and mucous membranes, its early signs, and whether it's preventable.
causes: Medications to treat seizures and mental illness (anticonvulsants and antipsychotics)
Pain relievers, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve)
risks: A family history of StevensJohnson syndrome
preventions: Consider genetic testing before taking certain drugs
If youve had this condition avoid the medication that triggered it
diagnosis: A review of your medical history and a physical exam
treatment: Medication to reduce inflammation of the eyes and mucous membranes (topical steroids).
Antibiotics to control infection, when needed.

Other oral or injected (systemic) medications, such as corticosteroids and intravenous immune globulin. Studies show that the drugs cyclosporine (Neoral, Sandimmune) and etanercept (Enbrel) are helpful in treating this disease.

name: Non-melanoma skin cancer
description: Learn about treatment options for all types of nonmelanoma skin cancer, including squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma and others.

name: Sudden cardiac arrest
description: This medical emergency involves sudden loss of all heart activity. Learn how fast, appropriate care may help prevent death.
risks: A family history of coronary artery disease.

name: Celiac disease
description: In celiac disease, wheat protein (gluten) in food damages the small intestine, making it hard to absorb nutrients and causing a variety of symptoms.
risks: A family member with celiac disease or dermatitis herpetiformis

name: Nonulcer stomach pain
description: Learn about functional dyspepsia, a digestive disorder with no clear cause. Treatment may help relieve this common condition.
symptoms: Pain or burning in the stomach, bloating, excessive belching, or nausea after eating
An early feeling of fullness when eating. The feeling of fullness also is called satiety.
Stomach pain that occurs unrelated to meals or goes away when eating.
risks: Using certain pain relievers that are available without a prescription. These include aspirin and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), which can cause stomach problems.
History of childhood physical or sexual abuse.

name: Myocardial ischemia
description: Myocardial ischemia reduces blood flow to the heart and may cause chest pain – but not always. Learn all the signs and symptoms and how to treat it.
symptoms: Shortness of breath when you are physically active

name: Hamstring injury
description: Self-care measures, such as rest and ice, might be all that's needed for an injury to one of the hamstring muscles.
risks: Tired muscles weak muscles and muscles that dont stretch well

name: Noonan syndrome
description: Noonan syndrome is a genetic disorder that may cause unusual facial features, short stature, heart defects, eye conditions and other health problems.

name: Broken hand
description: You may be at higher risk of a broken hand if you participate in contact sports like football or hockey, or if you have a condition in which bones become thinner and more fragile (osteoporosis).
symptoms: Severe pain that might worsen when gripping or squeezing or moving your hand
Obvious deformity, such as a crooked finger
Stiffness or inability to move your fingers or thumb
Numbness in your hand or fingers

name: Norovirus infection
description: This highly contagious virus spreads through contaminated food, water or surfaces and causes vomiting and diarrhea. Learn ways to protect yourself.
causes: Touching your hand to your mouth after your hand has been in contact with a contaminated surface or object
Being in close contact with a person who has norovirus infection
risks: Eating in a place where food has been handled by someone with norovirus infection or the food has been in contact with contaminated water or surfaces
Attending preschool or a child care center
Living in close quarters, such as in nursing homes
Staying in hotels, resorts, cruise ships or other destinations with many people in close quarters
Having contact with someone who has norovirus infection
preventions: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water for at least 20 seconds
Disinfect surfaces that might have been contaminated

name: Broken nose
description: A broken nose can cause pain, swelling and bruising around your nose and eyes. Surgery usually isn't necessary.
symptoms: Pain or tenderness, especially when touching your nose
Swelling of your nose and surrounding areas
Bruising around your nose or eyes
Discharge of mucus from your nose
Feeling that one or both of your nasal passages are blocked
causes: Injury from contact sports, such as football or hockey
risks: Playing contact sports, such as football and hockey, especially without a helmet that has a face mask
Lifting weights, especially if you don't use a spotter
Riding in a motor vehicle, especially without a seat belt

name: Hand-foot-and-mouth disease
description: Learn about the symptoms and treatment of this contagious viral infection. It is marked by sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet.
causes: Respiratory droplets sprayed into the air after a cough or sneeze
diagnosis: What your child's rash or sores look like

name: Compulsive sexual behavior
description: Compulsive sexual behavior or hypersexuality is an excessive preoccupation with sexual fantasies, urges or behaviors that disrupts your life or is harmful to you or others.
symptoms: You have recurrent and intense sexual fantasies, urges and behaviors that take up a lot of your time and feel as if they're beyond your control.
You feel driven to do certain sexual behaviors, feel a release of the tension afterward, but also feel guilt or remorse.
You've tried unsuccessfully to reduce or control your sexual fantasies, urges or behavior.
You use compulsive sexual behavior as an escape from other problems, such as loneliness, depression, anxiety or stress.

You continue to engage in sexual behaviors that have serious consequences, such as the potential for getting or giving someone else a sexually transmitted infection, the loss of important relationships, trouble at work, financial strain, or legal problems.
You have trouble establishing and maintaining healthy and stable relationships.
causes: An imbalance of natural brain chemicals
risks: Ease of access to sexual content
complications: Neglect or lie to your partner and family
Lose your focus or engage in sexual activity or search internet pornography at work
Contract HIV hepatitis or another sexually transmitted infection
preventions: Get help early for problems with sexual behavior
Seek treatment early for mental health disorders
Identify and seek help for alcohol and drug abuse problems
diagnosis: Physical and mental health, as well as your overall emotional well-being
Sexual thoughts, behaviors and compulsions that are hard to control
Use of recreational drugs and alcohol
Problems caused by your sexual behavior

name: Stickler syndrome
description: This genetic disorder can cause serious vision, hearing and joint problems. Children may be born with a cleft palate and distinctive facial features.

name: Cardiogenic shock
description: Most often the result of a severe heart attack, this rare condition can be deadly if not treated immediately.
symptoms: Pressure, fullness or a squeezing pain in the center of your chest that lasts for more than a few minutes
Pain spreading to your shoulder, one or both of your arms, your back, or even your teeth and jaw
causes: Drug overdoses or poisoning with substances that can affect your heart's pumping ability
risks: Have a history of heart failure or heart attack
Have blockages (coronary artery disease) in several of your heart's main arteries
Have diabetes or high blood pressure
preventions: Dont smoke and avoid secondhand smoke
Eat less cholesterol and saturated fat

name: Bee stings
description: Learn more about symptoms, treatment, self-care tips and prevention of bee stings, which in some people cause severe allergic reaction.
risks: You live in an area where bees are especially active or with beehives nearby
Your work or hobbies require spending time outside
preventions: Take care when drinking sweet beverages outside. Wide, open cups may be your best option because you can see if a bee is in them. Inspect cans and straws before drinking from them.
Tightly cover food containers and trash cans.
Clear away garbage, fallen fruit, and dog or other animal feces (flies can attract wasps).
Wear closed-toe shoes when walking outside.
Don't wear bright colors or floral prints, which can attract bees.
Don't wear loose clothing, which can trap bees between the cloth and your skin.
When driving, keep your windows rolled up.
Be careful when mowing the lawn or trimming vegetation, activities that might arouse insects in a beehive or wasp nest.
Have hives and nests near your home removed by a professional.
treatment: If you can, remove the stinger as soon as possible, such as by scraping it off with a fingernail. Don't try to remove a stinger below the skin surface. A stinger may not be present, as only bees leave their stingers. Other stinging insects, such as wasps, do not.
Wash the affected area with soap and water.
Take an over-the-counter pain reliever as needed. You might try ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) to help ease discomfort.
If the sting is on an arm or leg, elevate it.
Apply hydrocortisone cream or calamine lotion to ease redness, itching or swelling.
If itching or swelling is bothersome, take an oral antihistamine that contains diphenhydramine (Benadryl) or chlorpheniramine.
Avoid scratching the sting area. This will worsen itching and swelling and increase your risk of infection.

name: Hangover
description: Unpleasant signs and symptoms can develop after drinking too much alcohol — but severe signs may indicate alcohol poisoning, a life-threatening emergency.
symptoms: Increased sensitivity to light and sound
Dizziness or a sense of the room spinning
Mood disturbances, such as depression, anxiety and irritability
causes: Alcohol causes your body to produce more urine
Alcohol triggers an inflammatory response from your immune system
Alcohol irritates the lining of your stomach
Alcohol can cause your blood sugar to fall
Alcohol causes your blood vessels to expand
risks: Using other drugs such as nicotine along with alcohol
Not sleeping well or long enough after drinking
Having a family history of alcoholism
preventions: Know your limits and only drink in moderation

name: Jellyfish stings
description: Learn more about prevention and first aid for these painful injuries that are common among people swimming in seawater but are rarely life-threatening.
symptoms: Welts or tracks on the skin — a "print" of the tentacles' contact with the skin
Throbbing pain that radiates up a leg or an arm
risks: Swimming when jellyfish appear in large numbers (a jellyfish bloom)
Swimming or diving in jellyfish areas without protective clothing
Playing or sunbathing where jellyfish are washed up on the beach
Swimming in a place known to have many jellyfish
complications: Delayed skin reaction, causing blisters, rash or other irritation
Irukandji syndrome, which causes chest and stomach pain, high blood pressure, and heart problems

name: Enlarged heart
description: Cardiomegaly is another word for this sign or symptom that may be caused by certain heart conditions or even pregnancy. Know how it's treated.
symptoms: Shortness of breath, especially while lying flat
Swelling (edema) in the belly or in the legs
causes: Heart condition present at birth congenital heart defect
Diseases of the heart muscle cardiomyopathy
Fluid buildup in the sac around the heart pericardial effusion
High blood pressure in the arteries in the lungs pulmonary hypertension
Low red blood cell count anemia
Too much iron in the body hemochromatosis
Unusual protein deposits in the heart cardiac amyloidosis
risks: A family history of heart muscle disease cardiomyopathy
preventions: Monitor and manage high blood pressure, high cholesterol and diabetes.
Take any prescribed medications as directed.

name: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome
description: Learn about the rodent-transmitted virus that causes severe — and sometimes fatal — lung disease with flu-like symptoms that can rapidly worsen.
risks: Infrequently used buildings, such as storage sheds

name: Scorpion stings
description: Learn more about symptoms, risk factors, treatment and prevention of this type of sting, which is painful but rarely life-threatening.
risks: Working hiking or camping where scorpions are

name: Overactive bladder
description: Learn how you can get relief for frequent, sudden urges to urinate, which may point to overactive bladder or urinary incontinence.
symptoms: Feel a sudden urge to urinate that's difficult to control
Experience unintentional loss of urine immediately after an urgent need to urinate (urgency incontinence)
Urinate frequently, usually eight or more times in 24 hours
Wake up more than two times in the night to urinate (nocturia)
complications: Sleep disturbances and interrupted sleep cycles
preventions: Get regular, daily physical activity and exercise.
Manage chronic conditions, such as diabetes, that might contribute to overactive bladder symptoms.
Do exercises to make the pelvic floor muscles stronger. These exercises are called Kegel exercises.
diagnosis: Physical exam, which may include a rectal exam and a pelvic exam in women
