Urine sample to test for infection, traces of blood or other abnormalities
Focused neurological exam that may identify sensory issues or reflex problems
treatment: Oxybutynin, which can be taken as a pill (Ditropan XL) or used as a skin patch (Oxytrol) or gel (Gelnique)

name: Arteriosclerosis/atherosclerosis
description: Learn about the symptoms, causes and treatments for hardening of the arteries.
symptoms: If you have atherosclerosis in your heart arteries
If you have atherosclerosis in the arteries leading to your brain
If you have atherosclerosis in the arteries in your arms and legs
If you have atherosclerosis in the arteries leading to your kidneys
risks: A family history of early heart disease
High levels of C-reactive protein (CRP), a marker of inflammation
preventions: Checking and maintaining a healthy blood pressure
Checking and maintaining healthy cholesterol and blood sugar levels

name: Stomach cancer
description: Stomach cancer, which is also called gastric cancer, is cancer that begins in the stomach. Learn about symptoms, causes, detection and treatments.
symptoms: Feeling full after eating small amounts of food
Not feeling hungry when you would expect to be hungry
risks: Ongoing problems with stomach acid backing up into the esophagus, which is called gastroesophageal reflux disease
A diet high in salty and smoked foods
A diet low in fruits and vegetables
Infection in the stomach caused by a germ called Helicobacter pylori
Swelling and irritation of the inside of the stomach, which is called gastritis
Growths of noncancerous cells in the stomach, called polyps

Family history of genetic syndromes that increase the risk of stomach cancer and other cancers, such as hereditary diffuse gastric cancer, Lynch syndrome, juvenile polyposis syndrome, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and familial adenomatous polyposis
preventions: Eat plenty of fruits and vegetables
Reduce the amount of salty and smoked foods you eat
Tell your health care provider if stomach cancer runs in your family

name: Hashimoto's disease
description: Learn about the symptoms and treatment of this thyroid disorder caused by an immune-system dysfunction.
causes: Environmental triggers, such as infection, stress or radiation exposure
Interactions between environmental and genetic factors

name: Viral gastroenteritis
description: This condition, often called stomach flu, is usually harmless, except for infants and people with immunosuppression. Symptoms can usually be managed.
risks: Anyone with a weakened immune system
preventions: Use separate personal items around your home
Avoid touching laundry that may have been exposed to a virus
Check out your child care center

name: Obesity
description: Obesity isn't just a cosmetic concern. It is a medical problem that increases the risk of heart disease, diabetes and certain cancers.

name: Nonulcer stomach pain
description: Learn about functional dyspepsia, a digestive disorder with no clear cause. Treatment may help relieve this common condition.
symptoms: Pain or burning in the stomach, bloating, excessive belching, or nausea after eating
An early feeling of fullness when eating. The feeling of fullness also is called satiety.
Stomach pain that occurs unrelated to meals or goes away when eating.
risks: Using certain pain relievers that are available without a prescription. These include aspirin and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), which can cause stomach problems.
History of childhood physical or sexual abuse.

name: Stomach polyps
description: These masses of cells that form on your stomach lining usually don't cause symptoms. Learn what causes them and when to be concerned.
symptoms: Pain or tenderness when you press your stomach
causes: Regular use of certain stomach medications
treatment: Polyps associated with familial adenomatous polyposis

name: Burning mouth syndrome
description: This chronic burning, without an obvious cause, may affect the tongue, gums, lips, cheeks, roof of your mouth or widespread areas of your mouth.
symptoms: A burning or scalding sensation that most commonly affects your tongue, but may also affect your lips, gums, palate, throat or whole mouth
A sensation of dry mouth with increased thirst
Taste changes in your mouth, such as a bitter or metallic taste
Tingling, stinging or numbness in your mouth
diagnosis: Review your medical history and medications
Ask you to describe your symptoms, oral habits and oral care routine

name: Hepatitis A
description: Hepatitis A is a contagious liver infection caused by a virus. Learn how the disease spreads and what you can do to prevent or treat it.
symptoms: Sudden nausea and vomiting and diarrhea
Abdominal pain or discomfort, especially on the upper right side beneath your lower ribs, which is over your liver
Yellowing of the skin and the whites of your eyes (jaundice)
causes: Eating food handled by someone with the virus who doesn't thoroughly wash hands after using the toilet
Eating food washed in contaminated water
Eating raw shellfish from water polluted with sewage
Being in close contact with a person who has the virus — even if that person has no symptoms
Having sexual contact with someone who has the virus
risks: Travel or work in areas of the world where hepatitis A is common
Live with another person who has hepatitis A
Are a man who has sexual contact with other men
Have any type of sexual contact with someone who has hepatitis A
Use any type of recreational drugs, not just those that are injected
preventions: All children at age 1 year, or older children who didn't receive the childhood vaccine
Anyone age 1 year or older who is homeless
Infants ages 6 to 11 months traveling to parts of the world where hepatitis A is common
Family and caregivers of adoptees from countries where hepatitis A is common
People in direct contact with others who have hepatitis A
Laboratory workers who may come into contact with hepatitis A
Men who have sex with men
People who work or travel in parts of the world where hepatitis A is common
People who use any type of recreational drugs, not just injected ones
People with chronic liver disease, including hepatitis B or hepatitis C
treatment: Avoid alcohol and use medications with care

name: Childhood obesity
description: Childhood obesity can lead to various conditions, including type 2 diabetes and high blood pressure. Learn how to protect your child's health.
preventions: Be sure your child gets enough sleep
diagnosis: BMI 99th percentile or higher — severe obesity

name: Encopresis
description: Encopresis, also called fecal incontinence or soiling, occurs when constipation causes impacted stool to fill the colon, and liquid stool leaks out.
symptoms: Leakage of stool or liquid stool on underwear, which can be mistaken for diarrhea
Passage of large stool that clogs or almost clogs the toilet
Long periods of time between bowel movements
Problems with daytime wetting or bedwetting (enuresis)
Repeated bladder infections, typically in girls
risks: Using medications that may cause constipation, such as cough suppressants
diagnosis: Suggest that a psychological evaluation be done

name: Cardiomyopathy
description: This disease of the heart muscle makes it harder for the heart to pump blood to the rest of the body. Learn the different types and how they're treated.
symptoms: Breathlessness with activity or even at rest
Swelling of the legs, ankles and feet
Bloating of the abdomen due to fluid buildup
Heartbeats that feel rapid, pounding or fluttering
risks: Family history of cardiomyopathy, heart failure and sudden cardiac arrest
Conditions that affect the heart, including a past heart attack, coronary artery disease or an infection in the heart (ischemic cardiomyopathy)
Obesity, which makes the heart work harder
Illicit drug use, such as cocaine, amphetamines and anabolic steroids
Treatment with certain chemotherapy drugs and radiation for cancer
preventions: Avoiding the use of alcohol or cocaine
Controlling high blood pressure, high cholesterol and diabetes
treatment: Improve the heart's ability to pump blood
Remove extra fluid from the body

name: Hemangioma
description: Learn more about the causes and treatment of this red mark on the skin of babies that fades over time.

name: Hay fever
description: Find out more about how to diagnose and get relief from this common condition that can make you feel awful, seasonally and year-round.
symptoms: Itchy nose, roof of mouth or throat
Mucus that runs down the back of your throat (postnasal drip)
Swollen, bruised-appearing skin under the eyes (allergic shiners)
Extreme tiredness (fatigue), often due to poor sleep
risks: Having a condition called atopic dermatitis or eczema, which makes your skin irritated and itchy
Having a blood relative, such as a parent or sibling, with allergies or asthma
Living or working in an environment that constantly exposes you to allergens — such as animal dander or dust mites
Being exposed to smoke and strong odors that irritate the lining of the nose
Having a mother who smoked during your first year of life

name: Dilated cardiomyopathy
description: In this heart muscle disease, the heart's main pumping chamber stretches and can't pump blood well. Learn about the causes and treatment.
symptoms: Shortness of breath (dyspnea) during activity or while lying down
Swelling (edema) in the legs, ankles, feet or belly (abdomen)
causes: Excessive iron in the heart and other organs (hemochromatosis)
Heart valve disease, such as mitral valve or aortic valve regurgitation
risks: Damage to the heart muscle from certain diseases, such as hemochromatosis
Family history of dilated cardiomyopathy, heart failure or sudden cardiac arrest
Inflammation of the heart muscle from immune system disorders, such as lupus
Long-term excessive alcohol or illegal drug use
Neuromuscular disorders, such as muscular dystrophy
complications: Leaky heart valves heart valve regurgitation
preventions: Don't use cocaine or other illegal drugs.
Eat a healthy diet that is low in salt (sodium).

name: Hepatitis B
description: Hepatitis B is a contagious liver infection that can be long lasting. Learn how the infection spreads and what you can do to prevent or treat it.
symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and the whites of the eyes, also called jaundice
risks: Have unprotected sex with multiple sex partners or with someone who's infected with HBV
Share needles during IV drug use
Are a man who has sex with other men
Live with someone who has a chronic HBV infection
Are an infant born to an infected mother
Have a job that exposes you to human blood
Travel to regions with high infection rates of HBV, such as Asia, the Pacific Islands, Africa and Eastern Europe
complications: Reactivation of the hepatitis B virus
preventions: Children and adolescents not vaccinated at birth
Those who work or live in a center for people who are developmentally disabled
People who live with someone who has hepatitis B
Health care workers, emergency workers and other people who come into contact with blood
Anyone who has a sexually transmitted infection, including HIV
Men who have sex with men
People who have multiple sexual partners
Sexual partners of someone who has hepatitis B
People who inject illegal drugs or share needles and syringes
Travelers planning to go to an area of the world with a high hepatitis B infection rate

name: Strep throat
description: Learn more about the symptoms, causes and treatment of this throat bacterial infection in children and adults.
diagnosis: Molecular polymerase chain reaction or PCR test

name: Obsessive compulsive disorder
description: OCD features a pattern of unwanted thoughts and fears (obsessions), leading to repetitive behaviors (compulsions) that interfere with daily activities.
complications: Excessive time spent engaging in ritualistic behaviors
Health issues, such as contact dermatitis from frequent hand-washing
Difficulty attending work, school or social activities

name: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
description: In this condition, the heart muscle thickens, which makes it harder for the heart to pump blood. Learn about the causes and treatment.
symptoms: Fainting, especially during or just after exercise or exertion
Heart murmur, which a health care provider might detect while listening to the heart
Sensation of fast, fluttering or pounding heartbeats (palpitations)
Shortness of breath, especially during exercise
treatment: Beta blockers such as metoprolol (Lopressor, Toprol-XL), propranolol (Inderal, Innopran XL) or atenolol (Tenormin)
Calcium channel blockers such as verapamil (Verelan, Calan SR,) or diltiazem (Cardizem, Tiazac)
Heart rhythm drugs such as amiodarone (Pacerone) or disopyramide (Norpace)

Blood thinners such as warfarin (Jantoven), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto) or apixaban (Eliquis) to prevent blood clots if you have atrial fibrillation or the apical type of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can increase the risk of sudden cardiac death.

name: Broken heart syndrome
description: Learn more about this temporary heart muscle condition that can mimic a heart attack. It may be triggered by stressful events, such as a loved one's death.
causes: Sudden illness such as an asthma attack or COVID-19 infection.
Death of a loved one or other loss.
complications: Backup of fluid into the lungs, called pulmonary edema.
preventions: Connect with others in support groups.
treatment: Blood thinners, if there is a blood clot.

name: Achalasia
description: In achalasia, the muscles in your throat don't relax, preventing the passage of food and drink. Learn more about this rare digestive disorder.
symptoms: Inability to swallow (dysphagia), which may feel like food or drink is stuck in your throat
Chest pain that comes and goes
Pneumonia (from aspiration of food into the lungs)
diagnosis: Xrays of your upper digestive system esophagram

name: Cholestasis of pregnancy
description: This liver condition can occur late in pregnancy, triggering intense itching. The risk of complications for your baby may require early delivery.
symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes, called jaundice
risks: Personal or family history of cholestasis of pregnancy
History of liver damage or disease, including hepatitis C and gallbladder stones
Pregnancy at an older age, such as 35 years or older
complications: Being born too early, also called preterm birth.

Lung problems from breathing in meconium. Meconium is the sticky, green substance that typically collects in the developing baby's intestines. Meconium may pass into the amniotic fluid if a mom has cholestasis.
Death of the baby late in pregnancy before delivery, also called stillbirth.
diagnosis: Ask questions about your symptoms and medical history
Order blood tests to measure the level of bile acids in your blood and to check how well your liver is working

name: Hepatitis C
description: Many people with hepatitis C don't even know they're infected. Find out about symptoms and treatment for this potentially dangerous liver disease.
symptoms: Yellow discoloration of the skin and eyes (jaundice)
Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech (hepatic encephalopathy)
Spiderlike blood vessels on your skin (spider angiomas)
risks: Are a health care worker who has been exposed to infected blood, which may happen if an infected needle pierces your skin
Have ever injected or inhaled illicit drugs
Received a piercing or tattoo in an unclean environment using unsterile equipment
Received a blood transfusion or organ transplant before 1992
Received hemodialysis treatments for a long period of time
Were born to a woman with a hepatitis C infection
Were born between 1945 and 1965, the age group with the highest incidence of hepatitis C infection
preventions: Stop using illicit drugs particularly if you inject them
Be cautious about body piercing and tattooing

name: Stress fracture
description: Stress fractures are tiny cracks in bones often caused by overuse or osteoporosis. Learn how to prevent and treat them.

name: Obstructive sleep apnea
description: Learn the signs that point to this common and potentially serious sleep disorder and find out the treatments that can help you sleep better.
symptoms: Observed episodes of stopped breathing during sleep
Abrupt awakenings accompanied by gasping or choking
Awakening with a dry mouth or sore throat
Mood changes, such as depression or irritability
risks: A family history of sleep apnea

name: Head and neck cancer
description: Learn about innovative treatment for throat cancers, mouth cancers, tongue cancers, tonsil cancers and other cancers that affect the head and neck.

name: Heart disease
description: Learn about symptoms, causes and treatment of cardiovascular disease, a term describing a wide range of conditions that can affect the heart.
symptoms: Chest pain, chest tightness, chest pressure and chest discomfort (angina)
Pain in the neck, jaw, throat, upper belly area or back
Pain, numbness, weakness or coldness in the legs or arms if the blood vessels in those body areas are narrowed
preventions: Eat a diet that's low in salt and saturated fat.
Exercise at least 30 minutes a day on most days of the week.
Control high blood pressure, high cholesterol and diabetes.
Get good sleep. Adults should aim for 7 to 9 hours daily.
diagnosis: Heart cardiac magnetic resonance imaging MRI scan

name: Pediatric obstructive sleep apnea
description: If your child's breathing becomes repeatedly blocked during sleep — either partially or completely — pediatric obstructive sleep apnea could be the cause.
risks: Abnormalities in the skull or face
Family history of obstructive sleep apnea
treatment: Removal of the tonsils and adenoids

name: Head lice infestation
description: Find out how these tiny insects that feed on blood from the human scalp can spread from person to person, along with treatment options.
symptoms: Lice eggs nits on hair shafts
Sores on the scalp neck and shoulders
preventions: Hang clothes on a separate hook from other children's clothes
Avoid sharing combs, brushes, hats and scarves
Avoid lying on beds, couches or pillows that have been in contact with a person who has head lice

name: Occupational asthma
description: Dust, fumes and other substances you come into contact with at work can cause asthma. Find out how to recognize this common type of asthma.
risks: You have existing allergies or asthma
Allergies or asthma runs in your family
You work around known asthma triggers

name: Stress incontinence
description: Coughing, laughing, running — all can lead to accidental urine leakage if you have stress incontinence. Learn about treatment options and self-care.
diagnosis: Physical exam, which may include a rectal exam and a pelvic exam in women
Urine sample to test for infection, traces of blood or other abnormalities
Brief neurological exam to identify any pelvic nerve problems
Urinary stress test, in which the provider observes urine loss when you cough or bear down

name: Coma
description: Learn what can cause this state of prolonged loss of consciousness. While a coma rarely lasts longer than a few weeks, some people never wake from one.
symptoms: Depressed brainstem reflexes, such as pupils not responding to light.
No responses of limbs except for reflex movements.
No response to painful stimuli except for reflex movements.
diagnosis: Events leading up to the coma such as vomiting or headaches.
Details about how the affected person lost consciousness, including whether it occurred quickly or over time.
Medical history, including other conditions the person may have had in the past. This includes whether the person has had a stroke or ministroke.
Recent changes in the person's health or behavior.
The person's drug use, including prescription and nonprescription medicines, unapproved medicines, and illicit drugs.

name: Carotid artery disease
description: Learn about carotid artery disease symptoms, prevention and treatment options including stenting, angioplasty and carotid endarterectomy.
preventions: Eat a variety of fruits and vegetables

name: Obsessive compulsive disorder
description: OCD features a pattern of unwanted thoughts and fears (obsessions), leading to repetitive behaviors (compulsions) that interfere with daily activities.
complications: Excessive time spent engaging in ritualistic behaviors
Health issues, such as contact dermatitis from frequent hand-washing
Difficulty attending work, school or social activities

name: Carotid artery disease
description: Learn about carotid artery disease symptoms, prevention and treatment options including stenting, angioplasty and carotid endarterectomy.
preventions: Eat a variety of fruits and vegetables

name: Albinism
description: In this group of inherited disorders, the body makes little or no melanin, a pigment that determines hair, skin and eye color and vision development.
diagnosis: A physical exam that includes checking skin and hair pigmentation.
Comparison of your child's pigmentation to that of other family members.
Review of your child's medical history, including whether there has been bleeding that doesn't stop, frequent or large bruises, or unexpected infections.
treatment: Skin care and prevention of skin cancer

name: Chronic daily headache
description: If you have a headache most days, you might have one of the most disabling headache conditions, chronic daily headaches. Aggressive treatment and long-term management might help.
causes: Inflammation or other problems with the blood vessels in and around the brain, including stroke
Intracranial pressure that's either too high or too low

name: Carotid artery disease
description: Learn about carotid artery disease symptoms, prevention and treatment options including stenting, angioplasty and carotid endarterectomy.
preventions: Eat a variety of fruits and vegetables

name: Stretch marks
description: Find out the symptoms of and treatment for this painless condition that causes streaks on the abdomen, breasts, hips, buttocks and thighs.
risks: Having a personal or family history of stretch marks
Being pregnant, especially if you're young
Having a genetic disorder such as Cushing syndrome or Marfan syndrome

name: Cluster headache
description: These painful headaches cause severe pain on one side of the head and tend to occur in frequent bouts called cluster periods.

name: Exercise headache
description: Learn about the causes and treatments of this puzzling disorder.
risks: Have a personal or family history of migraine
diagnosis: Your headaches last more than a few hours
Your headaches strike suddenly, like a thunderclap
You have other signs and symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting or vision disturbances

name: Stroke
description: Promptly spotting stroke symptoms leads to faster treatment and less damage to the brain.
symptoms: Trouble speaking and understanding what others are saying
Paralysis or numbness of the face arm or leg
Problems seeing in one or both eyes
complications: Paralysis or loss of muscle movement
Changes in behavior and selfcare ability
preventions: Lowering the amount of cholesterol and saturated fat in your diet
Eating a diet rich in fruits and vegetables
Drinking alcohol in moderation if at all

name: Carpal tunnel syndrome
description: Learn more about the symptoms, diagnosis and treatment of this common nerve disorder affecting the hand and arm.
preventions: Reduce your force and relax your grip
treatment: Take more-frequent breaks to rest the hands.
Avoid activities that make symptoms worse.
Apply cold packs to reduce swelling.

name: Residual limb pain
description: This common pain in the part of a limb that remains after an amputation has many causes and effective treatment options.

name: Ocular rosacea
description: Learn about symptoms, causes and treatments of ocular rosacea — an eye condition that often affects people who have skin rosacea.
symptoms: Red, burning, itchy or watering eyes
Grittiness or the feeling of having a foreign body in the eye or eyes
Dilated small blood vessels on the white part of the eye that are visible when you look in a mirror
Recurrent eye or eyelid infections, such as pink eye (conjunctivitis), blepharitis, sties or chalazia

name: Migraine
description: Find out about painful migraine headaches that can last hours to days. Other symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

name: Stuttering
description: Stuttering, sometimes called stammering, is a speech disorder that involves frequent and significant problems with normal fluency and flow of speech.
symptoms: Difficulty starting a word, phrase or sentence
Prolonging a word or sounds within a word
Repetition of a sound, syllable or word
Brief silence for certain syllables or words, or pauses within a word (broken word)
Addition of extra words such as "um" if difficulty moving to the next word is anticipated
Excess tension, tightness, or movement of the face or upper body to produce a word
complications: Not speaking or avoiding situations that require speaking
Loss of social, school, or work participation and success
treatment: Participate fully in school, work and social activities

name: Primary cough headache
description: Often triggered by coughing and other types of straining, these headaches can be harmless or signal another problem in the brain.
symptoms: Begin suddenly with and just after coughing or other types of straining
Typically last a few seconds to a few minutes — some can last up to two hours
Cause sharp, stabbing, splitting or "bursting" pain
Usually affect both sides of your head and may be worse in the back of your head
May be followed by a dull, aching pain for hours
preventions: Treating conditions that would cause coughing, such as bronchitis or other lung infections
Avoiding medications that cause coughing as a side effect
Using stool softeners to avoid constipation
Minimizing heavy lifting or bending for long periods

name: Albinism
description: In this group of inherited disorders, the body makes little or no melanin, a pigment that determines hair, skin and eye color and vision development.
diagnosis: A physical exam that includes checking skin and hair pigmentation.
Comparison of your child's pigmentation to that of other family members.
Review of your child's medical history, including whether there has been bleeding that doesn't stop, frequent or large bruises, or unexpected infections.
treatment: Skin care and prevention of skin cancer

name: Sty
description: A stye (sty) is a painful red bump along the eyelash line that can often be treated with home remedies. Find out more about this irritating eyelid infection.
symptoms: A red lump on your eyelid that is similar to a boil or a pimple
risks: Touch your eyes with unwashed hands
Insert your contact lenses without thoroughly disinfecting them or washing your hands first
Have blepharitis, a chronic inflammation along the edge of the eyelid
Have rosacea, a skin condition characterized by facial redness
preventions: Make sure your contact lenses are clean

name: Sex headache
description: Learn about the causes and treatment of this type of headache.
symptoms: A dull ache in the head and neck that intensifies as sexual excitement increases
A sudden, severe, throbbing headache that occurs just before or at the moment of orgasm
causes: A widening or bubble in the wall of an artery inside your head (intracranial aneurysm)
An irregular connection between arteries and veins in the brain (arteriovenous malformation) that bleeds into the spinal fluid-filled space in and around the brain
Bleeding into the wall of an artery leading to the brain (dissection)
Narrowing of the arteries in the brain (reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome)
Use of some medications, such as birth control pills

name: Horner syndrome
description: Find out about Horner syndrome, an interruption in nerve signals from the brain to the eye and face on one side of the body.
symptoms: A notable difference in pupil size between the two eyes (anisocoria)
Little or delayed opening (dilation) of the affected pupil in dim light
Slight elevation of the lower lid, sometimes called upside-down ptosis
Sunken appearance of the affected eye
Little or no sweating (anhidrosis) on the affected side of the face

name: Sinus headache
description: Sinus headaches are often to blame for headache with facial pain — but that pain might actually be a migraine.
symptoms: Pain, pressure and fullness in the cheeks, brow or forehead
Worsening pain if you bend forward or lie down
Achy feeling in the upper teeth
risks: A previous history of migraines or headaches
A family history of migraines or headaches
treatment: Pain relievers available without a prescription

name: Childhood apraxia of speech
description: Speech therapy can help children with this speech disorder that's caused by a problem with communication between the brain and the muscles used for speech.
symptoms: A limited number of spoken words
The ability to form only a few consonant or vowel sounds
complications: Delayed language, such as difficulty understanding speech, reduced vocabulary, or difficulty using correct grammar when putting words together in a phrase or sentence
Delays in intellectual and motor development and problems with reading, spelling and writing
Difficulties with gross and fine motor movement skills or coordination
Hypersensitivity, in which the child may not like some textures in clothing or the texture of certain foods, or the child may not like tooth brushing

name: Spinal headache
description: These headaches can happen after a spinal tap procedure or spinal anesthesia, and usually don’t require treatment.
symptoms: Dull, throbbing pain that varies in intensity from mild to very severe
Pain that typically gets worse when you sit up or stand and decreases or goes away when you lie down
risks: Being between the ages of 18 and 30
Having a history of frequent headaches
Undergoing procedures involving the use of larger needles or multiple punctures in the membrane that surrounds the spinal cord

name: Oppositional defiant disorder
description: This childhood mental health condition includes frequent and persistent anger, irritability, arguing, defiance or vindictiveness toward authority.
symptoms: Is frequently touchy and easily annoyed by others.
diagnosis: How often the behaviors occur and how severe they are.
Emotions and behavior in different settings and relationships.
Strategies that have been helpful ― or not helpful ― in managing problem behaviors.
Issues experienced by the child and the family due to the problem behaviors.
Other possible mental health, learning or communication problems.

name: Castleman disease
description: This rare disorder involves an overgrowth of cells in your body's lymph nodes. Treatment varies depending on how many lymph nodes are involved.

name: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
description: Find out more about diagnosis and treatment options for this bleeding in the brain.

name: Jaw tumors and cysts
description: Also called odontogenic tumors and cysts, these typically benign lesions develop in the jawbone or the soft tissues in the mouth. They vary in severity.
symptoms: Other types of cysts and tumors
diagnosis: Imaging studies, such as X-ray, CT or MRI
A biopsy to remove a sample of tumor or cyst cells for laboratory analysis
treatment: Reconstruction of the jawbone or other structures
Medical therapy for certain types of jaw tumors and cysts
Supportive care to help maintain your quality of life, including assisting with nutrition, speech and swallowing, and replacements for missing teeth

name: Subconjunctival hemorrhage
description: Subconjunctival hemorrhage is a broken blood vessel in the eye — learn more about this common, harmless condition that clears up without treatment.
risks: Certain blood-thinning medications, such as warfarin (Coumadin, Jantoven) and aspirin
diagnosis: Ask you questions about your general health and symptoms
Obtain a routine blood test to make sure you don't have a potentially serious bleeding disorder

name: Cataract
description: Are things starting to look fuzzy or blurry? Find out about symptoms, diagnosis and treatment for this common eye condition.
symptoms: Increasing difficulty with vision at night
Need for brighter light for reading and other activities
Frequent changes in eyeglass or contact lens prescription
Double vision in a single eye
preventions: Choose a healthy diet that includes plenty of fruits and vegetables

name: Infertility
description: Find out about the challenges of infertility, when to seek help, causes, risk factors, and treatments including insemination and in vitro fertilization.

name: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome
description: Learn about this possible complication of fertility treatments and how to recognize when you need to contact your care team.
risks: Polycystic ovary syndrome — a common reproductive disorder that causes irregular menstrual periods, excess hair growth and unusual appearance of the ovaries on ultrasound examination
High or steeply increasing level of estradiol (estrogen) before an HCG trigger shot
complications: Fluid collection in the abdomen and sometimes the chest
Blood clots in large vessels, usually in the legs
Rupture of a cyst in an ovary, which can lead to serious bleeding
Pregnancy loss from miscarriage or termination because of complications
preventions: Avoiding use of an HCG trigger shot

name: Drug addiction
description: Drug addiction affects your brain and behavior to the point where you can't control your use of legal or illegal drugs, even when you know they cause harm.
symptoms: Feeling that you have to use the drug regularly — daily or even several times a day
Having intense urges for the drug that block out any other thoughts
Over time, needing more of the drug to get the same effect
Taking larger amounts of the drug over a longer period of time than you intended
Making certain that you maintain a supply of the drug
Spending money on the drug, even though you can't afford it
Not meeting obligations and work responsibilities, or cutting back on social or recreational activities because of drug use
Continuing to use the drug, even though you know it's causing problems in your life or causing you physical or psychological harm
Doing things to get the drug that you normally wouldn't do, such as stealing
Driving or doing other risky activities when you're under the influence of the drug
Spending a good deal of time getting the drug, using the drug or recovering from the effects of the drug
Failing in your attempts to stop using the drug
Experiencing withdrawal symptoms when you attempt to stop taking the drug
complications: Methamphetamine, opiates and cocaine are highly addictive and cause multiple short-term and long-term health consequences, including psychotic behavior, seizures or death due to overdose. Opioid drugs affect the part of the brain that controls breathing, and overdose can result in death. Taking opioids with alcohol increases this risk.

GHB and flunitrazepam may cause sedation, confusion and memory loss. These so-called "date rape drugs" are known to impair the ability to resist unwanted contact and recollection of the event. At high doses, they can cause seizures, coma and death. The danger increases when these drugs are taken with alcohol.

MDMA ― also known as molly or ecstasy ― can interfere with the body's ability to regulate temperature. A severe spike in body temperature can result in liver, kidney or heart failure and death. Other complications can include severe dehydration, leading to seizures. Long-term, MDMA can damage the brain.

One particular danger of club drugs is that the liquid, pill or powder forms of these drugs available on the street often contain unknown substances that can be harmful, including other illegally manufactured or pharmaceutical drugs.
Due to the toxic nature of inhalants, users may develop brain damage of different levels of severity. Sudden death can occur even after a single exposure.
treatment: Individual, group or family therapy sessions
A focus on understanding the nature of addiction, becoming drug-free and preventing relapse
Levels of care and settings that vary depending on your needs, such as outpatient, residential and inpatient programs

name: Esthesioneuroblastoma
description: Find out about this rare cancer that begins in the upper portion of the nasal cavity. Learn about symptoms and treatments, including minimally invasive surgery.
complications: Cancer that grows to invade nearby structures
Loss of the sense of smell
diagnosis: Using a tiny flexible camera to see in your nose
Removing a sample of tissue for testing
Testing a tissue sample in a lab

name: Tension headache
description: These common headaches are commonly triggered by stress and may be managed through a regimen of healthy habits and medications.
symptoms: Sensation of tightness or pressure across the forehead or on the sides and back of the head
Tenderness in the scalp, neck and shoulder muscles

name: Cavernous malformations
description: Understand the signs and symptoms that may occur when blood vessels in the brain or spinal cord are tightly packed and contain slow-moving blood.
symptoms: Weakness in the arms or legs
Vision changes, such as double vision

name: Drug addiction
description: Drug addiction affects your brain and behavior to the point where you can't control your use of legal or illegal drugs, even when you know they cause harm.
symptoms: Feeling that you have to use the drug regularly — daily or even several times a day
Having intense urges for the drug that block out any other thoughts
Over time, needing more of the drug to get the same effect
Taking larger amounts of the drug over a longer period of time than you intended
Making certain that you maintain a supply of the drug
Spending money on the drug, even though you can't afford it
Not meeting obligations and work responsibilities, or cutting back on social or recreational activities because of drug use
Continuing to use the drug, even though you know it's causing problems in your life or causing you physical or psychological harm
Doing things to get the drug that you normally wouldn't do, such as stealing
Driving or doing other risky activities when you're under the influence of the drug
Spending a good deal of time getting the drug, using the drug or recovering from the effects of the drug
Failing in your attempts to stop using the drug
Experiencing withdrawal symptoms when you attempt to stop taking the drug
complications: Methamphetamine, opiates and cocaine are highly addictive and cause multiple short-term and long-term health consequences, including psychotic behavior, seizures or death due to overdose. Opioid drugs affect the part of the brain that controls breathing, and overdose can result in death. Taking opioids with alcohol increases this risk.

GHB and flunitrazepam may cause sedation, confusion and memory loss. These so-called "date rape drugs" are known to impair the ability to resist unwanted contact and recollection of the event. At high doses, they can cause seizures, coma and death. The danger increases when these drugs are taken with alcohol.

MDMA ― also known as molly or ecstasy ― can interfere with the body's ability to regulate temperature. A severe spike in body temperature can result in liver, kidney or heart failure and death. Other complications can include severe dehydration, leading to seizures. Long-term, MDMA can damage the brain.

One particular danger of club drugs is that the liquid, pill or powder forms of these drugs available on the street often contain unknown substances that can be harmful, including other illegally manufactured or pharmaceutical drugs.
Due to the toxic nature of inhalants, users may develop brain damage of different levels of severity. Sudden death can occur even after a single exposure.
treatment: Individual, group or family therapy sessions
A focus on understanding the nature of addiction, becoming drug-free and preventing relapse
Levels of care and settings that vary depending on your needs, such as outpatient, residential and inpatient programs

name: Dental cavities
description: Cavities, also called tooth decay, are permanently damaged areas in the hard surface of your teeth that develop into tiny openings or holes.
symptoms: Toothache, spontaneous pain or pain that occurs without any apparent cause
Mild to sharp pain when eating or drinking something sweet, hot or cold
Visible holes or pits in your teeth
Brown, black or white staining on any surface of a tooth
complications: Swelling or pus around a tooth
Positioning shifts of teeth after tooth loss
preventions: Brush with fluoride toothpaste after eating or drinking

name: Oligodendroglioma
description: Oligodendroglioma — Overview covers diagnosis and treatment of this brain and spinal cord tumor. Treatments include surgery, chemotherapy and radiation.
treatment: Steroid medicines to reduce brain swelling.
Medicine to improves alertness if you have severe fatigue.
Medicine to help with thinking and memory problems.

name: Sudden cardiac arrest
description: This medical emergency involves sudden loss of all heart activity. Learn how fast, appropriate care may help prevent death.
risks: A family history of coronary artery disease.

name: Median arcuate ligament syndrome
description: Stomach pain after eating isn't always due to indigestion. It could be MALS, also called celiac artery compression.
symptoms: Pain in the upper middle stomach area, which may go away when leaning forward
Stomach pain after eating, exercising or changing body position
Fear of eating food due to pain, leading to significant weight loss — usually greater than 20 pounds (9.1 kilograms)
diagnosis: Computerized tomography CT of the abdomen

name: Nail fungus
description: Learn about symptoms, treatment and prevention of this common infection among older adults that causes nails to discolor and crumble.
risks: Wearing shoes that make your feet sweat heavily
Having had athlete's foot in the past
Walking barefoot in damp public areas, such as swimming pools, gyms and shower rooms
Having a minor skin or nail injury
Having a skin condition that affects the nails, such as psoriasis
Having diabetes, blood flow problems or a weakened immune system
preventions: Keep your nails clean and dry. Wash your hands and feet regularly. Wash your hands after touching an infected nail. Dry well, apply an antifungal foot powder and moisturize your nails. Consider applying a nail hardener, which might help strengthen nails and cuticles.

Keep your nails trimmed. Cut nails straight across, smooth the edges with a file and file down thickened areas. Disinfect your nail clippers after each use. Letting your nails grow long creates more places for the fungus to grow.
Wear absorbent socks or change your socks throughout the day.
Choose shoes made of materials that breathe.
Discard old shoes or treat them with disinfectants or antifungal powders.
Wear footwear in pool areas and locker rooms.
Choose a nail salon that uses sterilized manicure tools for each customer. Or disinfect tools you use for home pedicures.
Give up nail polish and artificial nails.
If you have athlete's foot, treat it with an antifungal product.

name: Sudden infant death syndrome
description: Learn about possible causes, risks and prevention of the sudden unexplained death of a seemingly healthy baby in the first year of life.
preventions: Keep the crib as bare as possible
Have your baby sleep in in your room
Dont use baby monitors and other commercial devices that claim to reduce the risk of SIDS

name: Median arcuate ligament syndrome
description: Stomach pain after eating isn't always due to indigestion. It could be MALS, also called celiac artery compression.
symptoms: Pain in the upper middle stomach area, which may go away when leaning forward
Stomach pain after eating, exercising or changing body position
Fear of eating food due to pain, leading to significant weight loss — usually greater than 20 pounds (9.1 kilograms)
diagnosis: Computerized tomography CT of the abdomen

name: Oppositional defiant disorder
description: This childhood mental health condition includes frequent and persistent anger, irritability, arguing, defiance or vindictiveness toward authority.
symptoms: Is frequently touchy and easily annoyed by others.
diagnosis: How often the behaviors occur and how severe they are.
Emotions and behavior in different settings and relationships.
Strategies that have been helpful ― or not helpful ― in managing problem behaviors.
Issues experienced by the child and the family due to the problem behaviors.
Other possible mental health, learning or communication problems.

name: Thunderclap headache
description: These headaches are sudden and severe, and can warn of a life-threatening condition — so seek immediate medical attention.
symptoms: Can be accompanied by nausea or vomiting
causes: Bleeding between the brain and membranes covering the brain (subarachnoid hemorrhage)
A rupture of a blood vessel in the brain
A tear in the lining of an artery that supplies blood to the brain
Leaking of cerebrospinal fluid — usually due to a tear of the covering around a nerve root in the spine
Death of tissue or bleeding in the pituitary gland
A blood clot in the brain
Severe elevation in blood pressure (hypertensive crisis)
Infection such as meningitis or encephalitis

name: Median arcuate ligament syndrome
description: Stomach pain after eating isn't always due to indigestion. It could be MALS, also called celiac artery compression.
symptoms: Pain in the upper middle stomach area, which may go away when leaning forward
Stomach pain after eating, exercising or changing body position
Fear of eating food due to pain, leading to significant weight loss — usually greater than 20 pounds (9.1 kilograms)
diagnosis: Computerized tomography CT of the abdomen

name: Optic neuritis
description: Learn about this painful eye disorder that affects your optic nerve and what your doctor may recommend for treatment.
causes: Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein MOG antibody disorder

name: Celiac disease
description: In celiac disease, wheat protein (gluten) in food damages the small intestine, making it hard to absorb nutrients and causing a variety of symptoms.
risks: A family member with celiac disease or dermatitis herpetiformis

name: Mouth cancer
description: Learn what doctors and dentists look for when diagnosing mouth cancer. Find out about oral cancer treatments, including surgery, chemotherapy and radiation.
symptoms: A lip or mouth sore that doesn't heal
A white or reddish patch on the inside of your mouth
A growth or lump inside your mouth
risks: Tobacco use of any kind, including cigarettes, cigars, pipes, chewing tobacco and snuff, among others
Excessive sun exposure to your lips
A sexually transmitted virus called human papillomavirus (HPV)
preventions: Stop using tobacco or dont start
Drink alcohol only in moderation if at all
Avoid excessive sun exposure to your lips

name: Median arcuate ligament syndrome
description: Stomach pain after eating isn't always due to indigestion. It could be MALS, also called celiac artery compression.
symptoms: Pain in the upper middle stomach area, which may go away when leaning forward
Stomach pain after eating, exercising or changing body position
Fear of eating food due to pain, leading to significant weight loss — usually greater than 20 pounds (9.1 kilograms)
diagnosis: Computerized tomography CT of the abdomen

name: Oral thrush
description: Oral thrush is a fungal infection caused by the overgrowth of Candida albicans, which causes creamy white lesions on the tongue and lining of your mouth.
preventions: Brush your teeth at least twice a day and floss daily
Maintain good blood sugar control if you have diabetes

name: Barrett's esophagus
description: Barrett's esophagus, which is linked to chronic heartburn, can turn into cancer of the esophagus. Learn about treatment.
symptoms: Frequent heartburn and regurgitation of stomach contents

name: Headache in children
description: Find out more about headaches in children, which may or may not be serious. They can often be managed with medications and healthy habits.
risks: Children who have a family history of headaches or migraines

name: Suicidal behavior
description: Suicide can be prevented. Learn suicide warning signs and how to reach out for immediate help and professional treatment.
symptoms: Talking about suicide — for example, making statements such as "I'm going to kill myself," "I wish I were dead" or "I wish I hadn't been born"
Getting the means to take your own life, such as buying a gun or stockpiling pills
Withdrawing from social contact and wanting to be left alone
Having mood swings, such as being emotionally high one day and deeply discouraged the next
Being preoccupied with death, dying or violence
Feeling trapped or hopeless about a situation
Increasing use of alcohol or drugs
Changing normal routine, including eating or sleeping patterns
Doing risky or self-destructive things, such as using drugs or driving recklessly
Giving away belongings or getting affairs in order when there's no other logical explanation for doing this
Saying goodbye to people as if they won't be seen again
Developing personality changes or being severely anxious or agitated, particularly when experiencing some of the warning signs listed above
risks: Feel hopeless, worthless, agitated, socially isolated or lonely
Experience a stressful life event, such as the loss of a loved one, military service, a breakup, or financial or legal problems
Have a substance abuse problem — alcohol and drug abuse can worsen thoughts of suicide and make you feel reckless or impulsive enough to act on your thoughts
Have suicidal thoughts and have access to firearms in your home
Have an underlying psychiatric disorder, such as major depression, post-traumatic stress disorder or bipolar disorder
Have a family history of mental disorders, substance abuse, suicide, or violence, including physical or sexual abuse
Have a medical condition that can be linked to depression and suicidal thinking, such as chronic disease, chronic pain or terminal illness
Are lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender with an unsupportive family or in a hostile environment

name: Oral lichen planus
description: This chronic inflammatory condition results in white, lacy patches; red, swollen tissues; or open sores inside your mouth that may cause burning or pain.
complications: Secondary oral yeast or fungal infections
diagnosis: Discussion of your medical and dental history and the medications you're taking
Review of symptoms, including lesions in your mouth and any other places on your body
Examination of your mouth, and other areas as appropriate

name: Illness anxiety disorder
description: Excessive worry that you're seriously ill based on minor symptoms can result in major emotional distress and disrupt your life. Also called hypochondria.
symptoms: Being preoccupied with having or getting a serious disease or health condition
Worrying that minor symptoms or body sensations mean you have a serious illness
Being easily alarmed about your health status
Finding little or no reassurance from doctor visits or negative test results
Worrying excessively about a specific medical condition or your risk of developing a medical condition because it runs in your family
Having so much distress about possible illnesses that it's hard for you to function
Repeatedly checking your body for signs of illness or disease
Frequently making medical appointments for reassurance — or avoiding medical care for fear of being diagnosed with a serious illness
Avoiding people, places or activities for fear of health risks
Constantly talking about your health and possible illnesses
Frequently searching the internet for causes of symptoms or possible illnesses
risks: A time of major life stress
Threat of a serious illness that turns out not to be serious
History of abuse as a child
A serious childhood illness or a parent with a serious illness
Personality traits, such as having a tendency toward being a worrier
complications: Relationship or family problems because excessive worrying can frustrate others
Work-related performance problems or excessive absences
Problems functioning in daily life, possibly even resulting in disability
Financial problems due to excessive health care visits and medical bills
Having another mental health disorder, such as somatic symptom disorder, other anxiety disorders, depression or a personality disorder
preventions: If you have problems with anxiety seek professional advice
Learn to recognize when youre stressed and how this affects your body
diagnosis: Conduct a psychological evaluation to talk about your symptoms, stressful situations, family history, fears or concerns, and ways that your anxiety is negatively affecting your life
Have you fill out a psychological self-assessment or questionnaire
Ask you about alcohol, drug or other substance use
Determine whether your illness preoccupation is better explained by another mental disorder, such as somatic symptom disorder or generalized anxiety disorder.

name: Suicidal behavior
description: Suicide can be prevented. Learn suicide warning signs and how to reach out for immediate help and professional treatment.
symptoms: Talking about suicide — for example, making statements such as "I'm going to kill myself," "I wish I were dead" or "I wish I hadn't been born"
Getting the means to take your own life, such as buying a gun or stockpiling pills
Withdrawing from social contact and wanting to be left alone
Having mood swings, such as being emotionally high one day and deeply discouraged the next
Being preoccupied with death, dying or violence
Feeling trapped or hopeless about a situation
Increasing use of alcohol or drugs
Changing normal routine, including eating or sleeping patterns
Doing risky or self-destructive things, such as using drugs or driving recklessly
Giving away belongings or getting affairs in order when there's no other logical explanation for doing this
Saying goodbye to people as if they won't be seen again
Developing personality changes or being severely anxious or agitated, particularly when experiencing some of the warning signs listed above
risks: Feel hopeless, worthless, agitated, socially isolated or lonely
Experience a stressful life event, such as the loss of a loved one, military service, a breakup, or financial or legal problems
Have a substance abuse problem — alcohol and drug abuse can worsen thoughts of suicide and make you feel reckless or impulsive enough to act on your thoughts
Have suicidal thoughts and have access to firearms in your home
Have an underlying psychiatric disorder, such as major depression, post-traumatic stress disorder or bipolar disorder
Have a family history of mental disorders, substance abuse, suicide, or violence, including physical or sexual abuse
Have a medical condition that can be linked to depression and suicidal thinking, such as chronic disease, chronic pain or terminal illness
Are lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender with an unsupportive family or in a hostile environment

name: Oral thrush
description: Oral thrush is a fungal infection caused by the overgrowth of Candida albicans, which causes creamy white lesions on the tongue and lining of your mouth.
preventions: Brush your teeth at least twice a day and floss daily
Maintain good blood sugar control if you have diabetes

name: Age-related hearing loss
description: Age- and noise-related hearing loss are common and can affect quality of life. But many treatments are available.
symptoms: Muffling of speech and other sounds
Difficulty understanding words, especially against background noise or in a crowd
Frequently asking others to speak more slowly, clearly and loudly
Needing to turn up the volume of the television or radio

name: Cellulite
description: Learn more about this common skin condition that causes dimpling of the thighs and buttocks. Treatment may result in temporary improvement.

name: Heart arrhythmia
description: Learn about common heart rhythm disorders that can cause your heart to beat too fast, too slow or irregularly.
risks: Coronary artery disease other heart problems and previous heart surgery
Caffeine nicotine or illegal drug use
preventions: Limiting or avoiding caffeine and alcohol
Reducing stress, as intense stress and anger can cause heart rhythm problems
Using medications as directed and telling your doctor about all the medicines you take, including those bought without a prescription

name: Sun allergy
description: Learn more about the causes, symptoms and treatment of this itchy rash that is an allergic reaction to sunlight.
risks: Having a blood relative with a sun allergy
preventions: Avoid sun exposure between 10 am and 4 pm
Avoid sudden exposure to lots of sunlight

name: Heart attack
description: A blockage of blood flow to the heart can damage or destroy heart muscle.
symptoms: Chest pain that may feel like pressure, tightness, pain, squeezing or aching
Pain or discomfort that spreads to the shoulder, arm, back, neck, jaw, teeth or sometimes the upper belly
complications: Irregular or atypical heart rhythms arrhythmias
Inflammation of the saclike tissue surrounding the heart pericarditis

name: Orchitis
description: This inflammation of one or both testicles can cause pain and infertility. It's usually caused by a bacterial infection or the mumps virus.
symptoms: Swelling in one or both testicles
Pain ranging from mild to severe
risks: Having surgery that involves the genitals or urinary tract
Being born with an abnormality in the urinary tract
preventions: Get immunized against mumps, the most common cause of viral orchitis
Practice safe sex, to help protect against STIs that can cause bacterial orchitis

name: Polymorphous light eruption
description: Learn more about the symptoms and treatments for this sun-induced skin rash that usually appears in spring or summer, and also after using tanning beds.
risks: Having a family history of the condition

name: Congenital heart defects in adults
description: A heart problem present at birth may not cause symptoms until adulthood. Learn how adult congenital heart disease is treated and what complications may occur.
symptoms: Feeling tired very quickly with activity
Swelling of body tissue or organs (edema)
complications: High blood pressure in the lung arteries pulmonary hypertension

name: Orthostatic hypotension
description: This form of low blood pressure might cause dizziness, lightheadedness or fainting when rising from sitting or lying down.

name: Cellulitis
description: Find out more about this potentially serious skin infection and how a few simple skin care tips can help prevent it.
symptoms: An irritated area of skin that tends to expand
risks: Longterm chronic swelling of the arms or legs lymphedema
preventions: Wash the wound daily with soap and water
Ask your health care provider whether it would help to apply a protective cream or ointment
Cover the wound with a bandage
treatment: Signs and symptoms don't respond to oral antibiotics

name: Sunburn
description: Learn more about how UV rays harm your skin and what you can do for symptom sunburn relief and how to protect yourself from sun exposure.
symptoms: Inflamed skin, which looks pink or red on white skin and may be harder to see on brown or Black skin
Skin that feels warm or hot to the touch
Small, fluid-filled blisters, which may break
Headache, fever, nausea and fatigue, if the sunburn is severe
Eyes that feel painful or gritty
risks: Having white skin and red hair
Living or vacationing somewhere sunny, warm or at high altitude
Swimming or spraying your skin with water or baby oil, as wet skin tends to burn more than does dry skin
Mixing outdoor recreation and drinking alcohol
Regularly exposing unprotected skin to UV light from sunlight or artificial sources, such as tanning beds
Taking a drug that makes you more likely to burn (photosensitizing medication)
preventions: Avoid sun exposure between 10 am and 4 pm
Avoid sun tanning and tanning beds
Be aware of sunsensitizing medications and cosmetics

name: Heart disease
description: Learn about symptoms, causes and treatment of cardiovascular disease, a term describing a wide range of conditions that can affect the heart.
symptoms: Chest pain, chest tightness, chest pressure and chest discomfort (angina)
Pain in the neck, jaw, throat, upper belly area or back
Pain, numbness, weakness or coldness in the legs or arms if the blood vessels in those body areas are narrowed
preventions: Eat a diet that's low in salt and saturated fat.
Exercise at least 30 minutes a day on most days of the week.
Control high blood pressure, high cholesterol and diabetes.
Get good sleep. Adults should aim for 7 to 9 hours daily.
diagnosis: Heart cardiac magnetic resonance imaging MRI scan

name: Pectus excavatum
description: Pectus excavatum causes the breastbone to sink into the chest. This can affect heart and lung function. Surgery helps correct the deformity.

name: Osteoarthritis
description: This most common form of arthritis mainly affects joints in your hands, knees, hips and spine. There's no cure, but symptoms can be managed.

name: Heart failure
description: Learn about this chronic disease that needs lifelong management, and find out what treatments help you live longer and may even strengthen your heart.
preventions: Controlling certain conditions, such as high blood pressure and diabetes

name: Central nervous system vascular malformations
description: Central nervous system vascular malformations, such as arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) and others, affect the blood vessels in your brain or spinal cord.

name: Progressive supranuclear palsy
description: Learn about this brain disorder that interferes with the ability to walk, move your eyes, talk and eat.
symptoms: A loss of balance while walking
An inability to aim your eyes properly
complications: Falling, which could lead to head injuries, fractures and other injuries
Difficulty focusing your eyes, which also can lead to injuries
Difficulty sleeping, which can lead to a feeling of tiredness and excessive daytime sleeping
Problems swallowing, which can lead to choking or inhaling food or liquid into your airway (aspiration)
Pneumonia, which can be caused by aspiration and is the most common cause of death in people with progressive supranuclear palsy
Impulsive behaviors — for example, standing up without waiting for assistance — which can lead to falls
diagnosis: Are having a lot of unexplained falls
Have little or no response to Parkinson's medications
Have difficulty moving your eyes, particularly downward
treatment: Eyeglasses with bifocal or prism lenses

name: Central sleep apnea
description: Find out how a mix-up in brain signals can affect your breathing during sleep and learn how this breathing disorder can be treated.
symptoms: Observed episodes of not breathing or abnormal breathing patterns during sleep
Abrupt awakenings accompanied by shortness of breath
risks: Stroke brain tumor or a structural brainstem lesion

name: Cervical spondylosis
description: As people age, the spinal disks in the neck shrink and bone spurs often develop. If symptoms occur, nonsurgical treatments are usually effective.
symptoms: Tingling, numbness and weakness in the arms, hands, legs or feet
Lack of coordination and difficulty walking
Loss of bladder or bowel control
diagnosis: Checking the range of motion in your neck
Testing your reflexes and muscle strength to find out if there's pressure on your spinal nerves or spinal cord
Watching you walk to see if spinal compression is affecting your gait

name: Heart murmur
description: An irregular heart sound may be harmless or worrisome. Know the causes of heart murmurs and when treatment is needed.
symptoms: Blue or gray fingernails or lips
Heavy sweating with little or no activity
In infants, poor appetite and lack of growth
causes: When the heart is filling with blood (diastolic murmur)
When the heart is emptying (systolic murmur)
risks: Family history of heart problems linked to murmurs
Uncontrolled diabetes in the mother during pregnancy
German measles (rubella) in the mother during pregnancy
Use of certain medications, alcohol or illegal drugs by the mother during pregnancy

name: Swimmer's itch
description: Learn more about the symptoms, treatment and prevention of this itchy rash that usually affects people swimming in freshwater lakes.
risks: Spending time in water that's infested with certain parasites.
Forgetting to dry off with a towel after getting out of the water.
Being sensitive to the parasites that cause swimmer's itch.

name: Supraventricular tachycardia
description: SVT is an irregularly fast heartbeat. For many people, treatment and lifestyle changes can control or eliminate this type of heart rhythm disorder (arrhythmia).
symptoms: A fluttering or pounding in the chest (palpitations)
A pounding sensation in the neck
causes: Other heart conditions, such as Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
Drug misuse, including cocaine and methamphetamine
Certain medications, including asthma medications and cold and allergy drugs
risks: Coronary artery disease other heart disease or previous heart surgery

name: Heart palpitations
description: Know when and how feelings of a rapid, fluttering or pounding heartbeat are treated.
causes: Strong emotional responses, such as stress, anxiety or panic attacks
Stimulants, including caffeine, nicotine, cocaine, amphetamines, and cold and cough medications that contain pseudoephedrine
Hormone changes associated with menstruation, pregnancy or menopause
Too much or too little thyroid hormone
risks: Certain medicines that contain stimulants, such as some cold or asthma medications
Other heart problems, such as irregular heartbeats, structural heart changes, previous heart attack or previous heart surgery

name: Suspicious breast lumps
description: Most breast lumps are benign, but it's important to see your doctor for a prompt evaluation.
symptoms: A round, smooth and firm breast lump
A large, solid-feeling lump that moves easily under your skin
Skin redness or dimpling like an orange
Changes in breast size or shape

name: Brain aneurysm
description: Learn about the signs and symptoms that may occur when a thinning wall of a blood vessel in your brain bulges — and know when to get emergency care.
risks: Narrow aorta coarctation of the aorta
complications: Narrowed blood vessels in the brain
A buildup of fluid within the brain hydrocephalus

name: Heart valve disease
description: Learn about this condition in which one or more of your heart valves doesn't work properly.
symptoms: Whooshing sound (heart murmur) when a doctor is listening to the heart with a stethoscope
Abdominal swelling (more common with advanced tricuspid regurgitation)
Shortness of breath, particularly when active or lying down
Swelling of your ankles and feet
risks: History of certain infections that can affect the heart
History of certain forms of heart disease or heart attack
High blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes and other heart disease risk factors
Heart conditions present at birth (congenital heart disease)
treatment: Take blood thinners to reduce the risk of blood clots if you have a certain irregular heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation

name: Osteochondritis dissecans
description: Osteochondritis dissecans most commonly affects children who are very active in sports. Learn about the symptoms and treatment of this joint condition.

name: Supraventricular tachycardia
description: SVT is an irregularly fast heartbeat. For many people, treatment and lifestyle changes can control or eliminate this type of heart rhythm disorder (arrhythmia).
symptoms: A fluttering or pounding in the chest (palpitations)
A pounding sensation in the neck
causes: Other heart conditions, such as Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
Drug misuse, including cocaine and methamphetamine
Certain medications, including asthma medications and cold and allergy drugs
risks: Coronary artery disease other heart disease or previous heart surgery

name: Cerebral palsy
description: Damage to the developing brain, usually before birth, causes this disorder of movement, muscle tone or posture.
preventions: Seek early and continuous prenatal care
Avoid alcohol tobacco and illegal drugs

name: Sweating and body odor
description: Learn more about the causes, treatment and self-care of this skin condition. Unusual changes may mean a medical problem.
symptoms: You suddenly begin to sweat much more or less than usual
You experience night sweats for no apparent reason
You notice a change in your body odor

name: CSF leak
description: Cerebrospinal fluid leaks may originate from the brain or spine, causing headaches, dizziness and other symptoms.
causes: An epidural in the spine for pain relief, such as during labor and delivery
An injury to the head or spine
Abnormalities of the dura mater around the nerve roots in the spine
Abnormal connections between dura mater and veins (CSF-venous fistulas)
risks: Having a previous surgery or procedure on or around the spine
Connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome

name: Hyperhidrosis
description: Learn more about causes, symptoms, treatment and self-care tips for this embarrassing condition that causes heavy sweating unrelated to heat or exercise.

name: Heartburn
description: Occasional heartburn is a common, manageable condition — but when is it a problem?
symptoms: A burning pain in the chest that usually occurs after eating and may occur at night
Pain that worsens when lying down or bending over
A bitter or acidic taste in the mouth
risks: Alcohol, carbonated beverages, coffee or other caffeinated beverages

name: Stroke
description: Promptly spotting stroke symptoms leads to faster treatment and less damage to the brain.
symptoms: Trouble speaking and understanding what others are saying
Paralysis or numbness of the face arm or leg
Problems seeing in one or both eyes
complications: Paralysis or loss of muscle movement
Changes in behavior and selfcare ability
preventions: Lowering the amount of cholesterol and saturated fat in your diet
Eating a diet rich in fruits and vegetables
Drinking alcohol in moderation if at all

name: Sweet's syndrome
description: Learn about the symptoms, causes and treatment of this painful skin condition that most often affects women between the ages of 30 and 60.
symptoms: Painful small inflamed bumps on your arms, face, neck or back
Bumps that grow quickly in size, spreading into painful clusters up to an inch (2.5 centimeters) in diameter

name: Earwax blockage
description: Learn simple steps for treatment and self-care of this common problem, including earwax removal.
symptoms: Feeling of fullness in the ear
Ringing or noises in the ear (tinnitus)
Odor or discharge in the ear
Pain or infection in the ear

name: Edema
description: Learn about symptoms, causes and treatment of swelling caused by too much fluid in body tissues.
causes: Sitting or staying in one position for too long.
risks: Having a long-lasting illness, such as congestive heart failure or liver or kidney disease.
Having surgery that involves a lymph node.
complications: Swelling that gets more and more painful.
Increased risk of infection in the swollen area.
Less ability of the of arteries, veins, joints and muscles to stretch.

name: Cervical cancer
description: Screening with Pap tests can reduce the risk of this cancer that begins in the cervix. Learn more about symptoms, causes, prevention and treatment.
preventions: Ask your doctor about the HPV vaccine

name: Swimmer's ear
description: The moist environment from water remaining in your ear after swimming or bathing can lead to this infection in the outer ear canal.
risks: Excess moisture in your ear canal
complications: Bone and cartilage damage early skull base osteomyelitis
preventions: Use caution after an ear infection or surgery
Avoid putting foreign objects in your ear

name: Osteosarcoma
description: Learn about the symptoms and causes of this bone cancer that occurs most often in children. Find out about treatments, including limb-sparing operations.
symptoms: Bone injury or bone break for no clear reason
risks: Other bone disorders, such as Paget's disease of bone and fibrous dysplasia
Certain inherited or genetic conditions, including hereditary retinoblastoma, Bloom syndrome, Li-Fraumeni syndrome, Rothmund-Thomson syndrome and Werner syndrome

name: Cervical dystonia
description: This rare movement disorder causes neck muscles to contract involuntarily. This can make your head twist or turn into often painful positions.

name: Heat exhaustion
description: An overheated body can lead to dangerous symptoms. Get tips to prevent heat exhaustion and how to cool down quickly when it happens.
symptoms: Cool, moist skin with goose bumps when in the heat
preventions: Take extra precautions with certain medications
Never leave anyone in a parked car
Take it easy during the hottest parts of the day
Be cautious if youre at increased risk

name: Swimmer's itch
description: Learn more about the symptoms, treatment and prevention of this itchy rash that usually affects people swimming in freshwater lakes.
risks: Spending time in water that's infested with certain parasites.
Forgetting to dry off with a towel after getting out of the water.
Being sensitive to the parasites that cause swimmer's itch.

name: Osteomyelitis
description: Bones don't easily get infected, but certain situations, such as a serious injury, bloodstream infection or surgery, may lead to a bone infection.
symptoms: Swelling, warmth and redness over the area of the infection
Pain in the area of the infection

name: Cervical spondylosis
description: As people age, the spinal disks in the neck shrink and bone spurs often develop. If symptoms occur, nonsurgical treatments are usually effective.
symptoms: Tingling, numbness and weakness in the arms, hands, legs or feet
Lack of coordination and difficulty walking
Loss of bladder or bowel control
diagnosis: Checking the range of motion in your neck
Testing your reflexes and muscle strength to find out if there's pressure on your spinal nerves or spinal cord
Watching you walk to see if spinal compression is affecting your gait

name: Heat rash
description: Learn more about the symptoms, causes and treatment of this heat-related problem of the skin that affects people of all ages.
risks: Being a newborn, as newborns have immature sweat ducts
Living in a hot, humid climate
Being on bedrest for a long time and having a fever
preventions: In hot weather, dress in loose, lightweight clothing that wicks moisture away from the skin. Don't wrap newborns in too many layers.
In hot weather, limit physical activity. Stay in the shade or in an air-conditioned building. Or use a fan to circulate the air.
Keep your sleeping area cool and well ventilated.
Avoid creams and ointments that can block pores.
Avoid drugs that cause sweating, such as clonidine, beta blockers and opioids.

name: Swollen knee
description: This condition can be caused by trauma, overuse injuries, or an underlying disease or condition. A fluid sample from the knee may be needed for diagnosis.
preventions: Strengthen the muscles around your knee

name: Cervical spondylosis
description: As people age, the spinal disks in the neck shrink and bone spurs often develop. If symptoms occur, nonsurgical treatments are usually effective.
symptoms: Tingling, numbness and weakness in the arms, hands, legs or feet
Lack of coordination and difficulty walking
Loss of bladder or bowel control
diagnosis: Checking the range of motion in your neck
Testing your reflexes and muscle strength to find out if there's pressure on your spinal nerves or spinal cord
Watching you walk to see if spinal compression is affecting your gait

name: Avascular necrosis
description: A broken bone or dislocated joint can block blood flow to the bone, causing bone tissue to die.

name: Heatstroke
description: Know the signs and what to do for this dangerous increase in body temperature.
preventions: Take extra precautions with certain medications
Never leave anyone in a parked car
Take it easy during the hottest parts of the day
Be cautious if youre at increased risk
treatment: Pack you with ice and cooling blankets
Give you medications to stop your shivering

name: Swollen lymph node
description: Learn more about swollen lymph nodes, including possible causes and treatments your doctor may recommend.

name: Bone spurs
description: Joint damage due to osteoarthritis is the most common cause of bone spurs. Most bone spurs create no problems and don't need treatment.

name: Menorrhagia
description: Learn about the causes and treatment of heavy menstrual periods.
symptoms: Soaking through one or more sanitary pads or tampons every hour for several consecutive hours
Needing to use double sanitary protection to control your menstrual flow
Needing to wake up to change sanitary protection during the night
Bleeding for longer than a week
Passing blood clots larger than a quarter
Restricting daily activities due to heavy menstrual flow
Symptoms of anemia, such as tiredness, fatigue or shortness of breath

name: Metabolic syndrome
description: Having three or more specific risk factors, such as high blood pressure or abdominal fat, boosts your risk of type 2 diabetes and heart disease.
preventions: Getting at least 30 minutes of physical activity most days
Eating plenty of vegetables, fruits, lean protein and whole grains
Limiting saturated fat and salt in your diet

name: Cervicitis
description: Sexually transmitted infections are often the reason why a woman develops inflammation of the cervix, which can cause abnormal discharge and bleeding.
risks: Engage in high-risk sexual behavior, such as unprotected sex, sex with multiple partners or sex with someone who engages in high-risk behaviors
Began having sexual intercourse at an early age
Have a history of sexually transmitted infections

name: Plantar fasciitis
description: Learn about this most common cause of stabbing heel pain.
risks: Occupations that keep you on your feet

name: Craniosynostosis
description: This condition results in premature fusing of one or more of the joints between the bone plates of an infant's skull before the brain is fully formed.
symptoms: A misshapen skull, with the shape depending on which of the sutures are affected
Development of a raised, hard ridge along affected sutures, with a change in the shape of the head that's not typical

name: Osteoporosis
description: Fractures associated with this bone-weakening condition can be life-altering. Good nutrition, regular exercise and medications can help.
symptoms: Back pain, caused by a fractured or collapsed vertebra
A bone that breaks much more easily than expected

name: Helicobacter pylori infection
description: Learn more about the symptoms, tests and treatments of this infection with Helicobacter pylori bacteria.
symptoms: An ache or burning pain in your stomach (abdomen)
Stomach pain that may be worse when your stomach is empty
risks: Living without a reliable supply of clean water
Living with someone who has an H pylori infection

name: Synovial sarcoma
description: Synovial sarcoma is a rare type of cancer that tends to arise near large joints, particularly the knee, in young adults. The main treatment is surgery.

name: UNDEFINED_CONDITION_NAME
description: Learn more about this inflammatory, infectious disease caused by a parasite and found in the feces of the triatomine bug.
